(배가) 좌초되다, 이륙을 못하게 하다
voca.means_en:
floor / ground / land / earth / soil
The ground is the surface of the earth.
If you say that something takes place on the ground, you mean it takes place on the surface of the earth and not in the air.
You can refer to land as ground, especially when it has very few buildings or when it is considered to be special in some way.
You can use ground to refer to a place or situation in which particular methods or ideas can develop and be successful.
If an argument, belief, or opinion is grounded in something, that thing is used to justify it.
You use groundbreaking to describe things which you think are significant because they provide new and positive ideas, and influence the way people think about things.\n

A group of people or things is a number of people or things which are together in one place at one time.
A group is a set of people who have the same interests or aims, and who organize themselves to work or act together.
A group is a set of people, organizations, or things which are considered together because they have something in common.
A group is a number of separate commercial or industrial firms which all have the same owner.
If a number of things or people are grouped together or group together, they are together in one place or within one organization or system.

A grove is a group of trees that are close together.
Grove is often used as part of the name of a street.
Jack looked across the stream to the dark grove of trees.
The tree house was in the tallest tree in a grove of tall, bare trees.

voca.means_ko:
[g로우]
(크기, 수, 강도, 특질이) 커지다, 늘어나다, 증가하다, 
자라다, 성장하다, 증가하다
(차츰) ~하기 시작하다
voca.means_en:
grow - grew - grown / grow - grown - grown
The wet dog smell grew stranger.
When people, animals, and plants grow, they increase in size and change physically over a period of time.
If you grow a particular type of plant, you put seeds or young plants in the ground and look after them as they develop.
When someone's hair grows, it gradually becomes longer. Your nails also grow.
If someone grows their hair, or grows a beard or moustache, they stop cutting their hair or shaving so that their hair becomes longer. You can also grow your nails.
If someone grows mentally, they change and develop in character or attitude.
if somebody/something grows on you, you gradually like them/it more and more\n
if the colour or style of your hair grows out, it disappears as your hair grows\n
Jerry grew out of sucking his thumb.\n

when a person grows up, they become an adult
to spend the time you are a child in a particular place or in a particular way
to develop gradually
When a dog or other animal growls, it makes a low noise in its throat, usually because it is angry.\nThe tiger growled.\n

voca.means_ko: 으르렁 거리는, 화를 잘 내는, 성마는
voca.means_en: "He was too slow" a growly voice said.\n
A grown man or woman is one who is fully developed and mature, both physically and mentally.\n

The growth of something such as an industry, organization, or idea is its development in size, wealth, or importance.
The growth in something is the increase in it.
Someone's growth is the development and progress of their character.
Growth in a person, animal, or plant is the process of increasing in physical size and development.
You can use growth to refer to plants which have recently developed or which developed at the same time.

voca.means_ko: 원한, 유감, 뒤끝\n~을 주기 싫어하다, ~을 아까워하다
voca.means_en: If you have or bear a grudge against someone, you have unfriendly feelings towards them because of something they did in the past.\n

complain / protest / object / grumble / moan / whine / whinge
If someone grumbles, they complain about something in a bad-tempered way.
If something grumbles, it makes a low continuous sound.

voca.means_ko: 기분이 언짢은, 심술이 난, 성격이 나쁜
voca.means_en: If you say that someone is grumpy, you mean that they are bad-tempered and miserable.\n

voca.means_ko: [g롼t]\n(돼지가) 꿀꿀거리다, 불평하다, 투덜거리다\n꿀꿀거리는 소리, 불평, 불만
voca.means_en: If you grunt, you make a low sound, especially because you are annoyed or not interested in something.\nWhen an animal grunts, it makes a low rough noise.\n

voca.means_ko: 굳은 약속, 확약, 품질 보증서, \n보증, 담보, 채무보증\n보증하다, 단언하다
voca.means_en:
If one thing guarantees another, the first is certain to cause the second thing to happen.
If you guarantee something, you promise that it will definitely happen, or that you will do or provide it for someone.
If a company guarantees its product or work, they provide a guarantee for it.
Something that is a guarantee of something else makes it certain that it will happen or that it is true.
A guarantee is a written promise by a company to replace or repair a product free of charge if it has any faults within a particular time.

voca.means_ko: [가r-d]\n경비요원, 보초, 감시, 경비, 수비\n지키다, 보호하다, 경비를 보다
voca.means_en:
If you guard a place, person, or object, you stand near them in order to watch and protect them.
If you guard someone, you watch them and keep them in a particular place to stop them from escaping.
If you guard some information or advantage that you have, you try to protect it or keep it for yourself.
A guard is someone such as a soldier, police officer, or prison officer who is guarding a particular place or person.
A guard is a specially organized group of people, such as soldiers or policemen, who protect or watch someone or something.
On a train, a guard is a person whose job is to travel on the train in order to help passengers, check tickets, and make sure that the train travels safely and on time.
A guard is a protective device which covers a part of someone's body or a dangerous part of a piece of equipment.

voca.means_ko: ~이 생기지 않도록 조심/경계 하다\n~에 대한 대비책
voca.means_en: to do something to prevent something happening or to protect yourself from something\n"I'm guarding against the worst"\n
A guerrilla is someone who fights as part of an unofficial army, usually against an official army or police force.\n

If you guess something, you give an answer or provide an opinion which may not be true because you do not have definite knowledge about the matter concerned.
If you guess that something is the case, you correctly form the opinion that it is the case, although you do not have definite knowledge about it.
A guess is an attempt to give an answer or provide an opinion which may not be true because you do not have definite knowledge about the matter concerned.
to try to imagine something or make a judgement without knowing all the facts\n

A guest is someone who is visiting you or is at an event because you have invited them.
A guest is someone who visits a place or organization or appears on a radio or television show because they have been invited to do so.
A guest is someone who is staying in a hotel.

take / lead / escort / drive / show / guide / usher / direct
A guide is a book that gives you information or instructions to help you do or understand something.
A guide is a book that gives tourists information about a town, area, or country.
A guide is someone who shows tourists around places such as museums or cities.
If you guide someone around a city, museum, or building, you show it to them and explain points of interest.
If you guide someone somewhere, you go there with them in order to show them the way.

voca.means_ko: (직업, 관심, 목적 등이 같은 사람들의) 협회, 조합\n길드(중세 시대 기능인들의 조합)
voca.means_en: A guild is an organization of people who do the same job.\n
Guilt is an unhappy feeling that you have because you have done something wrong or think that you have done something wrong.\nGuilt is the fact that you have done something wrong or illegal.\n
things you say to somebody in order to make them feel guilty about something\n

If you feel guilty, you feel unhappy because you think that you have done something wrong or have failed to do something which you should have done.
Guilty is used of an action or fact that you feel guilty about.
If someone is guilty of a crime or offence, they have committed that crime or offence.
If someone is guilty of doing something wrong, they have done that thing.

voca.means_ko: 외관, 모습, 겉치레, 가장, 옷차림, 복장\n(흔히 평상시와 다르거나 가장된) 겉모습/외피
voca.means_en: You use guise to refer to the outward appearance or form of someone or something, which is often temporary or different from their real nature.\n
A gull is a common sea bird.\n

voca.means_ko: (보통 시냇물이나 빗물에 의해 생긴) 도랑\n(깊은) 배수로
voca.means_en: A gully is a long narrow valley with steep sides.\n

voca.means_ko:
[갈p]
숨이 막히다, 목을 꿀꺽하다,
꿀꺽꿀꺽 삼키다, 벌컥벌컥 마시다 
(특히 공포, 놀라움에 질려) 침을 꿀꺽 삼키다
꿀꺽꿀꺽 삼킴, 꿀꺽 마시기
voca.means_en:
If you gulp something, you eat or drink it very quickly by swallowing large quantities of it at once.
If you gulp, you swallow air, often making a noise in your throat as you do so, because you are nervous or excited.
If you gulp air, you breathe in a large amount of air quickly through your mouth.
A gulp of air, food, or drink, is a large amount of it that you swallow at once.
to stop yourself showing that you are upset by swallowing hard\n

voca.means_ko: [검]\n껌, 잇몸, 치은, 고무, 눈곱\n풀칠을 하다, (풀로) 붙이다
voca.means_en:
Gum is a substance, usually tasting of mint, which you chew for a long time but do not swallow.
Your gums are the areas of firm, pink flesh inside your mouth, which your teeth grow out of.
Gum is a type of glue that is used to stick two pieces of paper together.
If two things are gummed together, they are stuck together.

voca.means_ko: (움직이거나 작동을 못 하도록 무엇에) \n끈적한 물질/접착제 을 발라 버리다
voca.means_en: to fill something with a sticky substance so that it cannot move or work\n

A gun is a weapon from which bullets or other things are fired.
A gun or a starting gun is an object like a gun that is used to make a noise to signal the start of a race.
To gun an engine or a vehicle means to make it start or go faster by pressing on the accelerator pedal.
A gurney is a bed on wheels that is used in hospitals for moving sick or injured people.\n

voca.means_ko:
[가쉬]
(액체가) 솟구치다, 쏟아져 나오다,
(액체를 갑자기) 쏟아 내다
(액체가 많은 양이) 솟구침, 분출
voca.means_en:
When liquid gushes out of something, or when something gushes a liquid, the liquid flows out very quickly and in large quantities.
If someone gushes, they express their admiration or pleasure in an exaggerated way.
A gush of liquid is a sudden, rapid flow of liquid, or a quantity of it that suddenly flows out.

voca.means_ko: [가쉬]\n쏟아져 나오는, 분출하는, \n지나치게 감정적인, 과장된 말을 하는
voca.means_en: displaying excessive admiration or sentimentality\n

voca.means_ko: 세찬 바람, 돌풍, 돌풍, \n(물, 연기 등의) 갑작스런 분출, 격발, 폭발\n(바람) 급격하게 불다, 분출하다
voca.means_en:
A gust is a short, strong, sudden rush of wind.
If you feel a gust of emotion, you feel the emotion suddenly and intensely.
When the wind gusts, it blows with short, strong, sudden rushes.
A gust of wind blew the canoe.

voca.means_ko: (특히 동물의) 내장, \n내용, 알맹이, 본질, 끈기, 용기\n본능적인, 감정적인, 근본적인
voca.means_en:
A person's or animal's guts are all the organs inside them.
The gut is the tube inside the body of a person or animal through which food passes while it is being digested.
Guts is the will and courage to do something which is difficult or unpleasant, or which might have unpleasant results.
A gut feeling is based on instinct or emotion rather than reason.
A gymnasium is the same as a gym.\n
of, relating to, like, or involving gymnastics\n

voca.means_ko: (특히 독일에서 대학 교수의) 자격을 얻다\n(사회 복귀를 위해) 교육[훈련]하다\n
voca.means_en: to equip and finance (a mine)\nto qualify for office\n

A habit is something that you do often or regularly.
A habit is an action which is considered bad that someone does repeatedly and finds it difficult to stop doing.
A drug habit is an addiction to a drug such as heroin or cocaine.
A habit is a piece of clothing shaped like a long loose dress, which a nun or monk wears.
The habitat of an animal or plant is the natural environment in which it normally lives or grows.\n

voca.means_ko: 흥정하다, 옥신각신\n(특히 물건 값을 두고) 실랑이를 벌이다, 흥정을 하다
voca.means_en: If you haggle, you argue about something before reaching an agreement, especially about the cost of something that you are buying.\n

voca.means_ko:
[헤일]
~에게 인사하다, 환영하다,
(신문 등에서 아주 훌륭하거나 특별한 것으로) 
묘사하다/일컫다
(택시?버스 등에[을]) 신호를 보내다/부르다
(사람을[에게]) 부르다/소리치다
인사, 환영, 싸라기눈, 우박
voca.means_en:
If a person, event, or achievement is hailed as important or successful, they are praised publicly.
When it hails, hail falls like rain from the sky.
Someone who hails from a particular place was born there or lives there.
If you hail a taxi, you wave at it in order to stop it because you want the driver to take you somewhere.
Hail consists of small balls of ice that fall like rain from the sky.
A hail of things, usually small objects, is a large number of them that hit you at the same time and with great force.
to come from or to live in a particular place\n
A hailstorm is a storm during which it hails.\n

Your hair is the fine threads that grow in a mass on your head.
Hair is the short, fine threads that grow on different parts of your body.
Hair is the threads that cover the body of an animal such as a dog, or make up a horse's mane and tail.
A hairpiece is a piece of false hair that some people wear on their head if they are bald or if they want to make their own hair seem longer or thicker.\n
Someone or something that is hairy is covered with hairs.\nIf you describe a situation as hairy, you mean that it is exciting, worrying, and rather frightening.\n

half / whole / quarter
Half of an amount or object is one of two equal parts that together make up the whole number, amount, or object.
You use half to say that something is only partly the case or happens to only a limited extent.
You use half to say that someone has parents of different nationalities. For example, if you are half German, one of your parents is German but the other is not.
In games such as football, rugby, and basketball, matches are divided into two equal periods of time which are called halves.
(complete, achieve, etc.) the most difficult part of something\n

voca.means_ko: (시간, 거리상으로) 중간의, 절반의\n중간쯤까지, 거의, 다소라도, 부분적으로\n꽤 괜찮은
voca.means_en:
Halfway means in the middle of a place or between two points, at an equal distance from each of them.
Halfway means in the middle of a period of time or of an event.
Halfway means reasonably.
"We're halfway there." said Jack.

The hall in a house or flat is the area just inside the front door, into which some of the other rooms open.
A hall in a building is a long passage with doors into rooms on both sides of it.
If students live in hall in British English, or in a hall in American English, they live in a university or college building called a hall of residence.
Hall is sometimes used as part of the name of a large house in the country.

A hallway in a building is a long passage with doors into rooms on both sides of it.
A hallway in a house or flat is the area just inside the front door, into which some of the other rooms open.
in AM, use entrance hall

voca.means_ko: [할t]\n멎다, 정지하다, ~ 을 그만두게 하다\n중지, 정지, 휴지
voca.means_en:
When a person or a vehicle halts or when something halts them, they stop moving in the direction they were going and stand still.
When something such as growth, development, or activity halts or when you halt it, it stops completely.
'Halt!' is a military order to stop walking or marching and stand still.
If someone calls a halt to something such as an activity, they decide not to continue with it or to end it immediately.

beat / batter / pound / pummel / lash / hammer
A hammer is a tool that consists of a heavy piece of metal at the end of a handle. It is used, for example, to hit nails into a piece of wood or a wall, or to break things into pieces.
In athletics, a hammer is a heavy weight on a piece of wire, which the athlete throws as far as possible.
If you hammer an object such as a nail, you hit it with a hammer.
If you hammer on a surface, you hit it several times in order to make a noise, or to emphasize something you are saying when you are angry.

voca.means_ko: ~을 저지하다, 방해하다\n큰 바구니, 식료품이 든 광주리
voca.means_en:
If someone or something hampers you, they makes it difficult for you to do what you are trying to do.
A hamper is a basket containing food of various kinds that is given to people as a present.
A hamper is a large basket with a lid, used especially for carrying food in.

Your hands are the parts of your body at the end of your arms. Each hand has four fingers and a thumb.
The hand of someone or something is their influence in an event or situation.
If you say that something is in a particular person's hands, you mean that they are looking after it, own it, or are responsible for it.
If you ask someone for a hand with something, you are asking them to help you in what you are doing.

voca.means_ko: 제출하다, 손으로 건내다\n(과제물 등을) 제출하다[내다]; (분실물 등을) 인계하다
voca.means_en: to give a piece of work to somebody, such as a teacher, so that they can correct, read or deal with it; to give something to somebody in authority because it belongs to them or is lost\nto tell somebody officially that you intend to leave your job\n
holding each other's hand, usually as a sign of affection\n
He went hand over hand.\n

Handcuffs are two metal rings which are joined together and can be locked round someone's wrists, usually by the police during an arrest.\nIf you handcuff someone, you put handcuffs around their wrists.\n

A handful of people or things is a small number of them.
A handful of something is the amount of it that you can hold in your hand.
If you say that someone, especially a child, is a handful, you mean that they are difficult to control.

A handicap is a physical or mental disability.
A handicap is an event or situation that places you at a disadvantage and makes it harder for you to do something.
In golf, a handicap is an advantage given to someone who is not a good player, in order to make the players more equal. As you improve, your handicap gets lower.
In horse racing, a handicap is a race in which some competitors are given a disadvantage of extra weight in an attempt to give everyone an equal chance of winning.
disabled / handicapped\nSomeone who is handicapped has a physical or mental disability that prevents them living a totally normal life. Many people who have a disability find this word offensive.\n

A handle is a small round object or a lever that is attached to a door and is used for opening and closing it.
A handle is the part of an object such as a tool, bag, or cup that you hold in order to be able to pick up and use the object.
If you have a handle on a subject or problem, you have a way of approaching it that helps you to understand it or deal with it.
If you say that someone can handle a problem or situation, you mean that they have the ability to deal with it successfully

A handout is a gift of money, clothing, or food, which is given free to poor people.
If you call money that is given to someone a handout, you disapprove of it because you believe that the person who receives it has done nothing to earn or deserve it.
A handout is a document which contains news or information about something and which is given, for example, to journalists or members of the public.
A handout is a paper containing a summary of information or topics which will be dealt with in a lecture or talk.

beautiful / pretty / handsome / attractive / lovely / good-looking / gorgeous
A handsome man has an attractive face with regular features.
A handsome woman has an attractive appearance with features that are large and regular rather than small and delicate.
A handsome sum of money is a large or generous amount.
If someone has a handsome win or a handsome victory, they get many more points or votes than their opponent.

Something that is handy is useful.
A thing or place that is handy is nearby and therefore easy to get or reach.
Someone who is handy with a particular tool is skilful at using it.
If something comes in handy, it is useful in a particular situation.

voca.means_ko: 잡역부, 숙련공, 사환\n(취미로나 직업으로) 집 안팎의 잔손질 보는 일을 잘하는 사람
voca.means_en: A handyman is a man who earns money by doing small jobs for people such as making and repairing things in their houses. You can also describe a man who is good at making or repairing things in his home as a handyman.\n

If something hangs in a high place or position, or if you hang it there, it is attached there so it does not touch the ground.
If a piece of clothing or fabric hangs in a particular way or position, that is how it is worn or arranged.
If something hangs loose or hangs open, it is partly fixed in position, but is not firmly held, supported, or controlled, often in such a way that it moves freely.
If someone is hanged or if they hang, they are killed, usually as a punishment, by having a rope tied around their neck and the support taken away from under their feet.

to attach something from the top to a hook, a piece of string, etc. so that the lower part is free or loose; to be attached in this way
to end a telephone conversation, often very suddenly, by putting down the part of the telephone that you speak into (the receiver) or switching the telephone off
to finish using something for the last time; to give up a particular activity, profession, etc.

If someone wakes up with a hangover, they feel sick and have a headache because they have drunk a lot of alcohol the night before.\nSomething that is a hangover from the past is an idea or way of behaving which people used to have in the past but which people no longer generally have.\n

voca.means_ko: 계획성 없는, 무작정의\n우연히, 아무렇게나, 되는데로, 무턱대고
voca.means_en: If you describe something as haphazard, you are critical of it because it is not at all organized or is not arranged according to a plan.\n

voca.means_ko: (특히 계획하지 않은일이) 일어나다, 발생하다, 벌어지다\n(무엇의 결과로) 일어나다/되다\n우연히 ~하다
voca.means_en:
Something that happens occurs or is done without being planned.
If something happens, it occurs as a result of a situation or course of action.
When something, especially something unpleasant, happens to you, it takes place and affects you.
If you happen to do something, you do it by chance. If it happens that something is the case, it occurs by chance.
to find or meet somebody/something by chance\n

voca.means_ko: 행복하게, 만족 스럽게, 기꺼이, \n다행히도, 운 좋게도,
voca.means_en: You can add happily to a statement to indicate that you are glad that something happened or is true.\n
satisfaction / happiness / contentment / fulfilment / glee\n

glad / happy / pleased / delighted / thrilled / overjoyed
Someone who is happy has feelings of pleasure, usually because something nice has happened or because they feel satisfied with their life.
A happy time, place, or relationship is full of happy feelings and pleasant experiences, or has an atmosphere in which people feel happy.
If you are happy about a situation or arrangement, you are satisfied with it, for example because you think that something is being done in the right way.

A harbour is an area of the sea at the coast which is partly enclosed by land or strong walls, so that boats can be left there safely.
If you harbour an emotion, thought, or secret, you have it in your mind over a long period of time.
If a person or country harbours someone who is wanted by the police, they let them stay in their house or country and offer them protection.

voca.means_ko:
단단한, 굳은, 딱딱한, 
어려운, 곤란한/힘든
열심히, 과도하게
명백한, 엄연한
(날씨가) 매서운/혹독한
voca.means_en:
hard / hardly
Something that is hard is very firm and stiff to touch and is not easily bent, cut, or broken.
Something that is hard is very difficult to do or deal with.
If you say that something is hard on a person or thing, you mean it affects them in a way that is likely to cause them damage or suffering.

hard / hardly
hardly / scarcely / barely / no sooner
You use hardly to modify a statement when you want to emphasize that it is only a small amount or detail which makes it true, and that therefore it is best to consider the opposite statement as being true.
You use hardly in expressions such as hardly ever, hardly any, and hardly anyone to mean almost never, almost none, or almost no-one.
You use hardly before a negative statement in order to emphasize that something is usually true or usually happens.

voca.means_ko: 손해, 손상, 불편\n해치다; 해를 끼치다, 손상시키다
voca.means_en:
damage / hurt / harm / impair / prejudice
To harm a person or animal means to cause them physical injury, usually on purpose.
To harm a thing, or sometimes a person, means to damage them or make them less effective or successful than they were.
Harm is physical injury to a person or an animal which is usually caused on purpose.
Harm is the damage to something which is caused by a particular course of action.
Something that is harmful has a bad effect on something else, especially on a person's health.\n

If people are living in harmony with each other, they are living together peacefully rather than fighting or arguing.
Harmony is the pleasant combination of different notes of music played at the same time.
The harmony of something is the way in which its parts are combined into a pleasant arrangement.

voca.means_ko:
[하아r쉬]
가혹한, 냉혹한, 혹독한, 거친, 냉엄한
(너무 강하거나 밝거나 추해서) 눈에 거슬리는, 야한
귀에 거슬리는, 듣기 싫은
(손상을 줄 수 있을 정도로) 너무 쌘
voca.means_en:
Harsh climates or conditions are very difficult for people, animals, and plants to live in.
Harsh actions or speech are unkind and show no understanding or sympathy.
Something that is harsh is so hard, bright, or rough that it seems unpleasant or harmful.
Harsh voices and sounds are ones that are rough and unpleasant to listen to.
If you talk about harsh realities or facts, or the harsh truth, you are emphasizing that they are true or real, although they are unpleasant and people try to avoid thinking about them.

voca.means_ko: ~을 부당하게 나무라다, \n~에게 잔소리 하다, 듣기 싫은 소리를 하다
voca.means_en: to criticize somebody\n

The harvest is the gathering of a crop.
A harvest is the crop that is gathered in.
When you harvest a crop, you gather it in.

A hassle is a situation that is difficult and involves problems, effort, or arguments with people.\nIf someone hassles you, they cause problems for you, often by repeatedly telling you or asking you to do something, in an annoying way.\n
Haste is the quality of doing something quickly, sometimes too quickly so that you are careless and make\nIf you do something in haste, you do it quickly and hurriedly, and sometimes carelessly.\n

voca.means_ko: 알에서 까다, 부화하다, \n(특히 비밀리에 계획등을) 만들어 내다, 기획하다\n부화, (항공기, 우주선의) 출입문
voca.means_en:
When a baby bird, insect, or other animal hatches, or when it is hatched, it comes out of its egg by breaking the shell.
When an egg hatches or when a bird, insect, or other animal hatches an egg, the egg breaks open and a baby comes out.
If you hatch a plot or a scheme, you think of it and work it out.
A hatch is an opening in the deck of a ship, through which people or cargo can go. You can also refer to the door of this opening as a hatch.
when a bird, an insect, etc. hatches out, it comes out of the egg; when an egg hatches out, it breaks open and a bird, an insect, etc. comes out\n

hate / hatred
hate / dislike / can’t stand / despise / can’t bear / loathe / detest
If you hate someone or something, you have an extremely strong feeling of dislike for them.
If you say that you hate something such as a particular activity, you mean that you find it very unpleasant.
You can use hate in expressions such as 'I hate to say it' or 'I hate to tell you' when you want to express regret about what you are about to say, because you think it is unpleasant or should not be the case.
You use haughty to describe someone's behaviour or appearance when you disapprove of the fact that they seem to be very proud and to think that they are better than other people.\n

voca.means_ko: 잡아끌다, 차로 운반하다, 수송하다, 체포하다\n(몸을) 간심히 움직이다\n세게 끌기, 잡아당기기, 수송량, 수송 거리
voca.means_en:
If you haul something which is heavy or difficult to move, you move it using a lot of effort.
A haul is a quantity of things that are stolen, or a quantity of stolen or illegal goods found by police or customs.
Annie and Jack were hauled onto the deck
He hauled himself into the rowboat.

voca.means_ko:
가지다, 있다, 소유하다, 경험하다
~ 으로 되어/이루어져 있다
(어떤 특징, 특질이) 있다
(경험을) 격다/하다
voca.means_en:
You use have to say that someone or something owns a particular thing, or when you are mentioning one of their qualities or characteristics.
If you have something to do, you are responsible for doing it or must do it.
You can use have instead of 'there is' to say that something exists or happens. For example, you can say 'you have no alternative' instead of 'there is no alternative', or 'he had a good view from his window' instead of 'there was a good view from his window'.
attempt to do, win or achieve something\n
used for asking somebody to be sympathetic or kind\n

voca.word: have a long way to go
voca.means_en: need to make a lot of progress before you can achieve something\n
talk too much, especially about things that are private\n
to joke with somebody by pretending something is true when it is not\n
to receive something that has been borrowed or taken from you\n

voca.means_ko: ~을 입고/쓰고/신고/매고 있다\n(장치를) 켜둔 체로 두다\n(계획, 일 등이) 잡혀/예정되어 있다
voca.means_en: to be wearing something\n
to have a tooth or an organ of your body removed\nto talk to somebody openly to try to settle a disagreement\n

voca.means_ko:
[하k]
매, 매와 비슷한 새의 총칭
(물건을) 팔러다니다, 행상을 하다
(기침을 하며) 가래를 뱉다
voca.means_en:
A hawk is a large bird with a short, hooked beak, sharp claws, and very good eyesight. Hawks catch and eat small birds and animals.
In politics, if you refer to someone as a hawk, you mean that they believe in using force and violence to achieve something, rather than using more peaceful or diplomatic methods. Compare dove.
If someone hawks goods, they sell them by walking through the streets or knocking at people's houses, and asking people to buy them.
You can say that someone is hawking something if you do not like the forceful way in which they are asking people to buy it.

Hay is grass which has been cut and dried so that it can be used to feed animals.\nIf you say that someone is making hay or is making hay while the sun shines, you mean that they are taking advantage of a situation that is favourable to them while they have the chance to.\n

voca.means_ko: [하져rd]\n위험 (요소), 위험을 초래하는 원인\n과감히 말하다, 용기를 내어 해보다
voca.means_en:
A hazard is something which could be dangerous to you, your health or safety, or your plans or reputation.
If you hazard someone or something, you put them into a situation which might be dangerous for them.
If you hazard or if you hazard a guess, you make a suggestion about something which is only a guess and which you know might be wrong.
Something that is hazardous is dangerous, especially to people's health or safety.\n

voca.means_ko:
[헤이-z]
연무, 실안개, (시야를 가리는) 희부연 것, 
(정신이) 몽롱한/흐리멍텅 한 상태
연무/실안개로 뒤덮이다
voca.means_en: Haze is light mist, caused by particles of water or dust in the air, which prevents you from seeing distant objects clearly. Haze often forms in hot weather.\nIf there is a haze of something such as smoke or steam, you cannot see clearly through it.\n

voca.means_ko:
[헤이즤]
연무/실안개가 낀, (연무가 끼어) 흐릿한
(기억이) 흐릿한/모호한
확신이 없는, 혼란스러워 하는
voca.means_en:
Hazy weather conditions are those in which things are difficult to see, because of light mist, hot air, or dust.
If you are hazy about ideas or details, or if they are hazy, you are uncertain or confused about them.
If things seem hazy, you cannot see things clearly, for example because you are feeling ill.

voca.means_ko: ~을 이끌다, 나아가다, 향하다\n머리, 지도자, 두뇌, 절정, 정점\n주요한, 주된, 머리의, 앞쪽에서 오는
voca.means_en:
Your head is the top part of your body, which has your eyes, mouth, and brain in it.
If someone or something heads a line or procession, they are at the front of it.
If you toss a coin and it comes down heads, you can see the side of the coin which has a picture of a head on it.
to intercept and force to change direction\nShe headed off through the gloom.\n
If you have a headache, you have a pain in your head.\nIf you say that something is a headache, you mean that it causes you difficulty or worry.\n
with the head foremost; headlong\nrashly or carelessly\n

voca.means_ko: (머리부터) 거꾸로, 곤두박질쳐서\n저돌적으로, 성급하게, 앞뒤 살피지 않고, 황급히
voca.means_en:
If you move headlong in a particular direction, you move there very quickly.
If you fall or move headlong, you fall or move with your head furthest forward.
If you rush headlong into something, you do it quickly without thinking carefully about it.

voca.means_ko:
[히-입]
(아무렇게나 쌓아 놓은) 더미/무더기
많음
(아무렇게나) 쌓다
(A에 B를) 쌓아 올리다, 수북히 담다
voca.means_en:
A heap of things is a pile of them, especially a pile arranged in a rather untidy way.
Heaps of something or a heap of something is a large quantity of it.
If you heap things somewhere, you arrange them in a large pile.
If you heap praise or criticism on someone or something, you give them a lot of praise or criticism.
Someone who is at the bottom of the heap or at the top of the heap is low down or high up in society or an organization.

When you hear a sound, you become aware of it through your ears.
If you hear something such as a lecture or a piece of music, you listen to it.
If you say that you can hear someone saying something, you mean that you are able to imagine hearing it.
When a judge or a court of law hears a case, or evidence in a case, they listen to it officially in order to make a decision about it.
If you hear from someone, you receive a letter or telephone call from them.
to be told news or information about somebody/something\n

Your heart is the organ in your chest that pumps the blood around your body. People also use heart to refer to the area of their chest that is closest to their heart.
You can refer to someone's heart when you are talking about their deep feelings and beliefs
You use heart when you are talking about someone's character and attitude towards other people, especially when they are kind and generous.
The heart of something is the most central and important part of it.

voca.means_ko: [히이-t]\n열, 열기, 더위, 난방\n~을 뜨겁게 하다, 뜨거워 지다
voca.means_en:
When you heat something, you raise its temperature, for example by using a flame or a special piece of equipment.
Heat is warmth or the quality of being hot.
The heat is very hot weather.
The heat of something is the temperature of something that is warm or that is being heated.
You use heat to refer to a source of heat, for example a cooking ring or the heating system of a house.
You use heat to refer to a state of strong emotion, especially of anger or excitement.
to become warm or hot; to make something warm or hot\n

voca.means_ko:
[히이-v]
(아주 무거운 것을 힘을 주어) 들어올리다/끌어 당기다
(규칙적으로 크게) 들썩 거리다
크게 한숨 등을 내쉬다
(들어)올리다,  (한숨을) 내쉬다, 헐떡이다
voca.means_en:
If you heave something heavy or difficult to move somewhere, you push, pull, or lift it using a lot of effort.
If something heaves, it moves up and down with large regular movements.
If you heave, or if your stomach heaves, you vomit or feel sick.
If you heave a sigh, you give a big sigh.

In some religions, heaven is said to be the place where God lives, where good people go when they die, and where everyone is always happy. It is usually imagined as being high up in the sky.\nYou can use heaven to refer to a place or situation that you like very much.\n
Heavenly things are things that are connected with the religious idea of heaven.\nSomething that is heavenly is very pleasant and enjoyable.\n

voca.means_ko:
[헤비]
무거운, 육중한,  
대량의, 심한, ~으로 가득한
(일이 많아서) 빡빡한, 아주 바쁜, 힘든
voca.means_en:
Something that is heavy weighs a lot.
You use heavy to ask or talk about how much someone or something weighs.
Heavy means great in amount, degree, or intensity.
Someone or something that is heavy is solid in appearance or structure, or is made of a thick material.
A heavy meal is large in amount and often difficult to digest.
Something that is heavy with things is full of them or loaded with them.
boring, tiring, difficult, etc\n
a way of doing something or of treating people that is much stronger and less sensitive than it needs to be\n
People sometimes say 'heck!' when they are slightly irritated or surprised.\n

voca.means_ko: [헤끌]\n(공적인 회의에서 발표자를) 방해하다, 야유를 퍼붓다\n당돌한 질문으로 애먹이다, 괴롭히다
voca.means_en: If people in an audience heckle public speakers or performers, they interrupt them, for example by making rude remarks.\n

voca.means_ko: 매우 흥분한, 법석을 떠는, 정신없이 바쁜, 빡빡한
voca.means_en: A hectic situation is one that is very busy and involves a lot of rushed activity.\n
A hedgehog is a small brown animal with sharp spikes covering its back.\n

voca.means_ko:
[히읠]
발뒤꿈치, (양말, 신발의) 뒤꿈치
굽이 ~한
(구두 등의) 굽을 수선하다, 한쪽으로 기울다
voca.means_en:
Your heel is the back part of your foot, just below your ankle.
The heel of a shoe is the raised part on the bottom at the back.
Heels are women's shoes that are raised very high at the back.
The heel of a sock or stocking is the part that covers your heel.
The heel of your hand is the rounded pad at the bottom of your palm.

The height of a person or thing is their size or length from the bottom to the top.
Height is the quality of being tall.
A particular height is the distance that something is above the ground or above something else mentioned.
A height is a high position or place above the ground.
When an activity, situation, or organization is at its height, it is at its most successful, powerful, or intense.
If you say that something is the height of a particular quality, you are emphasizing that it has that quality to the greatest degree possible.
If something reaches great heights, it becomes very extreme or intense.

In some religions, hell is the place where the Devil lives, and where wicked people are sent to be punished when they die. Hell is usually imagined as being under the ground and full of flames.
If you say that a particular situation or place is hell, you are emphasizing that it is extremely unpleasant.
Hell is used by some people when they are angry or excited, or when they want to emphasize what they are saying.
A helmet is a hat made of a strong material which you wear to protect your head.\n

voca.means_ko:
[헵p]
돕다, 거들다, 
(상황, 일에) 도움이 되다
도움, 지원, 구조
voca.means_en:
If you help someone, you make it easier for them to do something, for example by doing part of the work for them or by giving them advice or money.
If you say that something helps, you mean that it makes something easier to do or get, or that it improves a situation to some extent.
If you help someone go somewhere or move in some way, you give them support so that they can move more easily.
If you help yourself to something, you serve yourself or you take it for yourself. If someone tells you to help yourself, they are telling you politely to serve yourself anything you want or to take anything you want.
If you say that someone or something has been a help or has been some help, you mean that they have helped you to solve a problem.
If you say that someone or something has been a help or has been some help, you mean that they have helped you to solve a problem.\n

If you describe someone as helpful, you mean that they help you in some way, such as doing part of your job for you or by giving you advice or information.
If you describe information or advice as helpful, you mean that it is useful for you.
Something that is helpful makes a situation more pleasant or more easy to tolerate.

voca.means_ko:
[헵뤼s]
무력한, 속수무책인, 
(제 힘으로는) 어찌할 수 없는
난처한, 가여운,
voca.means_en: If you are helpless, you do not have the strength or power to do anything useful or to control or protect yourself.\nThey were helpless.\n

voca.means_ko: [헵뤼슬뤼]\n어찌해 볼 수도 없이, 의지할 데 없이
[헤미s퓌어r]\n(지구, 하늘의) 반구, 반구지도, 반구체, 범위, 영역
voca.means_en:
A hemisphere is one half of the earth.
A hemisphere is one half of the brain.
The jaguar is the beggest predator in the western hemisphere.
A hen is a female chicken. People often keep hens in order to eat them or sell their eggs.\nThe female of any bird can be referred to as a hen.\n

You use hence to indicate that the statement you are about to make is a consequence of what you have just said.\nYou use hence in expressions such as 'several years hence' or 'six months hence' to refer to a time in the future, especially a long time in the future.\n
A herb is a plant whose leaves are used in cooking to add flavour to food, or as a medicine.\n
Herbal means made from or using herbs.\n

voca.means_ko:
[허r-d]
사람의 무리/집단/군중, 다량, 다수
때를 짓다, (식물이) 군생하다
(특정 방향으로) 이동하다/하게 하다
(짐승을) 몰다
voca.means_en:
A herd is a large group of animals of one kind that live together.
If you say that someone has joined the herd or follows the herd, you are criticizing them because you think that they behave just like everyone else and do not think for themselves.
If you herd animals, you make them move along as a group.
If you herd people somewhere, you make them move there in a group.
She pointed to a herd of elk in the distance. / They were herding a small band of horses.
There was a picture of a herd of horses.
Brit equivalent : herdsman a person who cares for or drives herds of cattle or flocks of sheep, esp on an open range\nMustang herders captured them and sold them ot ranchers.\n

You use here when you are referring to the place where you are.
You use here when you are pointing towards a place that is near you, in order to draw someone else's attention to it.
You use here in order to indicate that the person or thing that you are talking about is near you or is being held by you.
If you say that you are here to do something, that is your role or function.
to or in various places\n
You use hereby when officially or formally saying what you are doing.\n
A country's heritage is all the qualities, traditions, or features of life there that have continued over many years and have been passed on from one generation to another.\n
A hermit is a person who lives alone, away from people and society.\n

The hero of a book, play, film, or story is the main male character, who usually has good qualities.
A hero is someone, especially a man, who has done something brave, new, or good, and who is therefore greatly admired by a lot of people.
If you describe someone as your hero, you mean that you admire them a great deal, usually because of a particular quality or skill that they have.

voca.means_ko: [헤뤄윈]\n영웅적인 여자, 여걸\n(소설, 영화 등의) 여자 주인공
voca.means_en:
The heroine of a book, play, film, or story is the main female character, who usually has good qualities.
A heroine is a woman who has done something brave, new, or good, and who is therefore greatly admired by a lot of people.
If you describe a woman as your heroine, you mean that you admire her greatly, usually because of a particular quality or skill that she has.
A herring is a long silver-coloured fish. Herring live in large groups in the sea.\n

If you hesitate, you do not speak or act for a short time, usually because you are uncertain, embarrassed, or worried about what you are going to say or do.
If you hesitate to do something, you delay doing it or are unwilling to do it, usually because you are not certain it would be right. If you do not hesitate to do something, you do it immediately.
You can use hesitate in expressions such as `don't hesitate to call me' or `don't hesitate to contact us' when you are telling someone that they should do something as soon as it needs to be done and should not worry about disturbing other people.

voca.means_ko: [헥s]\n(남을 해하기 위해) 마법을 걸다, \n~에 마술을 걸다, ~을 매혹하다
voca.means_en: short for hexadecimal\n

hide - hid - hidden
hide / conceal / cover / disguise / mask / camouflage
If you hide something or someone, you put them in a place where they cannot easily be seen or found.
If you hide or if you hide yourself, you go somewhere where you cannot easily be seen or found.
If you hide your face, you press your face against something or cover your face with something, so that people cannot see it.
A hide is a place which is built to look like its surroundings. Hides are used by people who want to watch or photograph animals and birds without being seen by them.
"Ahhh!" Jack and Annie hid their heads.
to go to a secret place to escape from somebody who is trying to find you\n
A hierarchical system or organization is one in which people have different ranks or positions, depending on how important they are.\n

voca.means_ko: 계급제도, 계층제, 계층\n(사상, 개념 등의) 체계
voca.means_en:
A hierarchy is a system of organizing people into different ranks or levels of importance, for example in society or in a company.
The hierarchy of an organization such as the Church is the group of people who manage and control it.
A hierarchy of ideas and beliefs involves organizing them into a system or structure.
funny / amusing / entertaining / witty / humorous / comic / hilarious\nIf something is hilarious, it is extremely funny and makes you laugh a lot.\n
A hill is an area of land that is higher than the land that surrounds it.\n
A hillside is the sloping side of a hill.\n
An animal's hind legs are at the back of its body.\n

rent / hire / let
If you hire someone, you employ them or pay them to do a particular job for you.
If you hire something, you pay money to the owner so that you can use it for a period of time.
You use hire to refer to the activity or business of hiring something.
to take a particular job or position; to give somebody a job\n
to allow somebody to use something for a short period of time in return for payment\n

voca.means_ko:
[히s]
쉬익/쉿 하는 소리를 내다
(화난 어조로) 낮게 말하다, 쉿 하고 말하다
쉬/쉿 하는 소리, 쉭쉭거리는 야유
voca.means_en:
To hiss means to make a sound like a long 's'.
If you hiss something, you say it forcefully in a whisper.
If people hiss at someone such as a performer or a person making a speech, they express their disapproval or dislike of that person by making long loud `s' sounds.

voca.means_ko:
[힛t]
(손이나 손에 들고있는 물건으로) 치다, 때리다, 
가하다, ~을 맞히다, 타격을 주다, 공격하다,

타격, 충격, 비난의 말, 풍자, 대성공
(목표물에) 맞음, 명중,
voca.means_en:
hit / knock / bang / strike / bump / bash
If you hit someone or something, you deliberately touch them with a lot of force, with your hand or an object held in your hand.
When one thing hits another, it touches it with a lot of force.
If a bomb or missile hits its target, it reaches it.
If something hits a person, place, or thing, it affects them very badly.
When a feeling or an idea hits you, it suddenly affects you or comes into your mind.
For the first time, it really hit Jack.
to criticize or attack somebody who has criticized or attacked you\n
sed to tell somebody to start doing something, such as playing music\n
to talk to somebody in a way that shows you are sexually attracted to them\n
to talk to somebody in a way that shows you are sexually attracted to them\n

You're starting to fall behind. You really need to hit the books!
I'm going to head to the library and hit the books.
We've got finals coming up. I really need to hit the books.
Don't you think you've been hitting the bottle a little too hard lately?\nHe's been hitting the bottle really hard lately.\n
Look at these love handles! I'd better hit the gym.\n
I'm going to hit the hay.\n
I think we'd better hit the road. We've got a long way to go.\n
if something hits the spot it does exactly what it should do\n

voca.means_ko:
[힛치]
(지나가는 차를) 얻어타다, 편승하다
(옷을) 끌어 올리다, 잡아당기다

(어떤 종류의) 매듭
voca.means_en:
A hitch is a slight problem or difficulty which causes a short delay.
If you hitch, hitch a lift, or hitch a ride, you hitchhike.
If you hitch something to something else, you hook it or fasten it there.
If you get hitched, you get married.
to pull up a piece of your clothing\n
If your voice is hoarse or if you are hoarse, your voice sounds rough and unclear, for example because your throat is sore.\n

voca.means_ko:
[하블]
다리를 절다, 절뚝 거리다
(말 등의 짐슴이 달리지 못하도록) 두 다리를 묶다
방해하다
voca.means_en:
If you hobble, you walk in an awkward way with small steps, for example because your foot is injured.
To hobble something or someone means to make it more difficult for them to be successful or to achieve what they want.
Jack threw his sneakers into his backpack and hobbled after Annie.

A hoe is a gardening tool with a long handle and a small square blade, which you use to remove small weeds and break up the surface of the soil.\nIf you hoe a field or crop, you use a hoe on the weeds or soil there.\n

voca.means_ko: (높이) 들어 올리다, 끌어 올리다\n들어 올리기, 끌어 올리기, 승강 장치
voca.means_en: If you hoist something heavy somewhere, you lift it or pull it up there.\nA hoist is a machine for lifting heavy things.\n

voca.means_ko:
[호을d]
(보통 신체의 아픈 부위를) 잡다, 쥐다, 
견디다, 지탱하다, (계속) 버티다
지속/계속 되다, 가다
소유하다, 보유하다
열다, 잡아주다, 유지하다
쥐기, 잡기, 잡는곳, 손잡이, 예약, 지연
voca.means_en:
hold - held - held
hold / hold on / cling / clutch / grip / grasp / clasp / hang on
When you hold something, you carry or support it, using your hands or your arms.
When you hold someone, you put your arms round them, usually because you want to show them how much you like them or because you want to comfort them.
If you hold someone in a particular position, you use force to keep them in that position and stop them from moving.
When you hold a part of your body, you put your hand on or against it, often because it hurts.
be or remain true, valid, correct, etc\n
He held it out to Annie.\n

voca.means_ko: (쓰러지지 않도록) ~을 떠받치다\n(~의 흐름/진행을) 지연시키다, 방해하다\n(하나의 예로서) ~을 들다/제시하다
voca.means_en:
to raise somebody/something in the air
to support somebody/something and prevent it/them from falling
to block or delay the progress of somebody/something
have power, control or great influence over somebody/something\n

voca.means_ko: 멈춰 서다. 정지하다, 견디다, 지속하다, 들어올리다, 뭠춰세워 강탈하다
voca.means_en:
to remain healthy, in good condition or working effectively, especially when there are difficulties
if an idea, an argument, etc. holds up, it remains strong when you analyse it carefully
She held up Morgan's note.

stop breathing for a short time, for example because you are afraid of something or very anxious about something
be anxious while you are waiting for something that you are worried about
used for telling somebody that it's not worth waiting for something

voca.means_en: The bone was hollow.\nAnnie drove the moon buggy over bumps and hollows.\n
Near the fire were knives, axes, and hollowed-out stones.\n

voca.means_en: If you describe something as holy, you mean that it is considered to be special because it is connected with God or a particular religion.\nA holy person is a religious leader or someone who leads a religious life.\n
Honey is a sweet, sticky, yellowish substance that is made by bees.\nYou call someone honey as a sign of affection.\n

voca.means_ko: [후d]\n(외투등에 달린) 모자, \n두건, 머리 덮개, 자동차의 보닛
voca.means_en:
A hood is a part of a coat which you can pull up to cover your head. It is in the shape of a triangular bag attached to the neck of the coat at the back.
The hood of a car is the metal cover over the engine at the front.
A cooker hood is an electrical device fitted over a cooker above head height, and containing an extractor fan and usually a light.
It had a hood and long sleeves.
The hooves of an animal such as a horse are the hard lower parts of its feet.\n
go somewhere on foot; walk somewhere\n

voca.means_en:
A hook is a bent piece of metal or plastic that is used for catching or holding things, or for hanging things up.
If you hook one thing to another, you attach it there using a hook. If something hooks somewhere, it can be hooked there.
Somehow you hooked right into my magic.
He's not hooked up to our radio.\n

voca.means_ko:
[후웃-t]
폭소를 터뜨리다, 콧방귀를 끼다, 비웃다
(부엉이가) 부엉부엉 울다

voca.means_en:
If you hoot the horn on a vehicle or if it hoots, it makes a loud noise on one note.
If you hoot, you make a loud high-pitched noise when you are laughing or showing disapproval.
When an owl hoots, it makes a sound like a long `oo'.
If you say that you don't give a hoot or don't care two hoots about something, you are emphasizing that you do not care at all about it.
An owl hooted.

If you describe a crowd of people as a horde, you mean that the crowd is very large and excited and, often, rather frightening or unpleasant.\nIt showed hordes of zebras, tall giraffes, big animals with horns, and tiny, deerlike creatures.\n

On a vehicle such as a car, the horn is the device that makes a loud noise as a signal or warning.
The horns of an animal such as a cow or deer are the hard pointed things that grow from its head.
Horn is the hard substance that the horns of animals are made of. Horn is sometimes used to make objects such as spoons, buttons, or ornaments.
A horn is a musical instrument of the brass family. It is a long circular metal tube, wide at one end, which you play by blowing.
A horn is a simple musical instrument consisting of a metal tube that is wide at one end and narrow at the other. You play it by blowing into it.
to rudely interrupt somebody when they are speaking\nto interfere in a situation that does not concern you\n

terrible / awful / horrible / dreadful / vile / foul
If you describe something or someone as horrible, you do not like them at all.
You can call something horrible when it causes you to feel great shock, fear, and disgust.
Horrible is used to emphasize how bad something is.
Cap'n Bones threw back his head and laughed horrible.
shock / appal / horrify / disgust / sicken / repel / revolt\nIf someone is horrified, they feel shocked or disgusted, usually because of something that they have seen or heard.\n

voca.means_ko: [호-r]\n공포, 공포감, 경악\n~에 대한 공포, 참혹한 경험
voca.means_en:
Horror is a feeling of great shock, fear, and worry caused by something extremely unpleasant.
If you have a horror of something, you are afraid of it or dislike it very much.
The horror of something, especially something that hurts people, is its very great unpleasantness.
You can refer to extremely unpleasant or frightening experiences as horrors.
A horror film or story is intended to be very frightening.
You can refer to an account of a very unpleasant experience or event as a horror story.

prisoner / hostage / captive / detainee / prisoner of war
A hostage is someone who has been captured by a person or organization and who may be killed or injured if people do not do what that person or organization demands.
If you say you are hostage to something, you mean that your freedom to take action is restricted by things that you cannot control.

A house is a building in which people live, usually the people belonging to one family.
You can refer to all the people who live together in a house as the house.
House is used in the names of types of places where people go to eat and drink.
House is used in the names of types of companies, especially ones which publish books, lend money, or design clothes.
House is sometimes used in the names of office buildings and large private homes or expensive houses.
You can refer to the two main bodies of Britain's parliament and the United States of America's legislature as the House or a House.

A household is all the people in a family or group who live together in a house.
The household is your home and everything that is connected with looking after it.
Someone or something that is a household name or word is very well known.

voca.means_ko:
[하을]
(길게) 울다, 울부짖다, 
울부짖다, 법석을 떨다, 윙윙거리다
(개, 늑대 등의) 길게 짖는 소리
voca.means_en:
If an animal such as a wolf or a dog howls, it makes a long, loud, crying sound.
If a person howls, they make a long, loud cry expressing pain, anger, or unhappiness.
When the wind howls, it blows hard and makes a loud noise.
If you howl something, you say it in a very loud voice.
If you howl with laughter, you laugh very loudly.

voca.means_ko:
[하들]
(보통 춥거나 무서워서) 옹송그리며 모이다, 
떼지어 모이다, 모이다, 몸을 움추리다
모인 무리, 뒤죽박죽, 혼란, 혼잡
옹기종기 모이는 것, 작전회의
voca.means_en:
If you huddle somewhere, you sit, stand, or lie there holding your arms and legs close to your body, usually because you are cold or frightened.
If people huddle together or huddle round something, they stand, sit, or lie close to each other, usually because they all feel cold or frightened.
If people huddle in a group, they gather together to discuss something quietly or secretly.
A huddle is a small group of people or things that are standing very close together or lying on top of each other, usually in a disorganized way.
Jake and Annie huddled in a corner.

If you huff, you indicate that you are annoyed or offended about something, usually by the way that you say something.\nIf someone is in a huff, they are behaving in a bad-tempered way because they are annoyed and offended.\n
breathe heavily while making a great physical effort\nmake it obvious that you are annoyed about something without doing anything to change the situation\n

voca.means_ko:
[하g]
(사람을) 껴안다, 포옹하다
(무엇을) 끌어안다, (사람몸에) 딱 들러붙다
껴안기, 포옹
voca.means_en:
When you hug someone, you put your arms around them and hold them tightly, for example because you like them or are pleased to see them. You can also say that two people hug each other or that they hug.
If you hug something, you hold it close to your body with your arms tightly round it.
Something that hugs the ground or a stretch of land or water stays very close to it.

Something or someone that is huge is extremely large in size.
Something that is huge is extremely large in amount or degree.
Something that is huge exists or happens on a very large scale, and involves a lot of different people or things.

If something hums, it makes a low continuous noise.
When you hum a tune, you sing it with your lips closed.
If you say that a place hums, you mean that it is full of activity.
Hum is sometimes used to represent the sound people make when they are not sure what to say.

voca.means_ko:
[험붤]
겸손한, 
(예의상 자기를 낮추는 자리에서) 변변치 않은, 초라한
겸허하게/겸손하게 만들다
voca.means_en:
A humble person is not proud and does not believe that they are better than other people.
People with low social status are sometimes described as humble.
A humble place or thing is ordinary and not special in any way.
People use humble in a phrase such as in my humble opinion as a polite way of emphasizing what they think, even though they do not feel humble about it.
If you eat humble pie, you speak or behave in a way which tells people that you admit you were wrong about something.
A hummingbird is a small brightly coloured bird found in America, especially Central and South America. It has a long thin beak and powerful narrow wings that can move very fast.\n

A hump is a small hill or raised area.
A hump is a large lump on a person's back, usually caused by illness or old age.
If you hump something heavy, you carry it from one place to another with great difficulty.

voca.means_ko: ~을 밀다, 일어버리다, 예감이 들다\n(등을) 구부리다\n혹, 융기, 덩어리, 예감, 육감, 직감
voca.means_en:
If you have a hunch about something, you are sure that it is correct or true, even though you do not have any proof.
If you hunch forward, you raise your shoulders, put your head down, and lean forwards, often because you are cold, ill, or unhappy.
If you hunch your shoulders, you raise them and lean forwards slightly.

If you hunt for something or someone, you try to find them by searching carefully or thoroughly.
If you hunt a criminal or an enemy, you search for them in order to catch or harm them.
When people or animals hunt, they chase and kill wild animals for food or as a sport.
In Britain, when people hunt, they ride horses over fields with dogs called hounds and try to catch and kill foxes, as a sport.
In Britain, a hunt is a group of people who meet regularly to hunt foxes.
to search for somebody/something, especially somebody/something that is hidden or difficult to find\n

throw / toss / hurl / fling / chuck / lob / bowl / pitch
If you hurl something, you throw it violently and with a lot of force.
If you hurl abuse or insults at someone, you shout insults at them aggressively.
"They'll think we're some enemy and hurl their spears."
"Maybe she hurls it."

throw / toss / hurl / fling / chuck / lob / bowl / pitch
If you hurl something, you throw it violently and with a lot of force.
If you hurl abuse or insults at someone, you shout insults at them aggressively.
He hurled it at the canoe.
to continue speaking, without allowing anyone to interrupt or speak\n
to encourage somebody to move or work faster; to do something to make something happen faster\nused to tell somebody to move or do something more quickly\n

voca.means_ko:

다치게 하다, 고통을 느끼다, 아프다
마음이 아프다, 감정이 상하다, 피해를 보다
부상, 상처
다친, 부상한
voca.means_en:
hurt - hurt - hurt
damage / hurt / harm / impair / prejudice
If you hurt yourself or hurt a part of your body, you feel pain because you have injured yourself.
If a part of your body hurts, you feel pain there.
If someone hurts you, they say or do something that makes you unhappy.
If you say that you are hurting, you mean that you are experiencing emotional pain.
To hurt someone or something means to have a bad effect on them or prevent them from succeeding.
If you are hurt, you have been injured.
If you are hurt, you are upset because of something that someone has said or done.

You say `Hush!' to someone when you are asking or telling them to be quiet.
If you hush someone or if they hush, they stop speaking or making a noise.
You say there is a hush in a place when everything is quiet and peaceful, or suddenly becomes quiet.
to hide information about a situation, especially something bad or shocking, because you do not want people to know about it\n

A hut is a small house with only one or two rooms, especially one which is made of wood, mud, grass, or stones.\nA hut is a small wooden building in someone's garden, or a temporary building used by builders or repair workers.\n
A hyena is an animal that looks rather like a dog and makes a sound which is similar to a human laugh. Hyenas live in Africa and Asia.\n
A hygienist or a dental hygienist is a person who is trained to clean people's teeth and to give them advice on how to look after their teeth and gums.\n
A hymn is a religious song that Christians sing in church.\nIf you describe a film, book, or speech as a hymn to something, you mean that it praises or celebrates that thing.\n
An iceberg is a large tall mass of ice floating in the sea.\n

voca.means_ko:

voca.means_en:
purpose / aim / intention / plan / point / idea
An idea is a plan, suggestion, or possible course of action.
An idea is an opinion or belief about what something is like or should be like.
If someone gives you an idea of something, they give you information about it without being very exact or giving a lot of detail.
If you have an idea of something, you know about it to some extent.
If you have an idea that something is the case, you think that it may be the case, although you are not certain.
The idea of an action or activity is its aim or purpose.
If you have the idea of doing something, you intend to do it.

An ideal is a principle, idea, or standard that seems very good and worth trying to achieve.
Your ideal of something is the person or thing that seems to you to be the best possible example of it.
The ideal person or thing for a particular task or purpose is the best possible person or thing for it.
An ideal society or world is the best possible one that you can imagine.

If you say that ideally a particular thing should happen or be done, you mean that this is what you would like to happen or be done, but you know that this is may not be possible or practical.
If you say that someone or something is ideally suited, ideally located, or ideally qualified, you mean that they are as well suited, located, or qualified as they could possibly be.
Things that are identical are exactly the same.\n

voca.means_ko:
[아이덴티퓌케이션]
신원 확인, 신분 증명, 신분증

(심리적) 동일시, 공감
voca.means_en:
The identification of something is the recognition that it exists, is important, or is true.
Your identification of a particular person or thing is your ability to name them because you know them or recognize them.
If someone asks you for some identification, they want to see something such as a driving licence, which proves who you are.
The identification of one person or thing with another is the close association of one with the other.
Identification with someone or something is the feeling of sympathy and support for them.

identify / recognize / make out / discern / pick out / distinguish
If you can identify someone or something, you are able to recognize them or distinguish them from others.
If you identify someone or something, you name them or say who or what they are.
If you identify something, you discover or notice its existence.
If a particular thing identifies someone or something, it makes them easy to recognize, by making them different in some way.
If you identify with someone or something, you feel that you understand them or their feelings and ideas.
If you identify one person or thing with another, you think that they are closely associated or involved in some way.

voca.means_ko: (자기) 신분을 증명하다, \n(자기가 ~라고) 말하다, 밝히다\n(정당, 정책 등과) 행동을 같이 하다, 제휴하다

voca.means_en: to consider somebody to be something or to be closely connected with somebody/something\nto consider something to be the same as something else\n
to feel that you can understand and share the feelings of somebody else\n
Your identity is who you are.\nThe identity of a person or place is the characteristics they have that distinguish them from others.\n

게으른, 나태한, 일하지 않는, 가동되지 않는, 놀고 있는

voca.means_en:
If people who were working are idle, they have no jobs or work.
If machines or factories are idle, they are not working or being used.
If you say that someone is idle, you disapprove of them because they are not doing anything and you think they should be.
Idle is used to describe something that you do for no particular reason, often because you have nothing better to do.
You refer to an idle threat or boast when you do not think the person making it will or can do what they say.
To idle a factory or other place of work means to close it down because there is no work to do or because the workers are on strike.
Ignorance of something is lack of knowledge about it.\n

If you ignore someone or something, you pay no attention to them.\nIf you say that an argument or theory ignores an important aspect of a situation, you are criticizing it because it fails to consider that aspect or to take it into account.\n

voca.means_ko: 죄악, 병, 고생, 불운\n병든, 나쁜, 바람직하지 않은\n나쁘게, 불충분하게

voca.means_en: An illusion is a false idea or belief.\nAn illusion is something that appears to exist or be a particular thing but does not actually exist or is in reality something else.\n

You can refer to the descriptions in something such as a poem or song, and the pictures they create in your mind, as its imagery.\nYou can refer to pictures and representations of things as imagery, especially when they act as symbols.\n

voca.means_ko: (강한 감정, 의견, 가치를) 가득 채우다\n듬뿍 스며들게 하다
voca.means_en: If someone or something is imbued with an idea, feeling, or quality, they become filled with it.\n

voca.means_ko: (특히 값 비싼 것의) 모조품\n모방, (특히 재미삼에 누구를) 흉내내기
voca.means_en:
artificial / synthetic / false / man-made / fake / imitation
An imitation of something is a copy of it.
Imitation means copying someone else's actions.
If someone does an imitation of another person, they copy the way they speak or behave, sometimes in order to be funny.
Imitation things are not genuine but are made to look as if they are.

voca.means_ko:
즉각적인, 당면한, 목전의
(시간적, 공간적으로) 아주 가까이에 있는
(관계, 계급이) 가장 가까운, 직속/직계의

voca.means_en:
An immediate result, action, or reaction happens or is done without any delay.
Immediate needs and concerns exist at the present time and must be dealt with quickly.
The immediate person or thing comes just before or just after another person or thing in a sequence.
You use immediate to describe an area or position that is next to or very near a particular place or person.
If you describe someone or their behaviour as immoral, you believe that their behaviour is morally wrong.\n

voca.means_ko: [임모r덜]\n죽지 않는, 불후의, 불멸의, \n불멸의 존재, 영생하는 존재
voca.means_en:
Someone or something that is immortal is famous and likely to be remembered for a long time.
Someone or something that is immortal will live or last for ever and never die or be destroyed.
If you refer to someone's immortal words, you mean that what they said is well-known, and you are usually about to quote it.

voca.means_ko:
[이뮤-운]
(특정 질병에) 면역성이 있는
~의 영향을 받지 않는, ~에 면역이 된
~이 면제되는, ~을 면하는
voca.means_en:
If you are immune to a particular disease, you cannot be affected by it.
If you are immune to something that happens or is done, you are not affected by it.
Someone or something that is immune from a particular process or situation is able to escape it.
immune from punishment\n

voca.means_ko: [이뮤나이z]\n(특히 백신 주사로) 면역력을 갖게 하다, \n면역성을 주다, ~을 무력/무효로 하다
voca.means_en: If people or animals are immunized, they are made immune to a particular disease, often by being given an injection.\n
Something that is immutable will never change or cannot be changed.\n

voca.means_ko: [임펙t]\n(강력한) 영향, 충격, 효과, \n~을 충돌시키다, ~에 영향을 주다
voca.means_en:
The impact that something has on a situation, process, or person is a sudden and powerful effect that it has on them.
An impact is the action of one object hitting another, or the force with which one object hits another.
To impact on a situation, process, or person means to affect them.
If one object impacts on another, it hits it with great force.
If you impart information to people, you tell it to them.\nTo impart a particular quality to something means to give it that quality.\n
Something that is an impediment to a person or thing makes their movement, development, or progress difficult.\nSomeone who has a speech impediment has a disability which makes speaking difficult.\n

Imperial is used to refer to things or people that are or were connected with an empire.\nThe imperial system of measurement uses inches, feet, and yards to measure length, ounces and pounds to measure weight, and pints and gallons to measure volume.\n
If you implement something such as a plan, you ensure that what has been planned is done.\nAn implement is a tool or other piece of equipment.\n

voca.means_ko: 영향, 결과, 함축, 암시, 연루, 밀접한 관계, 연루
voca.means_en: The implications of something are the things that are likely to happen as a result.\nThe implication of a statement, event, or situation is what it implies or suggests is the case.\n

voca.means_ko:
[임플뤼씻t]
암시된, 내포된, 
(직접 표현되지 않더라도) 내포/포함되는
절대적인, 무조건 적인
voca.means_en:
Something that is implicit is expressed in an indirect way.
If a quality or element is implicit in something, it is involved in it or is shown by it.
If you say that someone has an implicit belief or faith in something, you mean that they have complete faith in it and no doubts at all.

voca.means_ko: [임포r-t]\n수입하다, 들여오다, 중요하다\n수입, 수입품, 의미, 취지, 중요
voca.means_en:
To import products or raw materials means to buy them from another country for use in your own country.
If you import files or information into one type of software from another type, you open them in a format that can be used in the new software.
Imports are products or raw materials bought from another country for use in your own country.
The import of something is its importance.
The import of something is its meaning, especially when the meaning is not clearly expressed.
The importance of something is its quality of being significant, valued, or necessary in a particular situation.\nImportance means having influence, power, or status.\n
Something that is important is very significant, is highly valued, or is necessary.\nSomeone who is important has influence or power within a society or a particular group.\n

voca.means_ko:
[임포우z]
(새로운 법률, 세금 등을) 도입/시행하다, 
(힘들거나 불쾌한 것을) 부과하다, 강요/적용하다, 
폐를 끼치다, 
(자기 존재나 생각을) 내세우다
voca.means_en:
If you impose something on people, you use your authority to force them to accept it.
If you impose your opinions or beliefs on other people, you try and make people accept them as a rule or as a model to copy.
If something imposes strain, pressure, or suffering on someone, it causes them to experience it.
If someone imposes on you, they unreasonably expect you to do something for them which you do not want to do.
If someone imposes themselves on you, they force you to accept their company although you may not want to.

voca.means_ko: 주제넘게 나서다\n~을 틈타다, 이용하다, 속이다\n~을 위압하다
voca.means_en: to expect somebody to do something for you or spend time with you when they do not have much time, or when it may not be convenient for them\n

Something that is impossible cannot be done or cannot happen.
An impossible situation or an impossible position is one that is very difficult to deal with.
If you describe someone as impossible, you are annoyed that their bad behaviour or strong views make them difficult to deal with.

to link a group of qualities, items, etc. with their source, cause, position on a scale, etc.\n
to plan or arrange something in detail\n

voca.means_en:
When soldiers march somewhere, or when a commanding officer marches them somewhere, they walk there with very regular steps, as a group.
When a large group of people march for a cause, they walk somewhere together in order to express their ideas or to protest about something.
If you say that someone marches somewhere, you mean that they walk there quickly and in a determined way, for example because they are angry.
If you march someone somewhere, you force them to walk there with you, for example by holding their arm tightly.
The march of something is its steady development or progress.
A march is a piece of music with a regular rhythm that you can march to.

A margin is the difference between two amounts, especially the difference in the number of votes or points between the winner and the loser in an election or other contest.
The margin of a written or printed page is the empty space at the side of the page.
If there is a margin for something in a situation, there is some freedom to choose what to do or decide how to do it.
The margin of a place or area is the extreme edge of it.
Marijuana is a drug which is made from the dried leaves and flowers of the hemp plant, and which can be smoked.\n

A mark is a written or printed symbol, for example a letter of the alphabet.
A mark is a point that is given for a correct answer or for doing something well in an exam or competition. A mark can also be a written symbol such as a letter that indicates how good a student's or competitor's work or performance is.
If something marks a surface, or if the surface marks, the surface is damaged by marks or a mark.
If you mark something with a particular word or symbol, you write that word or symbol on it.

voca.means_en:
A market is a place where goods are bought and sold, usually outdoors.
The market for a particular type of thing is the number of people who want to buy it, or the area of the world in which it is sold.
The market refers to the total amount of a product that is sold each year, especially when you are talking about the competition between the companies who sell that product.
The job market or the labour market refers to the people who are looking for work and the jobs available for them to do.
To market a product means to organize its sale, by deciding on its price, where it should be sold, and how it should be advertised.
If you talk about a market economy, or the market price of something, you are referring to an economic system in which the prices of things depend on how many are available and how many people want to buy them, rather than prices being fixed by governments.

voca.means_en: Markings are coloured lines, shapes, or patterns on the surface of something, which help to identify it.\n

A marriage is the relationship between a husband and wife.
A marriage is the act of marrying someone, or the ceremony at which this is done.
Marriage is the state of being married.

When two people get married or marry, they legally become husband and wife in a special ceremony. Get married is less formal and more commonly used than marry.\nWhen a priest or official marries two people, he or she conducts the ceremony in which the two people legally become husband and wife.\n

voca.means_en: A marsupial is an animal such as a kangaroo or an opossum. Female marsupials carry their babies in a pouch on their stomach.\n
An opossum is a small animal that lives in America. It carries its young in a pouch on its body, and has thick fur and a long tail.\n

If you marvel at something, you express your great surprise, wonder, or admiration.
You can describe something or someone as a marvel to indicate that you think that they are wonderful.
Marvels are things that people have done, or that have happened, which are very unexpected or surprising.
to be very surprised or impressed by somebody/something\n

A mass of things is a large number of them grouped together.
A mass of something is a large amount of it.
Masses of something means a great deal of it.
Mass is used to describe something which involves or affects a very large number of people.
When people or things mass, or when you mass them, they gather together into a large crowd or group.

voca.means_en: Something that is massive is very large in size, quantity, or extent.\nIf you describe a medical condition as massive, you mean that it is extremely serious.\n

A servant's master is the man that he or she works for.
A dog's master is the man or boy who owns it.
If you say that someone is a master of a particular activity, you mean that they are extremely skilled at it.
If you master something, you learn how to do it properly or you succeed in understanding it completely.

A match is an organized game of football, tennis, cricket, or some other sport.
A match is a small wooden stick with a substance on one end that produces a flame when you rub it along the rough side of a matchbox.
If a combination of things or people is a good match, they have a pleasing effect when placed or used together.
If something of a particular colour or design matches another thing, they have the same colour or design, or have a pleasing appearance when they are used together.
If something such as an amount or a quality matches with another amount or quality, they are both the same or equal. If you match two things, you make them the same or equal.
to find things or people that are suitable for each other or fit well with each other\n
(with something) to be the same or similar\n

material / fabric / cloth / textile
A material is a solid substance.
Material is cloth.
Materials are the things that you need for a particular activity.
Ideas or information that are used as a basis for a book, play, or film can be referred to as material.
If you say that someone is a particular kind of material, you mean that they have the qualities or abilities to do a particular job or task.
Material things are related to possessions or money, rather than to more abstract things such as ideas or values.
Maternity is used to describe things relating to the help and medical care given to a woman when she is pregnant and when she gives birth.\n
Mathematics is the study of numbers, quantities, or shapes.\nThe mathematics of a problem is the calculations that are involved in it.\n
