You use matters to refer to the situation you are talking about, especially when something is affecting the situation in some way.
If you say that a situation is a matter of a particular thing, you mean that that is the most important thing to be done or considered when you are involved in the situation or explaining it.
Printed matter consists of books, newspapers, and other texts that are printed. Reading matter consists of things that are suitable for reading, such as books and newspapers.
If you say that something does not matter, you mean that it is not important to you because it does not have an effect on you or on a particular situation.

When something matures, it reaches a state of complete development.
If someone matures, they become more fully developed in their personality and emotional behaviour.
If something such as wine or cheese matures or is matured, it is left for a time to allow its full flavour or strength to develop.
If you describe someone as mature, you think that they are fully developed and balanced in their personality and emotional behaviour.

You use maybe to express uncertainty, for example when you do not know that something is definitely true, or when you are mentioning something that may possibly happen in the future in the way you describe.

You use maybe to indicate that, although a comment is partly true, there is also another point of view that should be considered.
You can say maybe as a response to a question or remark, when you do not want to agree or disagree.
You use maybe when you are making a rough guess at a number, quantity, or value, rather than stating it exactly.

voca.means_en:
mean - meant - meant
If you want to know what a word, code, signal, or gesture means, you want to know what it refers to or what its message is.
If you ask someone what they mean, you are asking them to explain exactly what or who they are referring to or what they are intending to say.
If something means something to you, it is important to you in some way.
If you describe someone as mean, you are being critical of them because they are unwilling to spend much money or to use very much of a particular thing.
If you describe an amount as mean, you are saying that it is very small.

The meaning of what someone says or of something such as a book or film is the thoughts or ideas that are intended to be expressed by it.
If an activity or action has meaning, it has a purpose and is worthwhile.

voca.means_en: In the meantime or meantime means in the period of time between two events.\n

If you measure the quality, value, or effect of something, you discover or judge how great it is.

If something measures a particular length, width, or amount, that is its size or intensity, expressed in numbers.

voca.means_en: A medallion is a round metal disc which some people wear as an ornament, especially on a chain round their neck.\n
Medical means relating to illness and injuries and to their treatment or prevention.\nA medical is a thorough examination of your body by a doctor, for example before you start a new job.\n

The Mediterranean is the sea between southern Europe and North Africa.
The Mediterranean refers to the southern part of Europe, which is next to the Mediterranean Sea.
Something that is Mediterranean is characteristic of or belongs to the people or region around the Mediterranean Sea.
Toyota announced that it would “ramp up” production in China to meet expected increases in market demand.\n

When a solid substance melts or when you melt it, it changes to a liquid, usually because it has been heated.

If a person or thing melts into something such as darkness or a crowd of people, they become difficult to see, for example because they are moving away from you or are the same colour as the background.
to disappear gradually; to make something disappear gradually\n
to gradually become part of something and difficult to see\n

A member of a group is one of the people, animals, or things belonging to that group.
A member of an organization such as a club or a political party is a person who has officially joined the organization.
A member or Member is a person who has been elected to a parliament or legislature.
A member country or member state is one of the countries that has joined an international organization or group.
"These must be their clothes. Maybe they're being mended".\n

Mental means relating to the process of thinking.
Mental means relating to the state or the health of a person's mind.
A mental act is one that involves only thinking and not physical action.
If you say that someone is mental, you mean that you think they are mad.
If you make a mental note of something, you make an effort to store it in your memory so that you will not forget it.

They will show you no mercy.

You use mere to emphasize how unimportant or inadequate something is, in comparison to the general situation you are describing.
You use mere to indicate that a quality or action that is usually unimportant has a very important or strong effect.
You use mere to emphasize how small a particular amount or number is.

You use merely to emphasize that something is only what you say and not better, more important, or more exciting.
You use merely to emphasize that a particular amount or quantity is very small.
You use not merely before the less important of two contrasting statements, as a way of emphasizing the more important statement.

If one thing merges with another, or is merged with another, they combine or come together to make one whole thing. You can also say that two things merge, or are merged.\nIf one sound, colour, or object merges into another, the first changes so gradually into the second that you do not notice the change.\n

If one thing is a metaphor for another, it is intended or regarded as a symbol of it.
If you mix your metaphors, you use two conflicting metaphors. People do this accidentally, or sometimes deliberately as a joke.
These rocks are called meteorites.\n

an archaic word for middle\nMid- is used to form nouns or adjectives that refer to the middle part of a particular period of time, or the middle point of a particular place.\n
some point above ground level, in the air\n

If people migrate, they move from one place to another, especially in order to find work or to live somewhere for a short time.
When birds, fish, or animals migrate, they move at a particular season from one part of the world or from one part of a country to another, usually in order to breed or to find new feeding grounds.
Users are migrating to martphones.
Every year, in late spring, thousands of zebras and gazelles and millions of wildebeests (will-duh-beests) migrate from the dry plains of Tanzania to Kenya.\n

Mild is used to describe something such as a feeling, attitude, or illness that is not very strong or severe.
A mild person is gentle and does not get angry easily.
Mild weather is pleasant because it is neither extremely hot nor extremely cold.
You describe food as mild when it does not taste or smell strong, sharp, or bitter, especially when you like it because of this.

voca.means_ko: 무언극\n무언극을 하다, (말은 하지 않고) 몸짓으로 표현하다
voca.means_en:
Mime is the use of movements and gestures in order to express something or tell a story without using speech.
If you mime something, you describe or express it using mime rather than speech.
If you mime, you pretend to be singing or playing an instrument, although the music is in fact coming from a CD or cassette.

voca.means_en:
Mine is the first person singular possessive pronoun. A speaker or writer uses mine to refer to something that belongs or relates to himself or herself.
A mine is a place where deep holes and tunnels are dug under the ground in order to obtain a mineral such as coal, diamonds, or gold.
A mine is a bomb which is hidden in the ground or in water and which explodes when people or things touch it.
When a mineral such as coal, diamonds, or gold is mined, it is obtained from the ground by digging deep holes and tunnels.
If an area of land or water is mined, mines are placed there which will explode when people or things touch them.
Something that is minimal is very small in quantity, value, or degree.\n

In Britain and some other countries, a minister is a person who is in charge of a particular government department.
A minister is a person who officially represents their government in a foreign country and has a lower rank than an ambassador.
A minister is a member of the clergy, especially in Protestant churches.
If you minister to people or to their needs, you serve them or help them, for example by making sure that they have everything they need or want.

If you say that a good event is a miracle, you mean that it is very surprising and unexpected.
A miracle is a wonderful and surprising event that is believed to be caused by God.
A miracle drug or product does something that was thought almost impossible.

voca.means_ko: 버릇없는 짓을 하다, 비행을 저지르다\n부정을 저지르다
voca.means_en: If someone, especially a child, misbehaves, they behave in a way that is not acceptable to other people.\n

voca.means_ko: 갖가지 주제를 다루는, 잡다한 흥미를 가지는\n여러가지 종류의, 이것저것 다양한
voca.means_en: A miscellaneous group consists of many different kinds of things or people that are difficult to put into a particular category.\n
A mischievous person likes to have fun by playing harmless tricks on people or doing things they are not supposed to do.\nA mischievous act or suggestion is intended to cause trouble.\n

voca.means_ko: [밋s컨쎕션]\n(옳지 않거나 사람들이 제대로 이해하지 못하는 정보에 근거한) 오해
voca.means_en: A misconception is an idea that is not correct.\n

task / duties / mission / job / assignment / chore
A mission is an important task that people are given to do, especially one that involves travelling to another country.
A mission is a group of people who have been sent to a foreign country to carry out an official task.
A mission is a special journey made by a military aeroplane or space rocket.
If you say that you have a mission, you mean that you have a strong commitment and sense of duty to do or achieve something.
A mission is the activities of a group of Christians who have been sent to a place to teach people about Christianity.
used when you have successfully completed what you have had to do\n

voca.means_ko:
[미st]
엷은 안개, 박무
안개, 놀, 연무, 이슬비
안개로 덮다, 이슬비가 내리다
voca.means_en: Mist consists of a large number of tiny drops of water in the air, which make it difficult to see very far.\nIf a piece of glass mists or is misted, it becomes covered with tiny drops of moisture, so that you cannot see through it easily.\n
if glass mists over, it becomes covered with very small drops of water so that you cannot see through it\nif your eyes mist over, they fill with tears\n
On a misty day, there is a lot of mist in the air.\n
The misuse of something is incorrect, careless, or dishonest use of it.\nIf someone misuses something, they use it incorrectly, carelessly, or dishonestly.\n
Mittens are gloves which have one section that covers your thumb and another section that covers your four fingers together.\n

voca.means_ko:
[믹s]
~을 섞다, 혼합하다, 교제하다
(두 가지 이상의 재로를 섞어) 만들다
혼합물
voca.means_en:
mix / stir / mingle / blend
If two substances mix or if you mix one substance with another, you stir or shake them together, or combine them in some other way, so that they become a single substance.
If you mix something, you prepare it by mixing other things together.
If two things or activities do not mix or if one thing does not mix with another, it is not a good idea to have them or do them together, because the result would be unpleasant or dangerous.
If you mix with other people, you meet them and talk to them. You can also say that people mix.
When a record producer mixes a piece of music, he or she puts together the various sounds that have been recorded in order to make the finished record.
combine things in different ways for different purposes\n

voca.means_ko:
[믹s져r]
(서로 다른것들이 섞인) 혼합물, 혼합체
(여러 재료를 석어 만든) 혼합 재료
혼합, 섞기, 혼합하기
voca.means_en: A mixture of things consists of several different things together.\nA mixture is a substance that consists of other substances which have been stirred or shaken together.\n

voca.means_ko:
[모운]
신음(소리), 슬픈 듯한 소리, 투덜거리다, 불평하다
투덜거림, 불평
신음하다
voca.means_en:
complain / protest / object / grumble / moan / whine / whinge
If you moan, you make a low sound, usually because you are unhappy or in pain.
To moan means to complain or speak in a way which shows that you are very unhappy.
A moan is a complaint.
The ship creaked and moaned.
Jack heard a low, deep moaning.
A moat is a deep, wide channel dug round a place such as a castle and filled with water, in order to protect the place from attack.\n

voca.means_ko:
[맙b]
(특히 폭력을 휘두르거나 말썽을 일으킬 것 같은) 군중, 무리, 
폭도, 집단, 군중, 갱, 마피아
(새, 동물이) 때를 지어 공격하다
(어떤 사람 주위로) 떼 지어 몰려들다
voca.means_en:
A mob is a large, disorganized, and often violent crowd of people.
People sometimes use the mob to refer in a disapproving way to the majority of people in a country or place, especially when these people are behaving in a violent or uncontrolled way.
You can refer to the people involved in organized crime as the Mob.
If you say that someone is being mobbed by a crowd of people, you mean that the people are trying to talk to them or get near them in an enthusiastic or threatening way.

voca.means_ko: [마커씐]\n모카신 (부드러운 가죽으로 만든 납작한 신, 원래 북미 원주민들이 신던 형태)
voca.means_en: Moccasins are soft leather shoes which have a low heel and a raised join round the top of the front part.\n

voca.means_ko:
[뫅-k]
(특히 흉내를 내며) 놀리다/조롱하다, 무시하다
거짓된, 가짜의, 모의의
모의고사
voca.means_en:
If someone mocks you, they show or pretend that they think you are foolish or inferior, for example by saying something funny about you, or by imitating your behaviour.
You use mock to describe something which is not real or genuine, but which is intended to be very similar to the real thing.
Mocks are practice exams that you take as part of your preparation for real exams.
to produce a copy of something that is going to be made, so that it can be tested or people can see what it will be like\n
modal verbs\nIn grammar, a modal or a modal auxiliary is a word such as `can' or `would' which is used with a main verb to express ideas such as possibility, intention, or necessity.\n

the condition of being modal
a quality, attribute, or circumstance that denotes mode, mood, or manner
the property of a statement of being classified under one of the concepts studied by modal logic, esp necessity or possibility
any physical or electrical therapeutic method or agency

voca.means_ko: ~을 절제하다, 알맞게 하다, 온화해지다\n온건한 사람, 온건주의자\n온건한, 적당한, 중간의, 알맞은, 보통의
voca.means_en:
Moderate political opinions or policies are not extreme.
You use moderate to describe people or groups who have moderate political opinions or policies.
You use moderate to describe something that is neither large nor small in amount or degree.
A moderate change in something is a change that is not great.

Someone who shows modesty does not talk much about their abilities or achievements.
You can refer to the modesty of something such as a place or amount when it is fairly small.
If someone, especially a woman, shows modesty, they are cautious about the way they dress and behave because they are aware that other people may view them in a sexual way.

If you modify something, you change it slightly, usually in order to improve it.\nA word or group of words that modifies another word describes or classifies something, or restricts the meaning of the word\n

a coefficient expressing a specified property of a specified substance See bulk modulus, modulus of rigidity, Young's modulus
the absolute value of a complex number See absolute value
the number by which a logarithm to one base is multiplied to give the corresponding logarithm to another base
an integer that can be divided exactly into the difference between two other integers See also congruence

A mole is a natural dark spot or small dark lump on someone's skin.
A mole is a small animal with black fur that lives underground.
A mole is a member of a government or other organization who gives secret information to the press or to a rival organization.
A molecule is the smallest amount of a chemical substance which can exist by itself.\n

A molehill is a small pile of earth made by a mole digging a tunnel.\nIf you say that someone is making a mountain out of a molehill, you are critical of them for making an unimportant fact or difficulty seem like a serious one.\n
You can refer to a very short period of time, for example a few seconds, as a moment or moments.\nA particular moment is the point in time at which something happens.\n

voca.means_ko: [모멘텀]\n(일의 진행에 있어서) 탄력, 기세, 여세, \n탄력성, 운동량
voca.means_en: If a process or movement gains momentum, it keeps developing or happening more quickly and keeps becoming less likely to stop.\nIn physics, momentum is the mass of a moving object multiplied by its speed in a particular direction.\n
The monarch of a country is the king, queen, emperor, or empress.\n
A monastery is a building or collection of buildings in which monks live.\n
Monday is the day after Sunday and before Tuesday.\n

money / cash
Money is the coins or bank notes that you use to buy things, or the sum that you have in a bank account.
Monies is used to refer to several separate sums of money that form part of a larger amount that is received or spent.
A monk is a member of a male religious community that is usually separated from the outside world.\n

A monkey is an animal with a long tail which lives in hot countries and climbs trees.\nIf you refer to a child as a monkey, you are saying in an affectionate way that he or she is very lively and naughty.\n
The monsoon is the season in Southern Asia when there is a lot of very heavy rain.\nMonsoon rains are sometimes referred to as the monsoons.\n

A monster is a large imaginary creature that looks very ugly and frightening.
A monster is something which is extremely large, especially something which is difficult to manage or which is unpleasant.
Monster means extremely and surprisingly large.

Your mood is the way you are feeling at a particular time. If you are in a good mood, you feel cheerful. If you are in a bad mood, you feel angry and impatient.
If someone is in a mood, the way they are behaving shows that they are feeling angry and impatient.
The mood of a group of people is the way that they think and feel about an idea, event, or question at a particular time.
The mood of a place is the general impression that you get of it.
Something that is moonlit is lit by moonlight.\n

A moose is a large type of deer. Moose have big flat horns called antlers and are found in Northern Europe, Asia, and North America. Some British speakers use moose to refer to the North American variety of this animal, and elk to refer to the European and Asian varieties.\n

A mop is a piece of equipment for washing floors. It consists of a sponge or many pieces of string attached to a long handle.
If someone has a mop of hair, they have a lot of hair and it looks rather untidy.
If you mop a surface such as a floor, you clean it with a mop.
If you mop sweat from your forehead or mop your forehead, you wipe it with a piece of cloth.

voca.means_ko: 더 많은 수/량의, 더,  더 많이
voca.means_en:
You use more to indicate that there is a greater amount of something than before or than average, or than something else. You can use 'a little', 'a lot', 'a bit', 'far', and 'much' in front of more.
You use more to refer to an additional thing or amount. You can use 'a little', 'a lot', 'a bit', 'far' and 'much' in front of more.
You use more to indicate that something or someone has a greater amount of a quality than they used to or than is average or usual.

voca.means_ko: 더욱 더, 갈수록 더\n점점 더 많은
대체로, 어느 정도, 거의, 대강, 약

voca.means_en: more important to the subject being discussed than what has already been mentioned\n

A mortar is a big gun which fires missiles high into the air over a short distance.
Mortar is a mixture of sand, water, and cement or lime which is put between bricks to hold them together.
A mortar is a bowl in which you can crush things such as herbs, spices, or grain using a rod called a pestle.
If you say that someone is mortified, you mean that they feel extremely offended, ashamed, or embarrassed.\n
If you say that something mortifies you, you mean that it offends or embarrasses you a great deal.\n
Moss is a very small soft green plant which grows on damp soil, or on wood or stone.\nVines and moss were hanging everywhere.\n
You use mostly to indicate that a statement is generally true, for example true about the majority of a group of things or people, true most of the time, or true in most respects.\n
A moth is an insect like a butterfly which usually flies about at night.\n

voca.means_ko:
[모우션]
운동, 움직임, 흔들림
(특히 의사를 전달하기 위한, 손, 머리의) 동작, 몸짓
동작/몸짓을 해 보이다
voca.means_en:
Motion is the activity or process of continually changing position or moving from one place to another.
A motion is an action, gesture, or movement.
A motion is a formal proposal or statement in a meeting, debate, or trial, which is discussed and then voted on or decided on.
If you motion to someone, you move your hand or head as a way of telling them to do something or telling them where to go.
Your motivation for doing something is what causes you to want to do it.\n

voca.means_ko: [머뤄라이z]\n(차에) 엔진을 달다\n(차 따위에) 모터를 장치하다. (농경) 동력화 하다
voca.means_en: to equip with a motor\nto provide (military units) with motor vehicles\n
A mound of something is a large rounded pile of it.\nIn baseball, the mound is the raised area where the pitcher stands when he or she throws the ball.\n
A mountain is a very high area of land with steep sides.\n
A mountainside is one of the steep sides of a mountain.\n

voca.means_ko: 한 입 가득,  한 입(소량)\n(발음하기 어려운) 장황한/과장된 말\n길고 복잡한 말(발음하기 힘든) 말
voca.means_en: A mouthful of drink or food is the amount that you put or have in your mouth.\nIf you describe a long word or phrase as a mouthful, you mean that it is difficult to say.

voca.means_ko:
움직이다, 움직이게 하다
바뀌다, 달라지다
옮기다, 두다
조취, 행동, 움직임, 이사 (생각, 행동, 태도 등의) 변화
voca.means_en:
action / move / act / gesture / deed / feat
When you move something or when it moves, its position changes and it does not remain still.
When you move, you change your position or go to a different place.
If you move, you act or you begin to do something.
If people in authority move someone, they make that person go from one place or job to another one.

voca.means_ko: (특히 다른사람에게 공간을 만들어 주기 위해)\n움직이다, 비키다
voca.means_en: to go forward\nif a project, etc. moves along, or if somebody moves it along, it continues to make good progress\n

voca.means_ko: 떠나다, \n이사/이전 하다, 전근/전직 하다\n(입장, 견해 따위를) 바꾸다
voca.means_en: to leave the place or position you are in and go to another; to take something from one place or position and put it in another\nto leave the place where you live to go and live in another place\n
to start a journey; to begin to move\nto leave the place where you are; to remove somebody/something from a particular place\n

to make somebody leave a place, especially their home
to leave your home and go to live somewhere else
to remove something from a place, especially in order to make more space

voca.means_ko: (다른 사람에게 공간을 만들어 주기 위해)\n몸을 움직이다, 자세를 바꾸다
voca.means_en: to go towards somebody/something\nto go forward slowly across a surface; to make something do this\n

voca.means_ko: [무v먼t]\n(몸, 신체 부위의) 움직임, 운동, 동작,\n(장소의) 이동
voca.means_en:
A movement is a group of people who share the same beliefs, ideas, or aims.
Movement involves changing position or going from one place to another.
A movement is a planned change in position that an army makes during a battle or military exercise.
Movement is a gradual development or change of an attitude, opinion, or policy.
Your movements are everything which you do or plan to do during a period of time.
A movie is a film.\nYou can talk about the movies when you are talking about seeing a movie in a movie theater.\n
A mower is the same as a lawnmower.\nA mower is a machine that has sharp blades for cutting something such as corn or wheat.\n
although\n
soil / mud / clay / land / earth / dirt / ground\nMud is a sticky mixture of earth and water.\n
A mudslide is a large amount of mud sliding down a mountain, usually causing damage or destruction.\n

A mug is a large deep cup with straight sides and a handle, used for hot drinks.
If you say that someone is a mug, you mean that they are stupid and easily deceived by other people.
Someone's mug is their face.
If someone mugs you, they attack you in order to steal your money.

voca.means_ko: [물롸로-]\n(각각 백인과 흑인인 부모 사이에서 태오난 사람)
voca.means_en: a person having one Black and one White parent\nof a light brown colour\n
Multicultural means consisting of or relating to people of many different nationalities and cultures.\n

You use multiple to describe things that consist of many parts, involve many people, or have many uses.
If one number is a multiple of a smaller number, it can be exactly divided by that smaller number.
A multiple or a multiple store is a shop with a lot of branches in different towns.
If you munch food, you eat it by chewing it slowly, thoroughly, and rather noisily.\n

voca.means_ko: 살해하다, 죽이다, 망쳐놓다, 잡치다\n살인, 살해, 살인적인 일, 어려운 일

voca.means_en: A murky place or time of day is dark and rather unpleasant because there is not enough light.\n

If you murmur something, you say it very quietly, so that not many people can hear what you are saying.
A murmur is something that is said which can hardly be heard.
A murmur is a continuous low sound, like the noise of a river or of voices far away.
A murmur of a particular emotion is a quiet expression of it.
A murmur is an abnormal sound which is made by the heart and which shows that there is probably something wrong with it.
If someone does something without a murmur, they do it without complaining.

voca.means_ko: 그 위에서(주문 등을) 작은 소리로 부르다

voca.means_en: A museum is a building where a large number of interesting and valuable objects, such as works of art or historical items, are kept, studied, and displayed to the public.\n

Mush is a thick, soft paste.
If you describe something such as a film or book as mush, you mean that it is very sentimental.
If you mush something, you make it into a mush.
Mussels are a kind of shellfish that you can eat from their shells.\n

voca.means_ko: (필요성 중요성을 나타내어) ~해야 한다\n(틀림없이) ~일 것이다, ~임에 틀림없다\n꼭 ~ 해야 한다.
voca.means_en:
must / have (got) to / must not / don’t have to
You use must to indicate that you think it is very important or necessary for something to happen. You use must not or mustn't to indicate that you think it is very important or necessary for something not to happen.
You use must to indicate that it is necessary for something to happen, usually because of a rule or law.
You use must to indicate that you are fairly sure that something is the case.
able to or tending to change\n
A mutineer is a person who takes part in a mutiny.\n"Mutineers! Come back!" shouted Cap'n Bones.
Mutton is meat from an adult sheep that is eaten as food.\n

voca.means_ko: 내 잘못이다, (자기 잘못이나 실수를 인정할 때 씀)
voca.means_en: used when you are admitting that something is your fault or that you have made a mistake\n

voca.means_ko: 마나님, 아씨 (특히 귀부인에 대한 하인의 말)
도움이 되어 저도 기뻐요.\n도와드릴 수 있어서 저도 기뻐요.\n(고맙다는 말에 대한 정중한 인사)

voca.means_en: A myth is a well-known story which was made up in the past to explain natural events or to justify religious beliefs or social customs.\nIf you describe a belief or explanation as a myth, you mean that many people believe it but it is actually untrue.\n
Someone or something that is mythic exists only in myths and is therefore imaginary.\nIf you describe someone or something as mythic, you mean that they have become very famous or important.\n

voca.means_ko: [미쏼러즤]\n(일반적인 또는 특정 문화 사회 등의 집합적) 신화\n(많은 사람들의) 근거 없는 믿음, 신화
voca.means_en: Mythology is a group of myths, especially all the myths from a particular country, religion, or culture.\nYou can use mythology to refer to the beliefs or opinions that people have about something, when you think that they are false or untrue.\n

voca.means_ko: [네엡]\n(나쁜 짓을 하고 있는 사람을) 붙잡다, 체포하다\n가지다, 가져가다
voca.means_en: If people in authority such as the police nab someone who they think has done something wrong, they catch them or arrest them.\n
Nail polish is a thick liquid that women paint on their nails.\n

voca.means_ko: [나이-v]\n(경험, 지식의 부족으로) 순진해 빠진, \n(모자랄 정도로) 순진한, 순진무구한
voca.means_en: If you describe someone as naive, you think they lack experience and so expect things to be easy or people to be honest or kind.\n

voca.means_ko:
[네임]
이름짓다, 명명하다, 이름을 대다/확인하다
지명/임명하다
이름, 성함, 성명, 명칭, 평판, 명성, 유명인, 명사
voca.means_en:
The name of a person, place, or thing is the word or group of words that is used to identify them.
You can refer to the reputation of a person or thing as their name.
You can refer to someone as, for example, a famous name or a great name when they are well-known.
When you name someone or something, you give them a name, usually at the beginning of their life.
If you name someone or something after another person or thing, you give them the same name as that person or thing.
to give somebody/something the name of somebody/something else that you like or admire, for example a family member or a famous person or place\n

voca.means_ko: [네임뤼s]\n이름 없는, 이름을 모르는\n이름을 밝히지 않은, 익명의
voca.means_en: You describe people or things as nameless when you do not know their name or when they do not have a name.\nIf you say that someone or something will remain nameless, you mean that you will not mention their name, often because you do not want to embarrass them.\n
A nappy is a piece of soft thick cloth or paper which is fastened round a baby's bottom in order to soak up its urine and faeces.\n

voca.means_ko: 좁아지다, 적어지다, 작아지다\n폭이 좁은, 편협한, 가는
범위를 좁히다\n(선택 가능한 수효를) 줄이다, 좁히다
voca.means_en: to gradually reduce the number of possibilities\n
If you describe someone as narrow-minded, you are criticizing them because they are unwilling to consider new ideas or other people's opinions.\n
a situation where somebody only just avoids injury, danger or failure\n

Nasal is used to describe things relating to the nose and the functions it performs.\nIf someone's voice is nasal, it sounds as if air is passing through their nose as well as their mouth while they are speaking.\n

voca.means_ko:
[네s디]
(아주 나빠서) 끔찍한, 형편없는,
(성격, 행동 등이) 못된, 고약한/심술궂은
불쾌한, 좋지않은, 심술궃은, 비열한
위험한, 험악한, 시막한
voca.means_en:
Something that is nasty is very unpleasant to see, experience, or feel.
If you describe a person or their behaviour as nasty, you mean that they behave in an unkind and unpleasant way.
If you describe something as nasty, you mean it is unattractive, undesirable, or in bad taste.
A nasty problem or situation is very worrying and difficult to deal with.
of or relating to birth / a rare word for native\n
A nation is an individual country considered together with its social and political structures.\nThe nation is sometimes used to refer to all the people who live in a particular country.\n

voca.means_ko:
[네츄럴]
(인위적으로 만든 것이 아닌) 자연의, 천연의, 자연스러운
(행동이) 타고난, 천성의
자연 발생적인, 당연한, 정상적인
voca.means_en:
If you say that it is natural for someone to act in a particular way or for something to happen in that way, you mean that it is reasonable in the circumstances.
Natural behaviour is shared by all people or all animals of a particular type and has not been learned.
Someone with a natural ability or skill was born with that ability and did not have to learn it.
If someone's behaviour is natural, they appear to be relaxed and are not trying to hide anything.
Natural things exist or occur in nature and are not made or caused by people.

If you pick your nose or teeth, you remove substances from inside your nose or between your teeth.
If you pick a fight or quarrel with someone, you deliberately cause one.
If someone such as a thief picks a lock, they open it without a key, for example by using a piece of wire.
You can refer to the best things or people in a particular group as the pick of that group.
When I looked at him, he was picking his nose.\n

voca.means_ko: ~를 (차에) 태우러 가다, ~를 차에 태우다\n~를 구조해 내다\n~를 체포하다
voca.means_en:
pick up somebodyif a bus, etc. picks up somebody, it stops and allows them to get on
to rescue somebody, for example from the sea
to arrest somebody; to take somebody somewhere in order to question them
to start talking to somebody you do not know, because you want to have a sexual relationship with them
to remove something from something with your nails or a tool\n

voca.means_ko:
(여럿 가운데서 신중하게) ~을 고르다/선발하다
(여럿 가운데서) ~을 알아보다/알아보고 골라내다,
(악보없이 천천히) ~을 연주하다
(세심히 살펴본 후) ~을 알아내다/알아보다
voca.means_en:
identify / recognize / make out / discern / pick out / distinguish
to choose somebody/something from a number of people or things
to recognize somebody/something from among people or things
to discover or recognize something after careful study
if you pick out a tune on a musical instrument, you play it slowly, note by note, without using written music
be picked outto paint, draw or write something in such a way that it is very easy to see, especially by using a colour that is different from the background

voca.means_ko: (어떤 정보를) 듣게/알게 되다, ~을 알아보다/알아채다\n~을 얻다/획득하다, \n(어지러진 물건을) 치우다/정리하다
voca.means_en: to obtain or buy something\n

to become better; to improve
if the wind picks up, it starts to blow more strongly
to start again; to continue

voca.means_ko: ~을 이해하다/알아차리다\n(이미 언급되거나 논의된 사항인) ~으로 다시 돌아가다
voca.means_en: to notice something\nto return to a point in order to talk about it in more detail\n
Someone who is picky is difficult to please and only likes a small range of things.\n

voca.means_ko: [피-s]\n(자르거나 나눠놓은 것의) 한 부분, 조각, 하나, 작품\n완성하다
voca.means_en:
A piece of something is an amount of it that has been broken off, torn off, or cut off.
A piece of an object is one of the individual parts or sections which it is made of, especially a part that can be removed.
A piece of land is an area of land.
You can use piece of with many uncount nouns to refer to an individual thing of a particular kind. For example, you can refer to some advice as a piece of advice.

If a sharp object pierces something, or if you pierce something with a sharp object, the object goes into it and makes a hole in it.\nIf you have your ears or some other part of your body pierced, you have a small hole made through them so that you can wear a piece of jewellery in them.\n
She looked at me with piercing blue eyes.\nA beautiful old woman with long white hair and piercing eyes.\n

voca.means_ko: [피기]\n(어린 아이의 말로) 돼지, \n작은 돼지, 새끼 돼지
voca.means_en: A piggy is a child's word for a pig or a piglet.\nIf someone has piggy eyes, their eyes are small and unattractive.\n
A piggy bank is a small container shaped like a pig, with a narrow hole in the top through which to put coins. Children often use piggy banks to save money.\n

voca.means_ko: [파일]\n(위로 차곡차곡) 쌓아올린 것, 더미, 다수, 대량\n~을 쌓다, 싣다, 저축하다, 늘리다
voca.means_en:
A pile of things is a mass of them that is high in the middle and has sloping sides.
A pile of things is a quantity of things that have been put neatly somewhere so that each thing is on top of the one below.
If you talk about a pile of something or piles of something, you mean a large amount of it.
If you pile things somewhere, you put them there so that they form a pile.
If something is piled with things, it is covered or filled with piles of things.
"From that pile of furry skins" said Annie, pointing.
if somebody's weight piles on, it increases rapidly\n

voca.means_ko: ~을 빠르게 증가시키다\n(감정을 필요 이상으로) 과장하다\n(사람에게) ~을 더 많이/지나치게 주다
voca.means_en:
to express a feeling in a much stronger way than is necessary
to give somebody a lot or too much of something
to make something increase rapidly
to form a pile; to make a lot of things into a pile\nto increase or to make something increase in quantity or amount\n
Pills are small solid round masses of medicine or vitamins that you swallow without chewing.\nIf a woman is on the pill, she takes a special pill that prevents her from becoming pregnant.\n

voca.means_ko: 조종하다, 추진시키다\n조종사, 안내인, 도선사\n안내의, 예비의, 사전의

(손가락으로) 꼬집다, 죄다
(실발 등이) 너무 끼다/꽉 조여 아프게 하다
(특히 사소한 것을) 흠치게 하다
꼬집기, 집기, 깨우기, 죄기
voca.means_en:
If you pinch a part of someone's body, you take a piece of their skin between your thumb and first finger and give it a short squeeze.
To pinch something, especially something of little value, means to steal it.
A pinch of an ingredient such as salt is the amount of it that you can hold between your thumb and your first finger.
He pinched his nose tighter.

voca.means_ko:
[파일]
솔, 소나무
못내(애타게) 기리워하다, 갈망하다
(사람이 죽거나 떠난 후) 몹시 슬퍼하다, 비통해 하다
voca.means_en:
A pine tree or a pine is a tall tree which has very thin, sharp leaves and a fresh smell. Pine trees have leaves all year round.
If you pine for someone who has died or gone away, you want them to be with you very much and feel sad because they are not there.
If you pine for something, you want it very much, especially when it is unlikely that you will be able to have it.
to become very sad, and sometimes ill/sick or weak because somebody has died or gone away\n
to want or miss somebody/something very much\n
to want or miss somebody/something very much\n

voca.means_ko:
[파이어니어]
(특정 지식, 문화 부문의) 개척자/선구자
(거친땅을 일구는) 개척자
개척하다
voca.means_en:
Someone who is referred to as a pioneer in a particular area of activity is one of the first people to be involved in it and develop it.
Pioneers are people who leave their own country or the place where they were living, and go and live in a place that has not been lived in before.
Someone who pioneers a new activity, invention, or process is one of the first people to do it.

voca.means_ko:
[파입p]
(속에 액체, 기체가 흐르는) 관, 도관, 파이프, 관 모양의 것
(기체, 액체를) 관으로 보내다
피리를 불다, 높은 소리로 말/노래 하다
voca.means_en:
A pipe is a long, round, hollow object, usually made of metal or plastic, through which a liquid or gas can flow.
A pipe is an object which is used for smoking tobacco. You put the tobacco into the cup-shaped part at the end of the pipe, light it, and breathe in the smoke through a narrow tube.
A pipe is a simple musical instrument in the shape of a tube with holes in it. You play a pipe by blowing into it while covering and uncovering the holes with your fingers.
If liquid or gas is piped somewhere, it is transferred from one place to another through a pipe.
used to tell somebody to be less noisy or to stop talking\n

voca.means_ko: (느닷없이) 지껄이기 시작하다\n(자지 주장을 하려고) 소리를 높이다
voca.means_en: To begin to speak.\n"Jake and I can read" Annie piped up.\n
A piranha is a small, fierce fish which is found in South America.\nThey're piranhas! They'll eat anything! Even people!\n

voca.means_ko: [파이륏t]\n해적, 약탈자, 저작/특허권 침해자, 표절자\n저작/특허권을 침해하다, ~ 을 표절하다
voca.means_en:
Pirates are sailors who attack other ships and steal property from them.
Someone who pirates video tapes, cassettes, books, or computer programs copies and sells them when they have no right to do so.
A pirate version of something is an illegal copy of it.
"Pirates of the Caribbean"

voca.means_ko: (땅에 생긴/판) 구명, 우묵한 곳, 함정\n~에 구멍을 파다/뚫다, 우묵하게 파다
voca.means_en: They covered deep pits with branches.\nThe pit was too deep to climb out of.\n

voca.means_ko:
[핏취]
치다, (힘껏) 내던지다, 투구하다, 
(상품을) 팔려고 내놓다
(감정, 활동의) 정도/강도, 정점, 최고조
음의 높이
던지기, 투구, 최고도, 절정, 정점
voca.means_en:
A pitch is an area of ground that is marked out and used for playing a game such as football, cricket, or hockey.
The pitch of a sound is how high or low it is.
If something such as a feeling or a situation rises to a high pitch, it rises to a high level.
If you pitch something somewhere, you throw it with quite a lot of force, usually aiming it carefully.
To pitch somewhere means to fall forwards suddenly and with a lot of force.
If someone is pitched into a new situation, they are suddenly forced into it.
In the game of baseball or rounders, when you pitch the ball, you throw it to the batter for them to hit it.
If a sound is pitched at a particular level, it is produced at the level indicated.
If something is pitched at a particular level or degree of difficulty, it is set at that level.
to arrive somewhere, especially late or without planning\n
If a place or the night is pitch-black, it is completely dark.\n

voca.means_ko: 주문하다, 설치/배치하다, (조심스럽게) 놓다, 두다\n장소, (장소를 가리키는) 곳, 부분, 부위, 자리
voca.means_en:
place / site / position / location / scene / spot / venue
A place is any point, building, area, town, or country.
If you place something somewhere, you put it in a particular position, especially in a careful, firm, or deliberate way.
In her place was an old woman.
Annie placed the mouse on the leafy forest floor.

voca.means_ko: 빠져있는 다른 것을 대신하는 기호나 텍스트의 일부

[플뤠인]
평원, 평야, 평지
(보거나 이해하기에) 명백한, 분명한, 평범한, 단순한
숨김없는, 솔직한
분명하게, 똑똑히, 알기쉽게
voca.means_en:
clear / obvious / apparent / evident / plain / crystal clear
A plain object, surface, or fabric is entirely in one colour and has no pattern, design, or writing on it.
Something that is plain is very simple in style.
If a fact, situation, or statement is plain, it is easy to recognize or understand.
If you describe someone as plain, you think they look ordinary and not at all beautiful.
a message set in a directly readable form rather than in coded groups\n

voca.means_ko: ~에 대패질 하다, 평평하게 하다\n비행기, 날개, 평면, 대패(목공)\n평평한, 평면의
(벽 등에 거는) 장식 액자, 장식판, 치석

voca.means_en:
Plaster is a smooth paste made of sand, lime, and water which goes hard when it dries. Plaster is used to cover walls and ceilings and is also used to make sculptures.
A plaster is a strip of sticky material used for covering small cuts or sores on your body.
If you plaster a wall or ceiling, you cover it with a layer of plaster.
If you plaster a surface or a place with posters or pictures, you stick a lot of them all over it.
If you plaster yourself in some kind of sticky substance, you cover yourself in it.

voca.means_ko: (금이 갔거나 낡은 벽 위에) 회반죽을 바르다
voca.means_en: to cover something such as a crack or a wall with plaster\n

voca.means_ko:
[플레잇t]
(보통 둥그런) 접시, 그릇, 음식, 요리
판, 번호판, 
~ 에 도금하다, 판금으로 덥다
voca.means_en:
A plate is a round or oval flat dish that is used to hold food.
A plate is a flat piece of metal, especially on machinery or a building.
On a road vehicle, the plates are the panels at the front and back which display the license number in the United States, and the registration number in Britain.
Plate is dishes, bowls, and cups that are made of precious metal, especially silver or gold.
A plate in a book is a picture or photograph which takes up a whole page and is usually printed on better quality paper than the rest of the book.
buy and sell stocks and shares in order to make a profit\n
A playful gesture or person is friendly or humorous.\nA playful animal is lively and cheerful.\n

A playground is a piece of land, at school or in a public area, where children can play.\nIf you describe a place as a playground for a certain group of people, you mean that those people like to enjoy themselves there or go on holiday there.\n

voca.means_ko:
[p뤼-d]
애원하다, 
변호 하다, (~에 대한) ~을 변명/이유로 내놓다
(~의 주장을) 옹호하다, 주장하다
voca.means_en:
If you plead with someone to do something, you ask them in an intense, emotional way to do it.
When someone charged with a crime pleads guilty or not guilty in a court of law, they officially state that they are guilty or not guilty of the crime.
If you plead the case or cause of someone or something, you speak out in their support or defence.
If you plead a particular thing as the reason for doing or not doing something, you give it as your excuse.
Something that is pleasant is nice, enjoyable, or attractive.\nSomeone who is pleasant is friendly and likeable.\n

entertainment / fun / recreation / relaxation / play / pleasure / amusement
If something gives you pleasure, you get a feeling of happiness, satisfaction, or enjoyment from it.
Pleasure is the activity of enjoying yourself, especially rather than working or doing what you have a duty to do.
A pleasure is an activity, experience or aspect of something that you find very enjoyable or satisfying.
If you meet someone for the first time, you can say, as a way of being polite, that it is a pleasure to meet them. You can also ask for the pleasure of someone's company as a polite and formal way of inviting them somewhere.
You can say `It's a pleasure' or `My pleasure' as a polite way of replying to someone who has just thanked you for doing something.
A pleat in a piece of clothing is a permanent fold that is made in the cloth by folding one part over the other and sewing across the top end of the fold.\n

If there is plenty of something, there is a large amount of it. If there are plenty of things, there are many of them. Plenty is used especially to indicate that there is enough of something, or more than you need.
Plenty is a situation in which people have a lot to eat or a lot of money to live on.
You use plenty in front of adjectives or adverbs to emphasize the degree of the quality they are describing.

voca.means_ko: 털썩 앉다, 벌렁 눕다, 퐁당 소리를 내다
잡아 뜯다, 뜯어내다, 뽑아내다, 골라내다\n(꽃, 과일을) 따다, 꺽다\n뽑아내기
voca.means_en: If you pluck a fruit, flower, or leaf, you take it between your fingers and pull it in order to remove it from its stalk where it is growing.\nShe starts to pluck at the air just in front of Ross.\n

voca.means_ko: [플롸g]\n(욕조, 싱크대의 구멍을 막는) 마개, 플러그\n메우다, 틀어막다, 끼워넣다
voca.means_en:
lid / top / cork / cap / plug / stopper
A plug on a piece of electrical equipment is a small plastic object with two or three metal pins which fit into the holes of an electric socket and connects the equipment to the electricity supply.
A plug is an electric socket.
A plug is a thick, circular piece of rubber or plastic that you use to block the hole in a bath or sink when it is filled with water.
A plug is a small, round piece of wood, plastic, or wax which is used to block holes.
If someone plugs a commercial product, especially a book or a film, they praise it in order to encourage people to buy it or see it because they have an interest in it doing well.
to connect a piece of electrical equipment to the electricity supply or to another piece of electrical equipment\n
to fill or block a hole with a substance or a piece of material that fits tightly into it\n

A plum is a small, sweet fruit with a smooth red or yellow skin and a stone in the middle.
Something that is plum or plum-coloured is a dark reddish-purple colour.
A plum job, contract, or role is a very good one that a lot of people would like.

voca.means_ko: [플롸암]\n(신비한 것을) 헤아리다, 파헤치다\n바로, 정확히, 완전히, 수직의, 곧은
voca.means_en:
If you plumb something mysterious or difficult to understand, you succeed in understanding it.
When someone plumbs a building, they put in all the pipes for carrying water.
If someone plumbs the depths of an unpleasant emotion or quality, they experience it or show it to an extreme degree.
to connect a washing machine, a bath, etc. to a water system\n

The plumbing in a building consists of the water and drainage pipes, baths, and toilets in it.\nPlumbing is the work of connecting and repairing things such as water and drainage pipes, baths, and toilets.\n

voca.means_ko:
[플란쥐]
감소하다, 급락하다, 떨어지다
(위아래로) 마구 요동치다
밀어넣다, 쑤셔밖다, 뛰어들다, 빠지다, 돌진하다
(양, 가치의) 급락,
voca.means_en:
If something or someone plunges in a particular direction, especially into water, they fall, rush, or throw themselves in that direction.
If you plunge an object into something, you push it quickly or violently into it.
If a person or thing is plunged into a particular state or situation, or if they plunge into it, they are suddenly in that state or situation.
If you plunge into an activity or are plunged into it, you suddenly get very involved in it.
If an amount or rate plunges, it decreases quickly and suddenly.
The woolly mammoth roared and plunged forward.

voca.means_ko: (~안으로) 벌컥 뛰어들다, 맹렬히 돌진하다\n(하는일에) 정신없이 빠져들기 시작하다
voca.means_en: to jump or fall into something, usually with some force\nto begin doing something or talking about something without preparing for it or thinking carefully\n
to put something quickly and with force into something else\n
The plural form of a word is the form that is used when referring to more than one person or thing.\nThe plural of a noun is the form of it that is used to refer to more than one person or thing.\n

voca.means_ko:
[포우취]
(조류, 동물, 물고리를) 밀렵하다
(남의 것을) 가로채다, 도용하다, 침해/침범하다
(특히 생선을) 졸이다
voca.means_en:
If someone poaches fish, animals, or birds, they illegally catch them on someone else's property.
If an organization poaches members or customers from another organization, they secretly or dishonestly persuade them to join them or become their customers.
If someone poaches an idea, they dishonestly or illegally use the idea.
When you poach an egg, you cook it gently in boiling water without its shell.
If you poach food such as fish, you cook it gently in boiling water, milk, or other liquid.
A poem is a piece of writing in which the words are chosen for their beauty and sound and are carefully arranged, often in short lines which rhyme.\n
A poet is a person who writes poems.\n
Poems, considered as a form of literature, are referred to as poetry.\nYou can describe something very beautiful as poetry.\n

voca.means_ko: [포인t]\n겨누다, 지적하다\n점, 끝, 순간, 요점, 요소, 점수
voca.means_en:
purpose / aim / intention / plan / point / idea
You use point to refer to something that someone has said or written.
If you say that someone has a point, or if you take their point, you mean that you accept that what they have said is important and should be considered.
The point of what you are saying or discussing is the most important part that provides a reason or explanation for the rest.
If you point at a person or thing, you hold out your finger towards them in order to make someone notice them.
If you point something at someone, you aim the tip or end of it towards them.
to give special emphasis to one particular aspect of a problem, fact or opinion; to show something very clearly\n

to mention something that you think is important and/or the reason why a particular situation exists\nif a fact, event or situation points to something, it suggests that this is true or likely to happen\n
Something that is pointy has a point at one end.\n
Poison is a substance that harms or kills people or animals if they swallow it or absorb it.\n

Something that is poisonous will kill you or make you ill if you swallow or absorb it.
An animal that is poisonous produces a poison that will kill you or make you ill if the animal bites you.
If you describe something as poisonous, you mean that it is extremely unpleasant and likely to spoil or destroy a good relationship or situation.

voca.means_ko:
[포욱k]
(손가락 등으로) 쿡 찌르다, 찌르다, 쑤시다, 
(재빨리) 밀다, 찌르다, 쑥 내밀다,
참견하다, 내밀다, 삐져나오다
voca.means_en:
If you poke someone or something, you quickly push them with your finger or with a sharp object.
If you poke one thing into another, you push the first thing into the second thing.
If something pokes out of or through another thing, you can see part of it appearing from behind or underneath the other thing.
If you poke your head through an opening or if it pokes through an opening, you push it through, often so that you can see something more easily.
The mouse poked its head out of Annie's pouch.
to look for something, especially something that is hidden among other things that you have to move.\n
to try to find out information, especially secret or hidden information; to get involved in something that does not concern you.\n
to push your finger, a stick, etc. into something, often several times.\nHe poked at other stuff in the store - an old feed sack, a rusted tin cup, a faded calendar dated 1878.\n

voca.means_ko: (뾰족한 것, 손가락 등으로 자꾸) ~을 쿡쿡 찌르다
voca.means_en: to push your finger, a stick, etc. into something, often several times\n

voca.means_ko:
[포올]
막대기, 기둥, 장대, (지구의) 극
~을 막대기로 받치다
장대로 배를 밀고 가다
voca.means_en:
A pole is a long thin piece of wood or metal, used especially for supporting things.
The earth's poles are the two opposite ends of its axis, its most northern and southern points.
The two poles of a range of qualities, opinions, or beliefs are the completely opposite qualities, opinions, or beliefs at either end of the range.

The police are the official organization that is responsible for making sure that people obey the law.
Police are men and women who are members of the official organization that is responsible for making sure that people obey the law.
If the police or military forces police an area or event, they make sure that law and order is preserved in that area or at that event.

A policy is a set of ideas or plans that is used as a basis for making decisions, especially in politics, economics, or business.
An official organization's policy on a particular issue or towards a country is their attitude and actions regarding that issue or country.
An insurance policy is a document which shows the agreement that you have made with an insurance company.

voca.means_ko: [풜뤼시]\n광택제, 연마제, 광택, 윤, 닦는 재료, \n닦다, 반짝이게 하다, 광을 내다
voca.means_en:
Polish is a substance that you put on the surface of an object in order to clean it, protect it, and make it shine.
If you say that someone has polish, you mean that they show confidence and know how to behave socially.
If you say that a performance or piece of work has polish, you mean that it is of a very high standard.
If you polish something, you put polish on it or rub it with a cloth to make it shine.

pressure / stress / tension / strain

If there is pressure on a person, someone is trying to persuade or force them to do something.

If you pretend that something is the case, you act in a way that is intended to make people believe that it is the case, although in fact it is not.

"Jack, look at those pretty fish with the teeth" said Annie.

If a proposal, principle, or opinion prevails, it gains influence or is accepted, often after a struggle or argument.

If one side in a battle, contest, or dispute prevails, it wins.

To prevent something means to ensure that it does not happen.\nTo prevent someone from doing something means to make it impossible for them to do it.\n

A quarter is one of four equal parts of something.
A quarter is a fixed period of three months. Companies often divide their financial year into four quarters.
When you are telling the time, you use quarter to talk about the fifteen minutes before or after an hour. For example, 8.15 is quarter past eight, and 8.45 is quarter to nine. In American English, you can also say that 8.15 is a quarter after eight and 8.45 is a quarter of nine.
A quarter is an American or Canadian coin that is worth 25 cents.
If you quarter something such as a fruit or a vegetable, you cut it into four roughly equal parts.
If the number or size of something is quartered, it is reduced to about a quarter of its previous number or size.
If you do something at close quarters, you do it very near to a particular person or thing.

In British English a receipt is a piece of paper that you get in a shop when you buy something, but in American English the more usual term for this is sales slip.\nReceipts are the amount of money received during a particular period, for example by a shop or theatre.\n

If someone or something has a particular kind of reception, that is the way that people react to them

If you say that someone or something reminds you of another person or thing, you mean that they are similar to the other person or thing and that they make you think about them.

Ritual activities happen as part of a ritual or tradition.
You can describe something as a ritual action when it is done in exactly the same way whenever a particular situation occurs.

Your rival is a person, business, or organization who you are competing or fighting against in the same area or for the same things.
If you say that someone or something has no rivals or is without rival, you mean that it is best of its type.
If you say that one thing rivals another, you mean that they are both of the same standard or quality.

If something, usually a vehicle, roars somewhere, it goes there very fast, making a loud noise.

The water roared as it raced downhill. / The cat roared and spun around.
The woolly mammoth roared and plunged forward.
A loud roar filled Jack's ears.
If someone is robbed, they have money or property stolen from them.\nIf someone is robbed of something that they deserve, have, or need, it is taken away from them.\n
A robber is someone who steals money or property from a bank, a shop, or a vehicle, often by using force or threats.\n
Robbery is the crime of stealing money or property from a bank, shop, or vehicle, often by using force or threats.\n

A robe is a loose piece of clothing which covers all of your body and reaches the ground. You can describe someone as wearing a robe or as wearing robes.

He wore a long fur robe.

If you roll something flexible into a cylinder or a ball, you form it into a cylinder or a ball by wrapping it several times around itself or by shaping it between your hands.

Journalists use romp in expressions like romp home, romp in, or romp to victory, to say that a person or horse has won a race or competition very easily.\nWhen children or animals romp, they play noisily and happily.\n
to do something easily and quickly\n

If there is rot in something, especially something that is made of wood, parts of it have decayed and fallen apart.
You can use the rot to refer to the way something gradually gets worse. For example, if you are talking about the time when the rot set in, you are talking about the time when a situation began to get steadily worse and worse.

If you describe someone as rotten, you are insulting them or criticizing them because you think that they are very unpleasant or unkind.

Now Jack and Annie and Peanut are about to set out in search of the third thing… in Sunset of the sabertooth.\n

~을 부대에 담다, ~ 을 해고하다, 약탈하다
voca.means_en:
A sack is a large bag made of rough woven material. Sacks are used to carry or store things such as vegetables or coal.
Some people refer to bed as the sack.
If your employers sack you, they tell you that you can no longer work for them because you have done something that they did not like or because your work was not good enough.
to lie down to rest or relax\n

Something that is sacred is believed to be holy and to have a special connection with God.
Something connected with religion or used in religious ceremonies is described as sacred.
You can describe something as sacred when it is regarded as too important to be changed or interfered with.

If you are sad, you feel unhappy, usually because something has happened that you do not like.
Sad stories and sad news make you feel sad.
A sad event or situation is unfortunate or undesirable.
If you describe someone as sad, you do not have any respect for them and think their behaviour or ideas are ridiculous.

A saddle is a leather seat that you put on the back of an animal so that you can ride the animal.
If you saddle a horse, you put a saddle on it so that you can ride it.
A saddle is a seat on a bicycle or motorcycle.
If you saddle someone with a problem or with a responsibility, you put them in a position where they have to deal with it.
to prepare to ride a horse by placing a saddle on it\n

Something that is safe does not cause physical harm or danger.
If a person or thing is safe from something, they cannot be harmed or damaged by it.
If you are safe, you have not been harmed, or you are not in danger of being harmed.
A safe place is one where it is unlikely that any harm, damage, or unpleasant things will happen to the people or things that are there.
If people or things have a safe journey, they reach their destination without harm, damage, or unpleasant things happening to them.

If you do something for the sake of something, you do it for that purpose or in order to achieve that result. You can also say that you do it for something's sake.
If you do something for its own sake, you do it because you want to, or because you enjoy it, and not for any other reason. You can also talk about, for example, art for art's sake or sport for sport's sake.
When you do something for someone's sake, you do it in order to help them or make them happy.
Some people use expressions such as for God's sake, for heaven's sake, for goodness sake, or for Pete's sake in order to express annoyance or impatience, or to add force to a question or request. The expressions `for God's sake' and `for Christ's sake' could cause offence.
For Morgan's sake!

voca.means_ko: 도룡뇽, 양서류, 불에 견디는 것, 석쇠
~에게 봉급을 주다\n봉급, 월급, 급료, 연봉, 임금

voca.means_en: Saliva is the watery liquid that forms in your mouth and helps you to chew and digest food.\n
A salmon is a large silver-coloured fish.\n
used to say that the same is also true of you\n

voca.means_ko:
[쌩션]
제재, 처벌, 벌칙, 
허가, 인가, 지지
인정하다, 용인하다
처벌하다, 제재를 가하다
voca.means_en:
If someone in authority sanctions an action or practice, they officially approve of it and allow it to be done.
If a country or an authority sanctions another country or a person for doing something, it declares that the country or person is guilty of doing it and imposes sanctions on them.
Sanctions are measures taken by countries to restrict trade and official contact with a country that has broken international law.
A sanction is a severe course of action which is intended to make people obey instructions, customs, or laws.

voca.means_ko: [쎈d]\n모래, 모래받, 모래사장\n~을 모래로 닦다, 사포로 닦다
voca.means_en:
coast / beach / seaside / coastline / shoreline / sand / seashore
Sand is a substance that looks like powder, and consists of extremely small pieces of stone. Some deserts and many beaches are made up of sand.
Sands are a large area of sand, for example a beach.
If you sand a wood or metal surface, you rub sandpaper over it in order to make it smooth or clean.
a ridge of sand in a river or sea, built up by the action of tides, currents, etc, and often exposed at low tide\n

Someone who is sane is able to think and behave normally and reasonably, and is not mentally ill.\nIf you refer to a sane person, action, or system, you mean one that you think is reasonable and sensible.\n

voca.means_ko: [쎄니타이z]\n불쾌한 부분을 제거하다, 건전하게 보이도록 하다\n위생처리하다, 살균하다
voca.means_en: To sanitize an activity or a situation that is unpleasant or unacceptable means to describe it in a way that makes it seem more pleasant or more acceptable.\n
A sarcophagus is a large decorative container in which a dead body was placed in ancient times.\n

voca.means_ko: [쎄디s풱션]\n만족, 충족\n(불만, 부채, 부상 등에 대한) 배상/보상
voca.means_en:
satisfaction / happiness / contentment / fulfilment / glee
Satisfaction is the pleasure that you feel when you do something or get something that you wanted or needed to do or get.
If you get satisfaction from someone, you get money or an apology from them because you have been treated badly.
If you do something to someone's satisfaction, they are happy with the way that you have done it.
Something that is satisfactory is acceptable to you or fulfils a particular need or purpose.\n

Saturation is the process or state that occurs when a place or thing is filled completely with people or things, so that no more can be added.\nSaturation is used to describe a campaign or other activity that is carried out very thoroughly, so that nothing is missed.\n
Saturday is the day after Friday and before Sunday.\n

one of the giant planets, the sixth planet from the sun, around which revolve planar concentric rings (Saturn's rings) consisting of small frozen particles. The planet has at least 30 satellites. Mean distance from sun: 1425 million km; period of revolution around sun: 29.41 years; period of axial rotation: 10.23 hours; equatorial diameter and mass: 9.26 and 95.3 times that of the earth, respectively See also Titan\n
A sauce is a thick liquid which is served with other food.\n
A saucer is a small curved plate on which you stand a cup.\n

voca.means_ko:
[싸뷔쥐]
야만적인, 흉포한, 몹시 사나운
(비판 등이) 맹렬한, 사나운, 미개한
미개인, 야만인, 포악한 사람
(심한 상처를 입히며) 흉포하게/모참히 공격하다
voca.means_en:
Someone or something that is savage is extremely cruel, violent, and uncontrolled.
If you refer to people as savages, you dislike them because you think that they do not have an advanced society and are violent.
If someone is savaged by a dog or other animal, the animal attacks them violently.
If someone or something that they have done is savaged by another person, that person criticizes them severely.

voca.means_ko:
[쎄이v]
(죽음, 손상, 손실 등에서) 구하다, 저축하다, 절약하다, 
저장하다
선방, 득점 차단
~외에, ~을 제외하고
voca.means_en:
save / budget / economize / tighten your belt / scrimp
save / rescue / bail out / redeem
If you save someone or something, you help them to avoid harm or to escape from a dangerous or unpleasant situation.
If you save, you gradually collect money by spending less than you get, usually in order to buy something that you want.
If you save something such as time or money, you prevent the loss or waste of it.
If you save something, you keep it because it will be needed later.
If someone or something saves you from an unpleasant action or experience, they change the situation so that you do not have to do it or experience it.
If you save data in a computer, you give the computer an instruction to store the data on a tape or disk.
If a goalkeeper saves, or saves a shot, they succeed in preventing the ball from going into the goal.
to use less of something or not more than necessary\n
to keep your money instead of spending it, especially because you want to buy a particular thing\n
do not waste your time speaking to somebody because they will not listen to your comments, advice, suggestions, etc\n

A saw is a tool for cutting wood, which has a blade with sharp teeth along one edge. Some saws are pushed backwards and forwards by hand, and others are powered by electricity.\nIf you saw something, you cut it with a saw.\n
to cut something down and bring it to the ground, using a saw\n
to remove something from something by cutting it with a saw\n
to cut something into pieces using a saw\n

A saying is a sentence that people often say and that gives advice or information about human life and experience.\nThe sayings of a person, especially a religious or political leader, are important things that they said or pieces of advice that they gave.\n

voca.means_ko: (저울로) 달 수 있는\n확장, 축소하여도 난조가 생기지 않는
voca.means_en: capable of being scaled or climbed\n(of a network) able to be expanded to cope with increased use\n

voca.means_ko:
[s께일]
(특히 다른것과 비교해서 본) 규모,/범위 등급, 척도, 
저울, 축척, 비늘
(아주 높고 가파른곳에) 오르다
비늘을 치다/벗기다
치석을 제거하다
voca.means_en:
If you refer to the scale of something, you are referring to its size or extent, especially when it is very big.
A scale is a set of levels or numbers which are used in a particular system of measuring things or are used when comparing things.
A pay scale or scale of fees is a list that shows how much someone should be paid, depending, for example, on their age or what work they do.
The scale of a map, plan, or model is the relationship between the size of something in the map, plan, or model and its size in the real world.
In music, a scale is a fixed sequence of musical notes, each one higher than the next, which begins at a particular note.
A scale model or scale replica of a building or object is a model of it which is smaller than the real thing but has all the same parts and features.
If you scale something such as a mountain or a wall, you climb up it or over it.
cut / slash / cut back / scale back / downsize / downsize\n
to reduce something in size or importance\n
to increase the size or importance of something\n
Scallops are large shellfish with two flat fan-shaped shells. Scallops can be eaten.\n

Your scalp is the skin under the hair on your head.
A scalp is the piece of skin and hair that is removed when someone is scalped.
To scalp someone means to remove the skin and hair from the top of their head.
If someone scalps tickets, they sell them outside a sports ground or theatre, usually for more than their original value.

A scaly animal has small pieces of hard skin covering its body.
If someone's skin is scaly, it has dry areas and small pieces of it come off.
It was cold and scaly. It wiggled and jerked!
A scam is an illegal trick, usually with the purpose of getting money from people or avoiding paying tax.\n

voca.means_ko:
[s껨뻐r]
날쌔게 움직이다, 허둥지둥 도망치다, 대충 훑어보다
뛰어놀다, 날쌔게 움직이다
질주, 도주, 급히 읽기
voca.means_en: When people or small animals scamper somewhere, they move there quickly with small, light steps.\nThe mouse scampered away.

voca.means_ko: ~을 자세히 살피다, 훑어보다\n죽 흝어보기, 면밀한 검사
겨우, 가까스로, 거의 ~ 아닌, 아마(절대) ~ 아닌
voca.means_en:
hardly / scarcely / barely / no sooner
You use scarcely to emphasize that something is only just true or only just the case.
You can use scarcely to say that something is not true or is not the case, in a humorous or critical way.
If you say scarcely had one thing happened when something else happened, you mean that the first event was followed immediately by the second.

frighten / scare / alarm / intimidate / startle
If something scares you, it frightens or worries you.
If a sudden unpleasant experience gives you a scare, it frightens you.
A scare is a situation in which many people are afraid or worried because they think something dangerous is happening which will affect them all.
A bomb scare or a security scare is a situation in which there is believed to be a bomb in a place.
to accidentally make somebody afraid of or nervous about something they are planning to do\n
to find somebody/something or to make something by using whatever is available\n
A scarf is a piece of cloth that you wear round your neck or head, usually to keep yourself warm.\n
They had black scarves over their faces.\n
Something that is scary is rather frightening.\n

voca.means_ko: [s께러r]\n(흩)뿌리기, 살포, 흩어지는 것\n~을 뿌리다, 흩뜨리다, 쫓아버리다
voca.means_en:
If you scatter things over an area, you throw or drop them so that they spread all over the area.
If a group of people scatter or if you scatter them, they suddenly separate and move in different directions.
Annie sat in the shadows, Boos were scattered everywhere.

voca.means_ko: [s께러r-d]\n드문드문 있는, 산재한, 산발적인, \n뿌려진, 흩어져 있는, 산만한
voca.means_en: Scattered things are spread over an area in an untidy or irregular way.\nIf something is scattered with a lot of small things, they are spread all over it.\n

voca.means_ko: [시네뤼어]\n(미래에 가능한 일을 묘사한) 시나리오\n(영화 등의) 시나리오, 각본
voca.means_en: If you talk about a likely or possible scenario, you are talking about the way in which a situation may develop.\nThe scenario of a film is a piece of writing that gives an outline of the story.\n

voca.means_ko:
[씨인]
(특히 좋지 못한 일이 일어난) 현장, 
(특정한 일이 벌어지는) 장면,
 경치, 무대, 풍경, 풍경화, 풍경 사진
voca.means_en:
place / site / position / location / scene / spot / venue
A scene in a play, film, or book is part of it in which a series of events happen in the same place.
You refer to a place as a scene when you are describing its appearance and indicating what impression it makes on you.
You can describe an event that you see, or that is broadcast or shown in a picture, as a scene of a particular kind.
You can refer to an area of activity as a particular type of scene.
If you make a scene, you embarrass people by publicly showing your anger about something.

country / landscape / countryside / terrain / land / scenery
The scenery in a country area is the land, water, or plants that you can see around you.
In a theatre, the scenery consists of the structures and painted backgrounds that show where the action in the play takes place.

voca.means_ko: [쎕더r]\n(왕이 지나는) 홀, 왕권, 왕위\n왕위에 앉히다, ~에게 왕권을 주다

voca.means_en:
agenda / diary / schedule / timetable
A schedule is a plan that gives a list of events or tasks and the times at which each one should happen or be done.
You can use schedule to refer to the time or way something is planned to be done. For example, if something is completed on schedule, it is completed at the time planned.
A schedule is a written list of things, for example a list of prices, details, or conditions.
A schedule is a list of all the times when trains, boats, buses, or aircraft are supposed to arrive at or leave a particular place.
In a school or college, a schedule is a diagram that shows the times in the week at which particular subjects are taught.
If something is scheduled to happen at a particular time, arrangements are made for it to happen at that time.

voca.means_ko: [s끼임]\n계획, 기획, 음모, 조직, 설계\n~하려고 꾸미다, 구상/계획하다
voca.means_en:
A scheme is a plan or arrangement involving many people which is made by a government or other organization.
A scheme is someone's plan for achieving something.
If you say that people are scheming, you mean that they are making secret plans in order to gain something for themselves.

voca.means_ko: 바보, 멍청이, 세상 물정을 모르는 얼간이

voca.means_en: A scholar is a person who studies an academic subject and knows a lot about it.\n

A school is a place where children are educated. You usually refer to this place as school when you are talking about the time that children spend there and the activities that they do there.\nIf you school someone in something, you train or educate them to have a certain skill, type of behaviour, or way of thinking.\n
In the study of language, schwa is the name of the neutral vowel sound represented by the symbol in this dictionary.\n

voca.means_ko: 비웃다, 놀리다, 조롱하다, (많은 양을 급히) 먹어 치우다\n비웃음, 조롱
voca.means_en: Jack scoffed.\n

voca.means_ko:

국자, 작은 삽, 숟갈, 스쿠프,

voca.means_en:
If you scoop a person or thing somewhere, you put your hands or arms under or round them and quickly move them there.
If you scoop something from a container, you remove it with something such as a spoon.
If a newspaper scoops other newspapers, it succeeds in printing an exciting or important story before they do.
If you scoop a prize or award, you win it.
A scoop is an object like a spoon which is used for picking up a quantity of a food such as ice cream or an ingredient such as flour.
You can use scoop to refer to an exciting news story which is reported in one newspaper or on one television programme before it appears anywhere else.
She scooped up the mouse.
If you scoot somewhere, you go there very quickly.\n
to move along on a seat to make room for another person\n
If there is scope for a particular kind of behaviour or activity, people have the opportunity to behave in this way or do that activity.\n

voca.means_ko: [s꺄울]\n노려보다, 쏘아보다. 얼굴을 찌뿌리다, 험악해 지다\n찡그린 얼굴, (날씨 등이) 험악해짐
voca.means_en: When someone scowls, an angry or hostile expression appears on their face.\n

voca.means_ko: 무서운 얼굴로 위합하다\n노려보아 입을 다물게 하다

[sk뤰블]
(특히 힘겹게 손으로 몸을 지탱하며) 재빨리 움직이다,
(여러 사람이 경쟁하듯) 서로 밀치다, 앞다투다, 
기어오르다, 앞을 다투다, ~을 마두 뒤섞다
기어오르기, 긴급발진
voca.means_en:
If you scramble over rocks or up a hill, you move quickly over them or up it using your hands to help you.
If you scramble to a different place or position, you move there in a hurried, awkward way.
If a number of people scramble for something, they compete energetically with each other for it.
If you scramble eggs, you break them, mix them together and then heat and stir the mixture in a pan.
If a device scrambles a radio or telephone message, it interferes with the sound so that the message can only be understood by someone with special equipment.

voca.means_ko:

폐기하다, 버리다, 싸우다, 다투다
voca.means_en:
A scrap of something is a very small piece or amount of it.
Scraps are pieces of unwanted food which are thrown away or given to animals.
Scrap is metal from old or damaged machinery or cars.
If you scrap something, you get rid of it or cancel it.
Scrap metal or paper is no longer wanted for its original purpose, but may have some other use.

voca.means_ko:

voca.means_en:
If you scrape something from a surface, you remove it, especially by pulling a sharp object over the surface.
If something scrapes against something else or if someone or something scrapes something else, it rubs against it, making a noise or causing slight damage.
If you scrape a part of your body, you accidentally rub it against something hard and rough, and damage it slightly.
Cro-Magnons scraped reindeer skins with flint rocks to make them soft.

to remove something from the inside of something else using something sharp and hard like a knife\nto just manage to make enough money to live\n

the act of scraping
a sound produced by scraping
something scraped off, together, or up; a small amount

voca.means_en:
If you scratch yourself, you rub your fingernails against your skin because it is itching.
If a sharp object scratches someone or something, it makes small shallow cuts on their skin or surface.
Scratches on someone or something are small shallow cuts.
If you do something from scratch, you do it without making use of anything that has been done before.
If you say that someone is scratching their head, you mean that they are thinking hard and trying to solve a problem or puzzle.
If you only scratch the surface of a subject or problem, you find out or do a small amount, but not enough to understand or solve it.
to remove a word, especially a name, from something written, usually by putting a line through it\n

voca.means_en: Scratchy sounds are thin and harsh.\nScratchy clothes or fabrics are rough and uncomfortable to wear next to your skin.\n
If you describe a person or animal as scrawny, you mean that they look unattractive because they are so thin.\n

voca.means_ko:
[s끄뤼임]
(아품, 무서움으로) 비명을 지르다, 
(흥분 등으로) 괴성을 지르다, 
비명, 절규, 환호
voca.means_en:
shout / yell / scream / cheer / cry / call
When someone screams, they make a very loud, high-pitched cry, for example because they are in pain or are very frightened.
If you scream something, you shout it in a loud, high-pitched voice.
When something makes a loud, high-pitched noise, you can say that it screams.

voca.means_ko: (비행기, 폭탄 등이) 쇳소리를 내며 강하하다\n(남에게) 고래고래 소리를 지르다
(화가 나거나 주의를 끌기 위해) 고함 지르다\n(~을) 간절히 필요로 하다, 갈구하다
voca.means_en: to give a loud, high cry, because you are hurt, frightened, etc.\nto be very obvious or noticeable; to demand attention\n

voca.means_en:
If a vehicle screeches somewhere or if its tyres screech, its tyres make an unpleasant high-pitched noise on the road.
When you screech something, you shout it in a loud, unpleasant, high-pitched voice.
When a bird, animal, or thing screeches, it makes a loud, unpleasant, high-pitched noise.
Screeching split the air again.

voca.means_ko: 두루마리\n(석재, 목재에 장식으로 새기는) 소용돌이 무늬
voca.means_en:
A scroll is a long roll of paper or a similar material with writing on it.
A scroll is a painted or carved decoration made to look like a scroll.
If you scroll through text on a computer screen, you move the text up or down to find the information that you need.

voca.means_ko:

(보통 비눗물과 솔로) 문질러 씻다/청소하다, 
(예정했던 일을) 취소하다, 
닦다, 문지르다, 씻다, 제거하다
관목, 덤블, 관목숲, 관목지대
작은, 소형의, 조그마한, 위축된
voca.means_en:
If you scrub something, you rub it hard in order to clean it, using a stiff brush and water.
If you scrub dirt or stains off something, you remove them by rubbing hard.
Scrub consists of low trees and bushes, especially in an area that has very little rain.
