voca.means_en:
Troops are soldiers, especially when they are in a large organized group doing a particular task.

A troop of people or animals is a group of them.
If people troop somewhere, they walk there in a group, often in a sad or tired way.
Tropical means belonging to or typical of the tropics.\nTropical weather is hot and damp weather that people believe to be typical of the tropics.\n

voca.means_en:
If you trot somewhere, you move fairly fast at a speed between walking and running, taking small quick steps.

If something happens several times on the trot, it happens that number of times without a break.
She looked around then trotted back down the hall.
to say or repeat something such as an excuse, an explanation, etc. without thinking about it or being sincere about it\n

seeming real rather than invented\n

You use truly to emphasize that something has all the features or qualities of a particular thing, or is the case to the fullest possible extent.
You can use truly in order to emphasize your description of something.
You use truly to emphasize that feelings are genuine and sincere.
You write Yours truly at the end of a formal letter to someone you do not know very well. You write your signature after the words `Yours truly'.
You can say yours truly as a way of referring to yourself.

make somebody feel impatient\n

to turn on the radio or television in order to listen or watch a programme or channel\nto be aware of, or understand other people's thoughts feelings or needs\n

If you describe someone as a turncoat, you think they are disloyal or deceitful, because they have left their party or organization and joined an opposing one.\n

voca.means_en:
If something happens twice, there are two actions or events of the same kind.
You use twice in expressions such as twice a day and twice a week to indicate that two events or actions of the same kind happen in each day or week.
If one thing is, for example, twice as big or old as another, the first thing is two times as big or old as the second. People sometimes say that one thing is twice as good or hard as another when they want to emphasize that the first thing is much better or harder than the second.
not just once but twice\n

Twilight is the time just before night when the daylight has almost gone but when it is not completely dark.
A twilight state or a twilight zone is a situation of confusion or uncertainty, which seems to exist between two different states or categories.
He led them through the twilight.

If a star or a light twinkles, it shines with an unsteady light which rapidly and constantly changes from bright to faint.
If you say that someone's eyes twinkle, you mean that their face expresses good humour or amusement.

If you twirl something such as your hair, you twist it around your finger.
Jack finished tying his sneakers.\n

If you say that someone or something is ugly, you mean that they are very unattractive and unpleasant to look at.\nIf you refer to an event or situation as ugly, you mean that it is very unpleasant, usually because it involves violent or aggressive behaviour.\n

You use ultimate to describe the final result or aim of a long series of events.
You use ultimate to describe the original source or cause of something.
You use ultimate to describe the most important or powerful thing of a particular kind.
You use ultimate to describe the most extreme and unpleasant example of a particular thing.
You use ultimate to describe the best possible example of a particular thing.
Ultimately means finally, after a long and often complicated series of events.\nYou use ultimately to indicate that what you are saying is the most important point in a discussion.\n

An umbrella is an object which you use to protect yourself from the rain or hot sun. It consists of a long stick with a folding frame covered in cloth.
Umbrella is used to refer to a single group or description that includes a lot of different organizations or ideas.
Umbrella is used to refer to a system or agreement which protects a country or group of people.
If you are unable to do something, it is impossible for you to do it, for example because you do not have the necessary skill or knowledge, or because you do not have enough time or money.\n
When a group of people are unanimous, they all agree about something or all vote for the same thing.\nA unanimous vote, decision, or agreement is one in which all the people involved agree.\n
consisting of, or affecting, a single element or component; monadic\n
If you describe something as unbearable, you mean that it is so unpleasant, painful, or upsetting that you feel unable to accept it or deal with it.\n

voca.means_en:
If you say that something is unbelievable, you are emphasizing that it is very good, impressive, intense, or extreme.
You can use unbelievable to emphasize that you think something is very bad or shocking.
If an idea or statement is unbelievable, it seems so unlikely to be true that you cannot believe it.

If you describe something as uncommon, you mean that it does not happen often or is not often seen.\nIf you describe a quality, usually a good quality, as uncommon, you mean that it is unusually great in degree or amount.\n

Someone who is unconscious is in a state similar to sleep, usually as the result of a serious injury or a lack of oxygen.
If you are unconscious of something, you are unaware of it.
If feelings or attitudes are unconscious, you are not aware that you have them, but they show in the way that you behave.
Your unconscious is the part of your mind that contains feelings and ideas that you do not know about or cannot control.

voca.means_ko: [언커버r]\n덮개를 벗기다, 뚜껑을 열다, 폭로하다, 노출시키다\n(비밀 등을) 알아내다, 적발하다
voca.means_en:
If you uncover something, especially something that has been kept secret, you discover or find out about it.
When people who are digging somewhere uncover something, they find a thing or a place that has been under the ground for a long time.
To uncover something means to remove something that is covering it.
If you describe someone as uncultured, you are critical of them because they do not seem to know much about art, literature, and other cultural topics.\n
If you say that something is undeniable, you mean that it is definitely true.\n

In a place such as a sea, river, or swimming pool, if someone or something is under the water, they are fully in the water and covered by it.
Something that is under a layer of something, especially clothing, is covered by that layer.
You can use under before a noun to indicate that a person or thing is being affected by something or is going through a particular process.

being forced to do something
made to feel anxious about something you have to do

voca.means_en: If you undergo something necessary or unpleasant, it happens to you.\n

In a country which is controlled by an enemy or has a harsh government, the underground is an organized group of people who are involved in illegal activities against the people in power.

voca.means_en: The underlying features of an object, event, or situation are not obvious, and it may be difficult to discover or reveal them.\nYou describe something as underlying when it is below the surface of something else.\n

voca.means_en: Underpants are a piece of underwear which have two holes to put your legs through and elastic around the top to hold them up round your waist or hips. In British English, underpants refers to only men's underwear but in American English it refers to both men's and women's.\n

In addition, the names for data cannot begin with numbers or most non-  alphabet characters (such as commas, plus or minus signs, slashes, and so on), with the exception of the underscore character.\n
Jack and Annie climbed down through the understory.\n
If an activity is under way, it has already started. If an activity gets under way, it starts.\n

voca.means_en:
worried / concerned / nervous / anxious / uneasy
If you are uneasy, you feel anxious, afraid, or embarrassed, because you think that something is wrong or that there is danger.
If you are uneasy about doing something, you are not sure that it is correct or wise.
If you describe a situation or relationship as uneasy, you mean that the situation is not settled and may not last.

voca.means_en:
An uneven surface or edge is not smooth, flat, or straight.
Something that is uneven is not regular or consistent.
If you describe something as uneven, you think it is not very good because it is not consistent in quality.
An uneven system or situation is unfairly arranged or organized.
If an event or someone's behaviour is unexpected, it surprises you because you did not think that it was likely to happen.\n

If you describe someone as unfortunate, you mean that something unpleasant or unlucky has happened to them. You can also describe the unpleasant things that happen to them as unfortunate.
If you describe something that has happened as unfortunate, you think that it is inappropriate, embarrassing, awkward, or undesirable.
You can describe someone as unfortunate when they are poor or have a difficult life.
You can use unfortunately to introduce or refer to a statement when you consider that it is sad or disappointing, or when you want to express regret.\n

A uniform is a special set of clothes which some people, for example soldiers or the police, wear to work in and which some children wear at school.
You can refer to the particular style of clothing which a group of people wear to show they belong to a group or a movement as their uniform.
If something is uniform, it does not vary, but is even and regular throughout.
If you describe a number of things as uniform, you mean that they are all the same.

If you consider something as a unit, you consider it as a single, complete thing.
A unit is a group of people who work together at a specific job, often in a particular place.
A unit is a group within an armed force or police force, whose members fight or work together or carry out a particular task.
A unit is a small machine which has a particular function, often part of a larger machine.
If a group of people or things unite or if something unites them, they join together and act as a group.\n

The universe is the whole of space and all the stars, planets, and other forms of matter and energy in it.\nIf you talk about someone's universe, you are referring to the whole of their experience or an important part of it.\n

voca.means_en: It would be there forever, unless someone moved it.\n

voca.means_en:
If one thing is unlike another thing, the two things have different qualities or characteristics from each other.
You can use unlike to contrast two people, things, or situations, and show how they are different.
If you describe something that a particular person has done as being unlike them, you mean that you are surprised by it because it is not typical of their character or normal behaviour.

If something is unpleasant, it gives you bad feelings, for example by making you feel upset or uncomfortable.\nAn unpleasant person is very unfriendly and rude.\n

If you say that someone is being unreasonable, you mean that they are behaving in a way that is not fair or sensible.\nAn unreasonable decision, action, price, or amount seems unfair and difficult to justify.\n

not appreciated or valued
not assessed or estimated as to price or valuation
of great value

to some extent; not completely\n
at the good standard that is expected or needed\n

If you are sitting or standing upright, you are sitting or standing with your back straight, rather than bending or lying down.
An upright vacuum cleaner or freezer is tall rather than wide.
An upright chair has a straight back and no arms.
You can describe people as upright when they are careful to follow acceptable rules of behaviour and behave in a moral way.
You can refer to vertical posts or the vertical parts of an object as uprights.

If you are upset, you are unhappy or disappointed because something unpleasant has happened to you.
If something upsets you, it makes you feel worried or unhappy.
If events upset something such as a procedure or a state of affairs, they cause it to go wrong.
If you upset an object, you accidentally knock or push it over so that it scatters over a large area.
A stomach upset is a slight illness in your stomach caused by an infection or by something that you have eaten.

If you go upstairs in a building, you go up a staircase towards a higher floor.
If something or someone is upstairs in a building, they are on a floor that is higher than the ground floor.
An upstairs room or object is situated on a floor of a building that is higher than the ground floor.
The upstairs of a building is the floor or floors that are higher than the ground floor.
Something that is moving upstream is moving towards the source of a river, from a point further down the river. Something that is upstream is towards the source of a river.\n
Someone who is uptight is tense, nervous, or annoyed about something and so is difficult to be with.\n

one of the giant planets, the seventh planet from the sun, sometimes visible to the naked eye. It has about 15 satellites, a ring system, and an axis of rotation almost lying in the plane of the orbit. Mean distance from sun: 2870 million km; period of revolution around sun: 84 years; period of axial rotation: 17.23 hours; diameter and mass: 4 and 14.5 times that of earth respectively\n
Urban means belonging to, or relating to, a town or city.\n
An urchin is a young child who is dirty and poorly dressed.\n
If something is urgent, it needs to be dealt with as soon as possible.\nIf you speak in an urgent way, you show that you are anxious for people to notice something or to do something.\n

voca.means_en: If something is usable, it is in a good enough state or condition to be used.\n

Usage is the way in which words are actually used in particular contexts, especially with regard to their meanings.
A usage is a meaning that a word has or a way in which it can be used.
Usage is the degree to which something is used or the way in which it is used.

voca.means_ko: [유-z]\n사용하다, 쓰다, 소비하다, 이용하다\n사용, 이용, 쓰임새, 사용하기, 사용방법
voca.means_en:
Your use of something is the action or fact of your using it.

If something has a particular use, it is intended for a particular purpose.
If you have the use of something, you have the permission or ability to use it.
to use all of something until no more is left\n
If something is useful, you can use it to do something or to help you in some way.\n

If something is useless, you cannot use it.
If something is useless, it does not achieve anything helpful or good.
If you say that someone or something is useless, you mean that they are no good at all.
If someone feels useless, they feel bad because they are unable to help someone or achieve anything.
Usual is used to describe what happens or what is done most often in a particular situation.\n

voca.means_en: If you vacate a place or a job, you leave it or give it up, making it available for other people.\n

voca.means_en:
If something written or spoken is vague, it does not explain or express things clearly.

If you describe someone as vague, you mean that they do not seem to be thinking clearly.
If something such as a feeling is vague, you experience it only slightly.
A vague shape or outline is not clear and is therefore not easy to see.

A vain attempt or action is one that fails to achieve what was intended.
If you describe a hope that something will happen as a vain hope, you mean that there is no chance of it happening.
If you describe someone as vain, you are critical of their extreme pride in their own beauty, intelligence, or other good qualities.

A valid argument, comment, or idea is based on sensible reasoning.
Something that is valid is important or serious enough to make it worth saying or doing.
If a ticket or other document is valid, it can be used and will be accepted by people in authority.

voca.means_en: A vampire is a creature in legends and horror stories. Vampires are said to come out of graves at night and suck the blood of living people.\n

voca.means_en: If someone or something vanishes, they disappear suddenly or in a way that cannot be explained.\nIf something such as a species of animal or a tradition vanishes, it stops existing.\n
The mouse vanished into the tall grass on the other side of the stream.\n

Something that is written or spoken in a particular vein is written or spoken in that style or mood.
A vein of a particular quality is evidence of that quality which someone often shows in their behaviour or work.
A vein of a particular metal or mineral is a layer of it lying in rock.
The veins on a leaf are the thin lines on it.
Velvet is soft material made from cotton, silk, or nylon, which has a thick layer of short cut threads on one side.\n

Someone or something that is vibrant is full of life, energy, and enthusiasm.

At night, they quietly bite their victims and suck their blood.

A victory is a success in a struggle, war, or competition.\nIf you say that someone has won a moral victory, you mean that although they have officially lost a contest or dispute, they have succeeded in showing they are right about something.\n

Your views on something are the beliefs or opinions that you have about it, for example whether you think it is good, bad, right, or wrong.
Your view of a particular subject is the way that you understand and think about it.
The view from a window or high place is everything which can be seen from that place, especially when it is considered to be beautiful.
If you have a view of something, you can see it.
You use view in expressions to do with being able to see something. For example, if something is in view, you can see it. If something is in full view of everyone, everyone can see it.

Vintage cars or aeroplanes are old but are admired because they are considered to be the best of their kind.
You can use vintage to describe something which is the best and most typical of its kind.

Violence is behaviour which is intended to hurt, injure, or kill people.\nIf you do or say something with violence, you use a lot of force and energy in doing or saying it, often because you are angry.\n

If someone is violent, or if they do something which is violent, they use physical force or weapons to hurt, injure, or kill other people.
A violent event happens suddenly and with great force.
If you describe something as violent, you mean that it is said, done, or felt very strongly.

A violet is a small plant that has purple or white flowers in the spring.

A virgin is someone who has never had sex.

You use virgin to describe something such as land that has never been used or spoiled.
If you say that a situation is virgin territory, you mean that you have no experience of it and it is completely new for you.

Visibility means how far or how clearly you can see in particular weather conditions.\nIf you refer to the visibility of something such as a situation or problem, you mean how much it is seen or noticed by other people.\n

to spend time with somebody talking in an informal and casual way\n

bright / brilliant / fluorescent / luminous / vivid / vibrant

If you vomit, food and drink comes back up from your stomach and out through your mouth.\nVomit is partly digested food and drink that has come back up from someone's stomach and out through their mouth.\n

election / vote / poll / referendum / straw poll / ballot / show of hands
A vote is a choice made by a particular person or group in a meeting or an election.
A vote is an occasion when a group of people make a decision by each person indicating his or her choice. The choice that most people support is accepted by the group.
The vote is the total number of votes or voters in an election, or the number of votes received or cast by a particular group.
If you have the vote in an election, or have a vote in a meeting, you have the legal right to indicate your choice.
When you vote, you indicate your choice officially at a meeting or in an election, for example by raising your hand or writing on a piece of paper.

A vowel is a sound such as the ones represented in writing by the letters 'a', 'e' 'I', 'o' and 'u', which you pronounce with your mouth open, allowing the air to flow through it. Compare consonant.\n

voca.means_en:
Someone who is vulnerable is weak and without protection, with the result that they are easily hurt physically or emotionally.
If a person, animal, or plant is vulnerable to a disease, they are more likely to get it than other people, animals, or plants.
Something that is vulnerable can be easily harmed or affected by something bad.

A vulture is a large bird which lives in hot countries and eats the flesh of dead animals.\nIf you describe a person as a vulture, you disapprove of them because you think they are trying to gain from another person's troubles.\n

voca.means_ko:
[워d]
(종이등의) 뭉치, 다발
(단단한 덩어리게 되게) 뭉치다, 뭉치로 만들다, 
채워넣다
voca.means_en: A wad of something such as paper or cloth is a tight bundle or ball of it.
To waddle somewhere means to walk there with short, quick steps, swinging slightly from side to side. A person or animal that waddles usually has short legs and a fat body.\n

If you wade through something that makes it difficult to walk, usually water or mud, you walk through it.
To wade through a lot of documents or pieces of information means to spend a lot of time and effort reading them or dealing with them.
Jack watched her wade into the water. / They started wading across.

voca.means_ko: (싸움, 논쟁, 토론 등 속으로) 마구 뛰어들다, 덤벼들다
voca.means_en: to get involved in a discussion, an argument, a difficult situation, etc. in a determined and not very sensitive way\n

voca.means_ko:
[웨-g]
(개가 꼬리를) 흔들다, (개의 꼬리가) 흔들리다
(흔히 불만스럽다는 뜻으로 손가락, 머리를) 흔들다
(학교를) 빼먹다, 땡땡이치다
voca.means_en:
When a dog wags its tail, it repeatedly waves its tail from side to side.
If you wag your finger, you shake it repeatedly and quickly from side to side, usually because you are annoyed with someone.
If you wag your head, you move it from side to side, often because you are unhappy about a situation.

voca.means_ko:
[웨읠]
(슬픔, 통증 때문에) 울부짖다, 통곡하다, 흐느끼다
(길고 높은) 소리를 내다/울리다
몹시 비통해 하다, 탄식하다
울부짖음, 통곡
voca.means_en:
If someone wails, they make long, loud, high-pitched cries which express sorrow or pain.
If you wail something, you say it in a loud, high-pitched voice that shows that you are unhappy or in pain.
If something such as a siren or an alarm wails, it makes a long, loud, high-pitched sound.
"I can't see them anymore!" wailed Annie.
Your waist is the middle part of your body where it narrows slightly above your hips.\nIt went up to the short ninja's waist.

wake - woke - woken
When you wake or when someone or something wakes you, you become conscious again after being asleep.
The wake of a boat or other object moving in water is the track of waves that it makes behind it as it moves through the water.
A wake is a gathering or social event that is held before or after someone's funeral.
If one thing follows in the wake of another, it happens after the other thing is over, often as a result of it.

voca.means_ko: ~에게 정신이 들게 하다, 활기를 불어 넣다

voca.means_en:
awake / awaken / wake up / waken
to stop sleeping; to make somebody stop sleeping
to become, or to make somebody, more lively and interested
to become conscious again
to become aware of something; to realize something\n

voca.means_ko:
[웍k]
걷다, 걸어가다, 
(걸어서) 바래다주다, (동물을) 걷게 하다/산책시키다
걷기, 산책, 걸음걸이
voca.means_en:
When you walk, you move forward by putting one foot in front of the other in a regular way.
If you walk someone somewhere, you walk there with them in order to show politeness or to make sure that they get there safely.
If you walk your dog, you take it for a walk in order to keep it healthy.
A walk is a journey that you make by walking, usually for pleasure.
A walk of a particular distance is the distance which a person has to walk to get somewhere.
to leave a difficult or unpleasant situation in order to avoid it, instead of staying to deal with it\nif you walk away from an accident, etc., you are not seriously injured\n

voca.means_ko: (특히 주의 부족으로 나쁜 상황에) 빠지다\n(일자리를) 쉽게 얻다,
voca.means_en: to become caught in something that you are not expecting, especially because you are not careful\nto succeed in getting a job without having to make an effort\n
to leave a place or a person suddenly because you are angry or upset\n

to leave a meeting, a performance, etc. suddenly before the end, because you do not like it or are angry
to stop working and go on strike
to leave somebody you have a close relationship with and a responsibility for

voca.means_ko: (회의, 공연 등을 하던 중에 특히 불만을 나타내기 위해)\n나가 버리다, 떠나 버리다
voca.means_en:
to leave a meeting, a performance, etc. suddenly before the end, because you do not like it or are angry
to stop working and go on strike
to leave somebody you have a close relationship with and a responsibility for
to treat somebody badly and not consider their wishes or feelings\nto defeat somebody easily in a competition\n

voca.means_ko: ~으로 부른 배를 산책하여 꺼지게 하다, 소화시키다
voca.means_en: to go for a walk in order to get rid of the feeling that you have eaten too much or an emotion such as anger\n

voca.means_ko: (자신이 무엇을 정말 잘 한다는 것을)\n실지로 행동으로 보여 주다

voca.means_en: to approach somebody/something in a confident way\n

A wall is one of the vertical sides of a building or room.
A wall is a long narrow vertical structure made of stone or brick that surrounds or divides an area of land.
The wall of something that is hollow is its side.
You can describe something as a wall of a particular kind when it acts as a barrier and prevents people from understanding something.
to keep somebody as a prisoner in a place surrounded by walls\n
to build a wall or a barrier around an area to separate it from another area\n
to block a space with bricks or a wall so that it can no longer be used\n
A wallet is a small flat folded case, usually made of leather or plastic, in which you can keep banknotes and credit cards.\n
A wand is the same as a magic wand.\n

voca.means_ko:
[완더r]
(이리저리 천천히) 거닐다, 돌아다니다, 헤매다,
있어야 할 곳에서 다른데로 가다,
돌아다니다, 배회하다, 헤매다
산만해지다, (다른데로) 쏠리다
voca.means_en:
If you wander in a place, you walk around there in a casual way, often without intending to go in any particular direction.
If a person or animal wanders from a place where they are supposed to stay, they move away from the place without going in a particular direction.
If your mind wanders or your thoughts wander, you stop concentrating on something and start thinking about other things.
AT the end of the 1800s, Over a million wild horses, called mustangs, wandered the West.

campaign / battle / struggle / drive / war / fight
A war is a period of fighting or conflict between countries or states.
War is intense economic competition between countries or organizations.
If you make war on someone or something that you are opposed to, you do things to stop them succeeding

voca.means_ko: [우워-d]\n병동, 병실, 큰 방, (성 안쪽의) 빈터\n(위험, 타격 등을) 피하다, 받아넘기다, 막다, 물리치다
voca.means_en:
A ward is a room in a hospital which has beds for many people, often people who need similar treatment.
A ward is a district which forms part of a political constituency or local council.
A ward or a ward of court is a child who is the responsibility of a person called a guardian, or of a court of law, because their parents are dead or because they are believed to be in need of protection.
A warehouse is a large building where raw materials or manufactured goods are stored until they are exported to other countries or distributed to shops to be sold.\n
Warfare is the activity of fighting a war.\nWarfare is sometimes used to refer to any violent struggle or conflict.\n

If you describe a leader of a country or organization as a warlord, you are critical of them because they have achieved power by behaving in an aggressive and violent way.\nSometimes warlords hired them to be spies.\n

Something that is warm has some heat but not enough to be hot.
Warm clothes and blankets are made of a material such as wool which protects you from the cold.
Warm colours have red or yellow in them rather than blue or green, and make you feel comfortable and relaxed.
A warm person is friendly and shows a lot of affection or enthusiasm in their behaviour.
If you warm a part of your body or if something hot warms it, it stops feeling cold and starts to feel hotter.

voca.means_ko: (스포츠나 활동 전에) 몸을 천천히 풀다, 준비운동하다\n(잘 작동될 수 있도록) 적당히 열이 오르다
voca.means_en:
to become warmer
to do gentle exercise or practice to prepare for exercise, a performance, etc.
to run for a short time in order to reach the temperature at which it will operate well

If you warn someone about something such as a possible danger or problem, you tell them about it so that they are aware of it.\nIf you warn someone not to do something, you advise them not to do it so that they can avoid possible danger or punishment.\n
to tell a person, a ship, an aircraft, etc. not to come near a place because it is dangerous\n

voca.means_ko: ~에게 접근하지 말라고 / ~을 떠나라고 경고하다\n~에게 (~하지 말라고) 경고하다
voca.means_en: to tell somebody to leave or not to come near a place, often in a threatening way\nto advise somebody not to do something or to stop doing something\n
A warrior is a fighter or soldier, especially one in former times who was very brave and experienced in fighting.\n

clean / wash / rinse / cleanse / dry-clean / bathe
If you wash something, you clean it using water and usually a substance such as soap or detergent.
Everything seemed washed with silver.
If you wash or if you wash part of your body, especially your hands and face, you clean part of your body using soap and water.
If a sea or river washes somewhere, it flows there gently. You can also say that something carried by a sea or river washes or is washed somewhere.
The wash of a boat is the wave that it causes on either side as it moves through the water.

voca.means_ko: 조수가 차다, 밀물이 되다\n(파도가) ~을 해안쪽으로 나르다\n(그림) ~을 (배경 따위에) 그려 넣다

voca.means_en: to be removed from clothes, etc. by washing; to remove something in this way\n
to be removed from a fabric, hair, etc. by washing; to remove something in this way\n
to suddenly affect somebody very strongly\nto happen all around somebody without affecting them\n
to suddenly affect somebody very strongly\nto happen all around somebody without affecting them\n
if water, a wave, etc. washes somebody/something away, it removes or carries them/it away to another place\n

voca.means_ko: 낭비하다, 쇠약하다\n낭비, 허비, 쓰레기\n사용되지 않은, 미개발의

(시간, 관심을 기울이며) 보다, 지켜보다, 주시하다
(잠깐동안) 봐주다 
조심하다
(손목에 차는) 시계, 감시, 망 보기, 주시, 불침번
voca.means_en:
look / watch / see / view / observe/ regard
If you watch someone or something, you look at them, usually for a period of time, and pay attention to what is happening.
If you watch something on television or an event such as a sports match, you spend time looking at it, especially when you see it from the beginning to the end.
If you watch a situation or event, you pay attention to it or you are aware of it, but you do not influence it.
A watch is a period of carefully looking and listening, often while other people are asleep and often as a military duty, so that you can warn them of danger or an attack.
to look and wait for something to happen or for somebody to come\n
used to warn somebody about something dangerous\n

Water is a clear thin liquid that has no colour or taste when it is pure. It falls from clouds as rain and enters rivers and seas. All animals and people need water in order to live.
You use waters to refer to a large area of sea, especially the area of sea which is near to a country and which is regarded as belonging to it.
You sometimes use waters to refer to a situation which is very complex or difficult.
If you water plants, you pour water over them in order to help them to grow.

voca.means_ko: ~에 물을타서 희석시키다\n(연설, 글 등을) 약간 부드럽게 조절하다
voca.means_en: to make a liquid weaker by adding water\nto change something such as a speech, a piece of writing, etc. to make it less strong and less likely to offend people\n

Something which is waterproof does not let water pass through it.
Waterproofs are items of clothing which do not let water in.
If something is waterproofed, it is treated so that water cannot pass through it or damage it.

Something that is watertight does not allow water to pass through it, for example because it is tightly sealed.\nA watertight case, argument, or agreement is one that has been so carefully put together that nobody will be able to find a fault in it.\n

voca.means_ko:
[웨이v]
물결치다, 흔들리다, 흔들다, 펄럭이다
(손, 팔을) 흔들다, 손짓하다
파도, 유행
(팔, 손, 몸을) 흔들기
voca.means_en:
If you wave or wave your hand, you move your hand from side to side in the air, usually in order to say hello or goodbye to someone.
If you wave someone away or wave them on, you make a movement with your hand to indicate that they should move in a particular direction.
If you wave something, you hold it up and move it rapidly from side to side.
If something waves, it moves gently from side to side or up and down.
A wave is a raised mass of water on the surface of water, especially the sea, which is caused by the wind or by tides making the surface of the water rise and fall.
If someone's hair has waves, it curves slightly instead of being straight.
to wave goodbye to somebody as they leave\n
Wavy hair is not straight or curly, but curves slightly.\nA wavy line has a series of regular curves along it.\n

voca.means_ko:
[웨이]
방법, 방식, 태도, 
(어떤곳에 으르는) 길, 방향,
지역, 구역, 상황, 조건
저쪽으로, 아주 멀리, 큰 차이로, 훨씬
voca.means_en:
If you refer to a way of doing something, you are referring to how you can do it, for example the action you can take or the method you can use to achieve it.
If you talk about the way someone does something, you are talking about the qualities their action has.
If a general statement or description is true in a particular way, this is the form of it that is true in a particular case.
You use way in expressions such as in some ways, in many ways, and in every way to indicate the degree or extent to which a statement is true.
a long time ago\n

A way of life is the behaviour and habits that are typical of a particular person or group, or that are chosen by them.\nIf you describe a particular activity as a way of life for someone, you mean that it has become a very important and regular thing in their life, rather than something they do or experience occasionally.\n
used to tell somebody that you are pleased about something they have done\n

If someone is weak, they are not healthy or do not have good muscles, so that they cannot move quickly or carry heavy things.
If someone has an organ or sense that is weak, it is not very effective or powerful, or is likely to fail.
If you describe someone as weak, you mean that they are not very confident or determined, so that they are often frightened or worried, or easily influenced by other people.
If you describe someone's voice or smile as weak, you mean that it not very loud or big, suggesting that the person lacks confidence, enthusiasm, or physical strength.
If an object or surface is weak, it breaks easily and cannot support a lot of weight or resist a lot of strain.

voca.means_ko: [위-k니s]\n(힘, 세력, 각오 등이) 약한 힘이 없음, 나약한, \n약점, 부진, 결함, 결점
voca.means_en: If you have a weakness for something, you like it very much, although this is perhaps surprising or undesirable.\n

Wealth is the possession of a large amount of money, property, or other valuable things. You can also refer to a particular person's money or property as their wealth.\nIf you say that someone or something has a wealth of good qualities or things, you are emphasizing that they have a very large number or amount of them.\n
rich / wealthy / prosperous / affluent / well off / comfortable\nSomeone who is wealthy has a large amount of money, property, or valuable possessions.\n

A weapon is an object such as a gun, a knife, or a missile, which is used to kill or hurt people in a fight or a war.\nA weapon is something such as knowledge about a particular subject, which you can use to protect yourself or to get what you want in a difficult situation.\n

voca.means_ko:
[웨어r]
(옷, 모자, 장갑, 신발, 장신구 등을) 입다, 쓰다
(어떤 표정을) 짓고있다, 띠고 있다
닳다, 낡다, 해어지다
착용, 의류
voca.means_en:
wear - wore - worn
clothes / clothing / garment / dress / wear / gear
When you wear something such as clothes, shoes, or jewellery, you have them on your body or on part of your body.
If you wear your hair or beard in a particular way, you have it cut or styled in that way.
If you wear a particular expression, that expression is on your face and shows the emotions that you are feeling.
If something wears, it becomes thinner or weaker because it is constantly being used over a long period of time.
You use wear to refer to clothes that are suitable for a certain time or place. For example, evening wear is clothes suitable for the evening.
Wear is the amount or type of use that something has over a period of time.
So footprints will never wear away naturally, not even in a billion years.\n
to become or to make something become, gradually smaller, thinner, etc. by continuously using or rubbing it\n
if a feeling or an effect wears off, it gradually disappears\n
when time wears on, it passes in a way that seems slow\n
to make somebody/something weaker or less determined, especially by continuously attacking or putting pressure on them/it over a period of time\n

voca.means_ko: (인내 등이) 다하다, 여러 번 쓰여 믿기지 않다\n약해지다, 참기/받아들이기 어렵게 되다
voca.means_en: begin to become less; become less interesting or amusing\n

voca.means_ko:
[위-v]
(실로) 짜다, 엮다, (이야기를) 역어내다
(천)짜기, 엮는 법
이리저리 빠져 나가다, 누비며 가다
voca.means_en:
weave - wove - woven
If you weave cloth or a carpet, you make it by crossing threads over and under each other using a frame or machine called a loom.
A particular weave is the way in which the threads are arranged in a cloth or carpet.
He wove his way between the grazing zebras and giraffes as he raced to the river.

voca.means_ko: [위버r]\n베 짜는 사람, 길쌈하는 사람, 직공, 방직공
voca.means_en: A weaver is a person who weaves cloth, carpets, or baskets.\n
Wednesday is the day after Tuesday and before Thursday.\n

voca.means_ko: [위이]\n(크기가) 아주 작은, 조그만한, 아주 이른\n쉬(오줌누기), 쉬를 하다
voca.means_en: Wee means small in size or extent.\nTo wee means to urinate. Wee is an informal word used especially by children.\n

voca.means_ko: [위-d]\n잡초, 잡풀, 수초, 물풀, 담배, 마리화나\n잡초를 뽑다, 제거하다
voca.means_en:
A weed is a wild plant that grows in gardens or fields of crops and prevents the plants that you want from growing properly.
Weed is a plant that grows in water and usually forms a thick floating mass. There are many different kinds of weed.
If you weed an area, you remove the weeds from it.

voca.means_ko: (불필요 하거나 부족한 대상 등을) 제거하다, 뽑아버리다
voca.means_en: to remove or get rid of somebody/something that you do not want from a group of people or things\n
A weekend is Saturday and Sunday.\n

voca.means_ko:
[웨이]
무게가 ~이다, 무게/체중를 달다, 무겁게 누르다
(결정을 내리기 전에) 따져보다, 저울질하다
(의견, 결과에) 영향을 주다, 작용하다
voca.means_en:
If someone or something weighs a particular amount, this amount is how heavy they are.
If you weigh something or someone, you measure how heavy they are.
If you weigh the facts about a situation, you consider them very carefully before you make a decision, especially by comparing the various facts involved.
to make somebody feel anxious or depressed\n
to form an opinion of somebody by watching them or talking to them\n

voca.means_ko:
[웨잇t]
무게, 체중, 무거운 것, 중요성, 가중치
(봉, 추 등을 매달아) 무겁게 하다, 무게를 주다
가중치를 두다
voca.means_en:
The weight of a person or thing is how heavy they are, measured in units such as kilograms, pounds, or tons.
A person's or thing's weight is the fact that they are very heavy.
If you move your weight, you change position so that most of the pressure of your body is on a particular part of your body.
Weights are objects which weigh a known amount and which people lift as a form of exercise.
Weights are metal objects which weigh a known amount and which are used on a set of scales to weigh other things.
You can refer to a heavy object as a weight, especially when you have to lift it.
If you weight something, you make it heavier by adding something to it, for example in order to stop it from moving easily.
to add a weight to something so that it feels very heavy, bends down, sinks, etc.\n
If you describe something or someone as weird, you mean that they are strange.\nListen - that weird sound.

voca.means_ko:
(다정하게) 맞이하다, 환영하다,
기꺼이 받아 들이다
반가운, ~ 해도 좋은
환영
voca.means_en:
If you welcome someone, you greet them in a friendly way when they arrive somewhere.
If you welcome an action, decision, or situation, you approve of it and are pleased that it has occurred.
If you describe something as welcome, you mean that people wanted it and are happy that it has occurred.
If you say that someone is welcome in a particular place, you are encouraging them to go there by telling them that they will be liked and accepted.
If you tell someone that they are welcome to do something, you are encouraging them to do it by telling them that they are allowed to do it.

voca.means_ko:
[웰]
잘, 좋게, 제대로, 충분히, 꽤, 아주, 상당히
우물
건강한, 만족할 만한, 좋은, 온당한, 적절한
(감탄사) 이런, 이거 참, 그래, 좋아, 글쎄
voca.means_en:
You say well to indicate that you are about to say something.
You say well to indicate that you intend or want to carry on speaking.
If you do something well, you do it to a high standard or to a great extent.
If you do something well, you do it thoroughly and completely.

voca.means_ko: 상당한 진척을 이루다\n술이 취한, 골아 떨어진

voca.means_en: if a liquid wells up, it rises to the surface and starts to flow\nif an emotion wells up, you start to feel it very strongly\n

voca.means_ko:
[웻t]
적시다, 축이다
습기, 굿은 날씨, 비
젖은, 비오는, 아직 마르지 않은
voca.means_en:
wet / moist / damp / soaked / drenched / dripping / saturated
If something is wet, it is covered in water, rain, sweat, tears, or another liquid.
If the weather is wet, it is raining.
If something such as paint, ink, or cement is wet, it is not yet dry or solid.
To wet something means to get water or some other liquid over it.
accidentally urinate (= get rid of water from your body) in your underwear\n
Whales are very large mammals that live in the sea.\nIf you say that someone is having a whale of a time, you mean that they are enjoying themselves very much.\n

voca.means_ko:
[왓t]
(의문문에서) 무엇, 몇, 어떤, 무슨, 
얼마만틈, 얼마나
(감탄문에서) 정말/얼마나
voca.means_en:
You use what in questions when you ask for specific information about something that you do not know.
You use what after certain words, especially verbs and adjectives, when you are referring to a situation that is unknown or has not been specified.
You use what at the beginning of a clause in structures where you are changing the order of the information to give special emphasis to something.
You use what in expressions such as what is called and what amounts to when you are giving a description of something.
You use what to indicate that you are talking about the whole of an amount that is available to you.
for what purpose or reason?\n
what would happen if …?\nwhy should I care if …? what does it matter if …?\n
used to say that you are going to do something that you know you should not do\n
because of something or a series of things\n

voca.means_ko: ~인가뭔가\n(이름을 모르거나 정확하지 않은 무엇을 가리킬 때 씀)
voca.means_en: People sometimes say 'and whatnot' or 'or whatnot' after mentioning one or more things, to refer in a vague way to other things which are similar.\n
Wheat is a cereal crop grown for food. Wheat is also used to refer to the grain of this crop, which is usually ground into flour and used to make bread.\n

The wheels of a vehicle are the circular objects which are fixed underneath it and which enable it to move along the ground
A wheel is a circular object which forms a part of a machine, usually a moving part.
The wheel of a car or other vehicle is the circular object that is used to steer it. The wheel is used in expressions to talk about who is driving a vehicle. For example, if someone is at the wheel of a car, they are driving it.
People talk about the wheels of an organization or system to mean the way in which it operates.
If you wheel an object that has wheels somewhere, you push it along.
If something such as a group of animals or birds wheels, it moves in a circle.
If you wheel around, you turn around suddenly where you are standing, often because you are surprised, shocked, or angry.
do a lot of complicated deals in business or politics, often in a dishonest way\n
to produce somebody/something to help you do something, even though they have often been used before\n
A wheelbarrow is a small open cart with one wheel and handles that is used for carrying things, for example in the garden.\n
A wheelchair is a chair with wheels that you use in order to move about in if you cannot walk properly, for example because you are disabled or sick.\n

덮다, 가라앉히다

when it is a case, matter or question of something/of doing something\nwhen it is a question of something\n

voca.means_en: You use whenever to refer to any time or every time that something happens or is true.\nYou use whenever to refer to a time that you do not know or are not sure about.\n

You use where to ask questions about the place something is in, or is coming from or going to.
You use where to ask questions about a situation, a stage in something, or an aspect of something.
You use where after certain words, especially verbs and adjectives, to introduce a clause in which you mention the place in which something is situated or happens.
You use where after certain words, especially verbs and adjectives, to introduce a clause in which you mention a situation, a stage in something, or an aspect of something.
You use where to introduce a clause that contrasts with the other parts of the sentence.

voca.means_en: You use whereas to introduce a comment which contrasts with what is said in the main clause.\n

voca.means_en: Wherein means in which place or thing.\nWherein means in which part or respect.\n

voca.means_en:
You use wherever to indicate that something happens or is true in any place or situation.
You use wherever when you indicate that you do not know where a person or place is.
You use wherever in questions as an emphatic form of `where', usually when you are surprised about something.
You use whether when you are talking about a choice or doubt between two or more alternatives.\nYou use whether to say that something is true in any of the circumstances that you mention.\n

voca.word: whether for good or for evil

voca.means_ko: [윗치]\n(의문문에서) 어느, 어떤, 어느 것, \n어느쪽, 어느것, 그리고 그것은
voca.means_en:
You use which in questions when there are two or more possible answers or alternatives.
You use which to refer to a choice between two or more possible answers or alternatives.
You use which at the beginning of a relative clause when specifying the thing that you are talking about or when giving more information about it.
You use which to refer back to an idea or situation expressed in a previous sentence or sentences, especially when you want to give your opinion about it.
used to talk about distinguishing one person or thing from another\n

voca.means_ko: 어느 쪽이든 ~ 한 것, 누구든 ~ 한 사람\n어느 ~ 이든, 이느 쪽을 ~ 하든
voca.means_en: You use whichever in order to indicate that it does not matter which of the possible alternatives happens or is chosen.\nYou use whichever to specify which of a number of possibilities is the right one or the one you mean.\n

voca.means_ko: 동안, (잛은)시간, 기간\n~하는 동안에, ~ 동안 줄곧, ~과 동시에,\n~에 반하여, ~ 인데도
voca.means_en:
A while is a period of time.
If something happens while something else is happening, the two things are happening at the same time.
If something happens while something else happens, the first thing happens at some point during the time that the second thing is happening.
You use while at the beginning of a clause to introduce information which contrasts with information in the main clause.
You use while, before making a statement, in order to introduce information that partly conflicts with your statement.
If someone whimpers, they make quiet unhappy or frightened sounds, as if they are about to start crying.\nIf someone whimpers something, they say it in an unhappy or frightened way.\n

complain / protest / object / grumble / moan / whine / whinge
If something or someone whines, they make a long, high-pitched noise, especially one which sounds sad or unpleasant.
If you say that someone is whining, you mean that they are complaining in an annoying way about something unimportant.
whined and yelped
When a horse whinnies, it makes a series of high-pitched sounds, usually not very loudly.\nJust them a loud whinny split the air.\n

voca.means_en:
A whip is a long thin piece of material such as leather or rope, fastened to a stiff handle. It is used for hitting people or animals.
A whip is a member of a political party in a parliament or legislature who is responsible for making sure that party members are present to vote on important issues and that they vote in the appropriate way.
If someone whips a person or animal, they beat them or hit them with a whip or something like a whip.
If something, for example the wind, whips something, it strikes it sharply.
If someone whips something out or whips it off, they take it out or take it off very quickly and suddenly.
When you whip something liquid such as cream or an egg, you stir it very fast until it is thick or stiff.

voca.means_ko: (사냥개 따위를) 채찍으로 불러 모으다\n(의원 등)에게 등원을 촉구하다, 지령을 내려 ~을 모으다

채찍질 하여 나아가게 하다, 재촉하다\n휙 입다, 걸치다

voca.means_en: to deliberately make somebody feel strong emotions or get excited about or interested in something\n

voca.means_ko: [워얼]\n빙빙돌다, 회전하다, 질주하다, 급히가다\n회전, 선회, 소용돌이, 소동, 혼란
voca.means_en:
If something or someone whirls around or if you whirl them around, they move around or turn around very quickly.
You can refer to a lot of intense activity as a whirl of activity.
If you decide to give an activity a whirl, you do it even though it is something that you have never tried before.
"Where is it?" said Jack, whirling around.

voca.means_ko: [윗쓸]\n휘파람, 호각, 경적, (기차, 배 등의) 기적, 경적\n휘파람을 불다
voca.means_en:
When you whistle or when you whistle a tune, you make a series of musical notes by forcing your breath out between your lips, or your teeth.
When someone whistles, they make a sound by forcing their breath out between their lips or their teeth. People sometimes whistle when they are surprised or shocked, or to call a dog, or to show that they are impressed.
If something such as a train or a kettle whistles, it makes a loud, high sound.
If something such as the wind or a bullet whistles somewhere, it moves there, making a loud, high sound.
A whistle is a loud sound produced by air or steam being forced through a small opening, or by something moving quickly through the air.
A whistle is a small metal tube which you blow in order to produce a loud sound and attract someone's attention.
A whistle is a simple musical instrument in the shape of a metal pipe with holes.

voca.means_en:
half / whole / quarter
If you refer to the whole of something, you mean all of it.
A whole is a single thing which contains several different parts.
If something is whole, it is in one piece and is not broken or damaged.
You use whole to emphasize what you are saying.
If you refer to something as a whole, you are referring to it generally and as a single unit.
You use on the whole to indicate that what you are saying is true in general but may not be true in every case, or that you are giving a general opinion or summary of something.
very much; a lot\n

to enjoy yourself in a noisy and excited way\nto try to make people excited or enthusiastic about somebody/something\n
used in questions to mean 'why?', expressing surprise
They hollowed out a rock, filled it with animal fat, then burned a wick made from moss.\n

voca.means_en:
Something that is wide measures a large distance from one side or edge to the other.
A wide smile is one in which your mouth is stretched because you are very pleased or amused.
If you open or spread something wide, you open or spread it as far as possible or to the fullest extent.
You use wide to talk or ask about how much something measures from one side or edge to the other.
You use wide to describe something that includes a large number of different things or people.
You use wide to say that something is found, believed, known, or supported by many people or throughout a large area.

voca.means_ko: [와이든]\n~을 넓히다, 넓어지다\n(정도, 범위 등이) 커지다, 확대되다, 키우다, 확대하다
voca.means_en:
If you widen something or if it widens, it becomes greater in measurement from one side or edge to the other.
If you widen something or if it widens, it becomes greater in range or it affects a larger number of people or things.
If your eyes widen, they open more.
If a difference or gap widens or if something widens it, it becomes greater.
Annie's eyes widened.

The width of something is the distance it measures from one side or edge to the other.
The width of something is its quality of being wide.
A width is the distance from one side of a swimming pool to the other.
A wig is a covering of false hair which you wear on your head, for example because you have little hair of your own or because you want to cover up your own hair.\n
If you wiggle something or if it wiggles, it moves up and down or from side to side in small quick movements.\nIt was cold and scaly. It wiggled and jerked!\n

voca.means_en:
Wild animals or plants live or grow in natural surroundings and are not looked after by people.
Wild land is natural and is not used by people.
Wild is used to describe the weather or the sea when it is stormy.
Wild behaviour is uncontrolled, excited, or energetic.
If you describe someone or their behaviour as wild, you mean that they behave in a very uncontrolled way.
If someone is wild, they are very angry.

If you refer to someone or something as a wild card in a particular situation, you mean that they cause uncertainty because you do not know how they will behave.
If a sports player is given a wild card for a particular competition, they are allowed to play in it, although they have not qualified for it in the usual way. You can also use wild card to refer to a player who enters a competition in this way.
A wildcard is a symbol such as * or ? which is used in some computing commands or searches in order to represent any character or range of characters.
A wildebeest is a large African antelope which has a hairy tail, short curved horns, and long hair under its neck. Wildebeest usually live in large groups.\n

A wildfire is a fire that starts, usually by itself, in a wild area such as a forest, and spreads rapidly, causing great damage.\nIf something, especially news or a rumour, spreads like wildfire, it spreads extremely quickly.\n
You can use wildlife to refer to the animals and other living things that live in the wild.\n

극도로, 아주 몹시
voca.means_en:
You use wildly to emphasize the degree, amount, or intensity of something.
The rope ladder was dancing wildly in the wind.
Jack and Annie looked around wildly.

voca.means_en: If someone is willing to do something, they are fairly happy about doing it and will do it if they are asked or required to do it.\nWilling is used to describe someone who does something fairly enthusiastically and because they want to do it rather than because they are forced to do it.\n
A willow or a willow tree is a type of tree with long branches and long narrow leaves that grows near water.\n

voca.means_en: A person who is willowy is tall, thin, and graceful.\n

win - won - won
If you win something such as a competition, battle, or argument, you defeat those people you are competing or fighting against, or you do better than everyone else involved.
If something wins you something such as an election, competition, battle, or argument, it causes you to defeat the people competing with you or fighting you, or to do better than everyone else involved.
If you win something such as a prize or medal, you get it because you have defeated everyone else in something such as an election, competition, battle, or argument, or have done very well in it.
If you win something that you want or need, you succeed in getting it.
to gain somebody's support or approval, especially by persuading them that you are right\n

voca.means_en:
wind - wound - wound
A wind is a current of air that is moving across the earth's surface.
Journalists often refer to a trend or factor that influences events as a wind of a particular kind.
Wind is the air that you sometimes swallow with food or drink, or gas that is produced in your intestines, which causes an uncomfortable feeling.
If you are winded by something such as a blow, the air is suddenly knocked out of your lungs so that you have difficulty breathing for a short time
The wind section of an orchestra or band is the group of people who produce musical sounds by blowing into their instruments.

If a road, river, or line of people winds in a particular direction, it goes in that direction with a lot of bends or twists in it.
When you wind something flexible around something else, you wrap it around it several times.
When you wind a mechanical device, for example a watch or a clock, you turn a knob, key, or handle on it several times in order to make it operate.
To wind a tape or film back or forward means to make it move towards its starting or ending position.

voca.means_ko: 긴장을 풀다, 긴장을 풀고 쉬다\n서서히 멈추다
voca.means_en:
to relax, after a period of stress or excitement
if a machine winds down, it goes slowly and then stops
if a business winds down, it gradually reduces the amount of work it does until it closes completely

voca.means_ko: [와인d 업]\n(연설, 모임 등을) 마무리 짓다\n(어떤 장소, 상황에) 처하게 되다
voca.means_en: to make a machine, etc. work by turning a handle several times\nto bring something such as a speech, a meeting or a discussion to an end\n

a curving or sinuous course or movement
anything that has been wound or wrapped around something
a particular manner or style in which something has been wound
a curve, bend, or complete turn in wound material, a road, etc

A windmill is a building with long pieces of wood on the outside which turn around as the wind blows and provide energy for a machine that crushes grain. A windmill is also a similar structure that is used to convert the power of the wind into electricity.\n

A window is a space in the wall of a building or in the side of a vehicle, which has glass in it so that light can come in and you can see out.
A window is a large piece of glass along the front of a shop, behind which some of the goods that the shop sells are displayed.
A window is a glass-covered opening above a counter, for example in a bank, post office, railway station, or museum, which the person serving you sits behind.
If you have a window in your diary for something, or if you can make a window for it, you are free at a particular time and can do it then.
If you say that something such as a plan or a particular way of thinking or behaving has gone out of the window or has flown out of the window, you mean that it has disappeared completely.
A windowsill is a shelf along the bottom of a window, either inside or outside a building.\n

voca.means_en: A windswept place has no shelter and is not protected against strong winds.\nThey stared at the windswept snow.\n

The wings of a bird or insect are the two parts of its body that it uses for flying.
The wings of an aeroplane are the long flat parts sticking out of its side which support it while it is flying.
A wing of a building is a part of it which sticks out from the main part.
A wing of an organization, especially a political organization, is a group within it which has a particular function or particular beliefs.
In a theatre, the wings are the sides of the stage which are hidden from the audience by curtains or scenery.
In a game such as football or hockey, the left wing and the right wing are the areas on the far left and the far right of the pitch. You can also refer to the players who play in these positions as the left wing and the right wing.
If you say that something or someone wings their way somewhere or wings somewhere, you mean that they go there quickly, especially by plane.
do something without planning or preparing it first; improvise\n

If you wipe something, you rub its surface to remove dirt or liquid from it.
If you wipe dirt or liquid from something, you remove it, for example by using a cloth or your hand.
A wipe is a small moist cloth for cleaning things and is designed to be used only once.
He took off his glasses to wipe off the snow.\n

voca.means_en:
A wire is a long thin piece of metal that is used to fasten things or to carry electric current.
A wire is a cable which carries power or signals from one place to another.
A wire is the same as a telegram.
If you wire something such as a building or piece of equipment, you put wires inside it so that electricity or signals can pass into or through it.
If you wire an amount of money to a person or place, you tell a bank to send it to the person or place using a telegram message.
If something goes to the wire, it continues until the last possible moment.

Wisdom is the ability to use your experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions or judgments.
Wisdom is the store of knowledge that a society or culture has collected over a long period of time.
If you talk about the wisdom of a particular decision or action, you are talking about how sensible it is.
You can use wisdom to refer to ideas that are accepted by a large number of people.
A wise person is able to use their experience and knowledge in order to make sensible decisions and judgments.\nA wise action or decision is sensible.\n
to become aware of the unpleasant truth about a situation\n
"You shouldn't have been goofing off" said Annie wisely.\n

voca.means_en: A wisp of hair is a small, thin, untidy bunch of it.\nA wisp of something such as smoke or cloud is an amount of it in a long thin shape.\n

voca.means_ko:
[위쓰d롸-]
(뒤로) 물러나다, 철수하다, 빼다, 철수키시가, 
(계좌에서 돈을) 인출하다,
취소하다, 철회하다
voca.means_en:
If you withdraw something from a place, you remove it or take it away.
When groups of people such as troops withdraw or when someone withdraws them, they leave the place where they are fighting or where they are based and return nearer home.
If you withdraw money from a bank account, you take it out of that account.
If you withdraw from an activity or organization, you stop taking part in it.
If you withdraw a remark or statement that you have made, you say that you want people to ignore it.

voca.means_ko:
[위쓰d롸얼]
철회, 취소, 철수, 회수
기권, 탈퇴, 
인출, (약물 중독 등으로 인한) 금단
voca.means_en:
The withdrawal of something is the act or process of removing it, or ending it.
Someone's withdrawal from an activity or an organization is their decision to stop taking part in it.
A withdrawal is an amount of money that you take from your bank account.
Withdrawal is the period during which someone feels ill after they have stopped taking a drug which they were addicted to.
If someone or something withers, they become very weak.\nIf a flower or plant withers, it dries up and dies.\n
If something is within a place, area, or object, it is inside it or surrounded by it.\nSomething that happens or exists within a society, organization, or system, happens or exists inside it.\n

voca.means_ko: 잡을 수 있는 곳에, 손이 닿는 곳에

voca.means_en: You use without to indicate that someone or something does not have or use the thing mentioned.\n
immediately; without stopping to think about something further\n
without objecting or hesitating.\nThey accepted without demur.\n
used to emphasize that the statement you are making is always true and everyone or everything is included.\nAll students without exception must take the English examination.\n
used for emphasizing that something always happens or must happen.\nShe sends me a Christmas card every year without fail.\n
without delaying; immediately.\nSo without further ado, let's get on with tonight's show.\n
without affecting any other legal matter.\nThey agreed to pay compensation without prejudice.\n

voca.means_ko: [윗t니s]\n목격자, 입회인, 증언, 증거, 증명\n~을 목격하다, 증명/증언하다
voca.means_en:
notice / note / detect / observe / witness / perceive
A witness to an event such as an accident or crime is a person who saw it.
A witness is someone who appears in a court of law to say what they know about a crime or other event.
A witness is someone who writes their name on a document that you have signed, to confirm that it really is your signature.
If you witness something, you see it happen.
If someone witnesses your signature on a document, they write their name after it, to confirm that it really is your signature.
If you say that a place, period of time, or person witnessed a particular event or change, you mean that it happened in that place, during that period of time, or while that person was alive.
funny / amusing / entertaining / witty / humorous / comic / hilarious\nSomeone or something that is witty is amusing in a clever way.\n

voca.means_ko:
[와붤]
(불안정하게) 흔들리다, 떨리다, 
(불안정하게) 뒤뚱거리며 가다
주저하다, (마음이) 흔들리다
(불안정하게 약간) 흔들림/떨림, 동요
voca.means_en: If something or someone wobbles, they make small movements from side to side, for example because they are unsteady.\n

Something that is wobbly moves unsteadily from side to side.\nIf you feel wobbly or if your legs feel wobbly, you feel weak and have difficulty standing up, especially because you are afraid, ill, or exhausted.\n

A wolf is a wild animal that looks like a large dog.
If someone wolfs their food, they eat it all very quickly and greedily.
If someone cries wolf, they say that there is a problem when there is not, with the result that people do not believe them when there really is a problem.

voca.means_ko:
[원더r]
궁금하다, 궁금해 하다, ~할까 생각하다
(정중한 부탁, 질문에서) ~일지 모르겠다,
(크게) 놀라다
놀라움, 경이, 감탄,
voca.means_en:
If you wonder about something, you think about it, either because it interests you and you want to know more about it, or because you are worried or suspicious about it.
If you wonder at something, you are very surprised about it or think about it in a very surprised way.
If you say that it is a wonder that something happened, you mean that it is very surprising and unexpected.
Wonder is a feeling of great surprise and pleasure that you have, for example when you see something that is very beautiful, or when something happens that you thought was impossible.
If you refer, for example, to a young man as a wonder boy, or to a new product as a wonder drug, you mean that they are believed by many people to be very good or very effective.
to be very surprised by something\n
save / rescue / bail out / redeem\nIf you describe something or someone as wonderful, you think they are extremely good.\n

Wood is the material which forms the trunks and branches of trees.
A wood is a fairly large area of trees growing near each other. You can refer to one or several of these areas as woods, and this is the usual form in American English.
If something or someone is not out of the woods yet, they are still having difficulties or problems.

voca.means_ko: [우든]\n나무로 된, 나무로 만든\n(표정, 감정, 움직임이) 경직된, 뻣뻣한, 딱딱한
voca.means_en: Wooden objects are made of wood.\nIf you describe an actor as wooden, you are critical of them because their performance is not at all lively or natural.\n
A woodpecker is a type of bird with a long sharp beak. Woodpeckers use their beaks to make holes in tree trunks.\n

Wool is the hair that grows on sheep and on some other animals.
Wool is a material made from animal's wool that is used to make things such as clothes, blankets, and carpets.
If you say that someone is pulling the wool over your eyes, you mean that they are trying to deceive you, in order to have an advantage over you.

voca.means_ko:
[월뤼]
양모로 된, 털이 있는, (생각이) 뚜렷하지 않은
털이 뒤덮인, 털북숭이의, 
털이 난 동물, 양, 모직 옷
voca.means_en:
Something that is woolly is made of wool or looks like wool.
If you describe a person or their ideas as woolly, you are criticizing them for being confused or vague.
A woolly is a woollen piece of clothing, especially a sweate
The woolly mommoth roared and plunged forward.

voca.means_ko: 작업하다, 수리하다, ~ 에 작용하다\n~에 노력을 들이다, 착수하다

voca.means_en: A workhorse is a horse which is used to do a job, for example to pull a plough.\nIf you describe a person or a machine as a workhorse, you mean that they can be relied upon to do a large amount of work, especially work that is dull or routine.\n

voca.means_ko: [워rk압]\n(정확한 진단을 내리기 위한) 일련의 정밀 검사\n잠정안, 시안
voca.means_en:
to arouse the feelings of; excite
to cause to grow or develop
to move or cause to move gradually upwards
to manipulate or mix into a specified object or shape
If something exists or happens worldwide, it exists or happens throughout the world.\n

voca.means_ko: [워-엄]\n(땅 속에 사는) 벌레, 기생충, 애벌래, 유충\n꿈틀거리며 나아가다, 천천히 움직이다
voca.means_en:
A worm is a small animal with a long thin body, no bones and no legs.
If animals or people have worms, worms are living in their intestines.
A worm is a computer program that contains a virus which duplicates itself many times in a network.
If you worm an animal, you give it medicine in order to kill the worms that are living in its intestines.
If you say that someone is worming their way to success, or is worming their way into someone else's affection, you disapprove of the way that they are gradually making someone trust them or like them, often in order to deceive them or gain some advantage.
Worn is the past participle of wear.\nWorn is used to describe something that is damaged or thin because it is old and has been used a lot.\n

voca.means_ko: 써서 낡은, 닳아 해진, 진부한, 케케묵은, 녹초가 된

voca.means_en: worried / concerned / nervous / anxious / uneasy\nWhen you are worried, you are unhappy because you keep thinking about problems that you have or about unpleasant things that might happen in the future.\n
Something that is worrisome causes people to worry.\n

voca.means_ko:
[워-뤼]
걱정하다, 걱정/불안하게 만들다, 
성가시게/귀찮게 하다, 괴롭히다/집적거리다
걱정, 근심, 우려
voca.means_en:
If you worry, you keep thinking about problems that you have or about unpleasant things that might happen.
If someone or something worries you, they make you anxious because you keep thinking about problems or unpleasant things that might be connected with them.
If someone or something does not worry you, you do not dislike them or you are not annoyed by them.
Worry is the state or feeling of anxiety and unhappiness caused by the problems that you have or by thinking about unpleasant things that might happen.
A worry is a problem that you keep thinking about and that makes you unhappy.

voca.means_ko: ~을 물고 당기다/흔들다\n(해답을 찾으려고) ~을 곰곰히 생각하다, ~을 가지고 고심하다
voca.means_en: if an animal such as a dog worries at something, it holds it in its teeth and shakes it about\nto think or talk a lot about a problem and try to find a solution\n

더 나쁘게, 더 심하게
voca.means_en: Worse is the comparative of bad.\nWorse is the comparative of badly.\nWorse is used to form the comparative of compound adjectives beginning with 'bad' and 'badly.' For example, the comparative of 'badly off' is 'worse off'.

voca.means_ko: 재수 없게도(말이지)!\n(어떤일에 대한 실망을 나타내는 말)
voca.means_en: used to show that you are disappointed about something\n

voca.means_ko: [워r쉽]\n예배, 예배식, 참배, 숭배, 존경, 참미\n(교회에서) 예배하다, 존경/찬양하다
voca.means_en: If you worship a god, you show your respect to the god, for example by saying prayers.\nIf you worship someone or something, you love them or admire them very much.\n

Worst is the superlative of bad.
Worst is the superlative of badly.
Worst is used to form the superlative of compound adjectives beginning with 'bad' and 'badly'. For example, the superlative of 'badly-affected' is 'worst-affected'.
The worst is the most unpleasant or unfavourable thing that could happen or does happen.
You say worst of all to indicate that what you are about to mention is the most unpleasant or has the most disadvantages out of all the things you are mentioning.

voca.means_ko:
[워r쓰]
(금전 등의 면에서) ~의 가치가 있는/되는, 
~할 가치가 있는, ~해 볼만한, 
가치, 값어치, 재산
가치가 있는
voca.means_en:
price / cost / value / expense / worth
If something is worth a particular amount of money, it can be sold for that amount or is considered to have that value.
If you say that something is worth having, you mean that it is pleasant or useful, and therefore a good thing to have.
If something is worth a particular action, or if an action is worth doing, it is considered to be important enough for that action.
Worth combines with amounts of money, so that when you talk about a particular amount of money's worth of something, you mean the quantity of it that you can buy for that amount of money.
Worth combines with time expressions, so you can use worth when you are saying how long an amount of something will last. For example, a week's worth of food is the amount of food that will last you for a week.
Someone's worth is the value, usefulness, or importance that they are considered to have.
If something is worthwhile, it is enjoyable or useful, and worth the time, money, or effort that is spent on it.\n

voca.means_ko:
[워r듸]
~을 받을만한, (~을 받을) 자격이 있는,
훌륭한, 괜찮은, 
~ 할만한, ~에 어울리는
중요한 인물
voca.means_en: If a person or thing is worthy of something, they deserve it because they have the qualities or abilities required.\nA worthy person or thing is approved of by most people in society and considered to be morally respectable or correct.\n

injure / wound / hurt / bruise / maim / sprain / pull / twist / strain
A wound is damage to part of your body, especially a cut or a hole in your flesh, which is caused by a gun, knife, or other weapon.
A wound is a lasting bad effect on someone's mind or feelings caused by a very upsetting experience.
If a weapon or something sharp wounds you, it damages your body.
If you are wounded by what someone says or does, your feelings are deeply hurt.

voca.means_ko:
[뤱p]
(포장지 등으로) 싸다, 표장하다, 
(무엇의 둘레를 단단히) 두르다, 걸치다
싸는 물건, 덥개, 포장지
voca.means_en:
When you wrap something, you fold paper or cloth tightly round it to cover it completely, for example in order to protect it or so that you can give it to someone as a present.
When you wrap something such as a piece of paper or cloth round another thing, you put it around it.
If someone wraps their arms, fingers, or legs around something, they put them firmly around it.
Wrap is the material that something is wrapped in.
If you keep something under wraps, you keep it secret, often until you are ready to announce it at some time in the future.
(in something) to cover something in paper or other material, to protect it or because you are giving it to somebody as a present\nto complete something in an acceptable way\n
to put warm clothes, etc. on yourself/somebody\n

voca.means_ko:

난파선, (심하게 부서진) 사고 자동차, 
(비행기 등의) 잔해
(육체적, 정신적으로) 망가진 사람, 만신창이
망가뜨리다, 파괴하다, 엉망으로 만들다
voca.means_en:
crash / slam / collide / smash / wreck
To wreck something means to completely destroy or ruin it.
If a ship is wrecked, it is damaged so much that it sinks or can no longer sail.
A wreck is something such as a ship, car, plane, or building which has been destroyed, usually in an accident.
A wreck is an accident in which a moving vehicle hits something and is damaged or destroyed.
If you say that someone is a wreck, you mean that they are very exhausted or unhealthy.

voca.means_ko:
