비틀다, 비틀어 떼다, 잡아떼다
(법, 사실 등을) 왜곡하다, (의미를) 억지로 맞추다
비틀기, 왜곡, 부정 행위
voca.means_en: If you wrest something from someone else, you take it from them, especially when this is difficult or illegal.\nIf you wrest something from someone who is holding it, you take it from them by pulling or twisting it violently.\n
to take something such as power or control from somebody/something with great effort\nto take something from somebody that they do not want to give, suddenly or violently\n

voca.means_ko: [뤠슬]\n몸싸움을 벌이다, 맞붙어 싸우다, 레슬링 하다\n(힘든 문제를 해결하기 위해) 씨름하다, 허우적거리다
voca.means_en:
When you wrestle with a difficult problem, you try to deal with it.
If you wrestle with someone, you fight them by forcing them into painful positions or throwing them to the ground, rather than by hitting them. Some people wrestle as a sport.
If you wrestle a person or thing somewhere, you move them there using a lot of force, for example by twisting a part of someone's body into a painful position.
to struggle to deal with something difficult\n
A wrestler is someone who wrestles as a sport, usually for money.\n

voca.means_ko:
[륑끌]
(특히 얼굴위) 주름, (옷, 종이 등에 생긴) 주름/구김살
~에 주름을 잡다, 주름이 지다
찡그리다
voca.means_en:
Wrinkles are lines which form on someone's face as they grow old.
A wrinkle is a raised fold in a piece of cloth or paper that spoils its appearance.
When someone's skin wrinkles or when something wrinkles it, lines start to form in it because the skin is getting old or damaged.
If cloth wrinkles, or if someone or something wrinkles it, it gets folds or lines in it.
When you wrinkle your nose or forehead, or when it wrinkles, you tighten the muscles in your face so that the skin folds.
Your wrist is the part of your body between your hand and your arm which bends when you move your hand.\n

When you write something on a surface, you use something such as a pen or pencil to produce words, letters, or numbers on the surface.
If you write something such as a book, a poem, or a piece of music, you create it and record it on paper or perhaps on a computer.
Someone who writes creates books, stories, or articles, usually for publication.
When you write to someone or write them a letter, you give them information, ask them something, or express your feelings in a letter. In American English, you can also write someone.
When someone writes something such as a cheque, receipt, or prescription, they put the necessary information on it and usually sign it.
If you write to a computer or a disk, you record data on it.
to write in reply to somebody's letter\n

voca.means_ko: (특히 기억하거나 기록하기 위해) ~을 적다\n(회계 장부에서) ~을 감가상각하다
voca.means_en: to write something on paper so that you do not forget it\nto reduce the value of what a company owns when stating it in the company's accounts\n
to cancel a debt; to recognize that something is a failure, has no value, etc.\nto consider that somebody/something is a failure or not important\n
to write something on paper clearly, including all the details\n

voca.means_ko:
[뤄엉]
나쁨, 부정
잘못된, 틀린, 부적절한, 원하는 것이 아닌
잘못하여
voca.means_en:
wrong / wrongly / wrongfully
If you say there is something wrong, you mean there is something unsatisfactory about the situation, person, or thing you are talking about.
If you choose the wrong thing, person, or method, you make a mistake and do not choose the one that you really want.
If something such as a decision, choice, or action is the wrong one, it is not the best or most suitable one.
If something is wrong, it is incorrect and not in accordance with the facts.
If something is wrong or goes wrong with a machine or piece of equipment, it stops working properly.
A wrong is an unfair or immoral action.
If someone wrongs you, they treat you in an unfair way.
wrong / wrongly / wrongfully\n

If you yank someone or something somewhere, you pull them there suddenly and with a lot of force.\nSome people refer to people from the United States of America as Yanks. This use could cause offence.\n
to pull at something hard and quickly\n
to remove something by pulling it quickly and hard\n
to remove somebody/something from somewhere by pulling hard and quickly\n

factory / plant / mill / works / yard / workshop / foundry
A yard is a unit of length equal to thirty-six inches or approximately 91.4 centimetres.
A yard is a flat area of concrete or stone that is next to a building and often has a wall around it.
You can refer to a large open area where a particular type of work is done as a yard.
A yard is a piece of land next to someone's house, with grass and plants growing in it.

If you yawn, you open your mouth very wide and breathe in more air than usual, often when you are tired or when you are not interested in something.
A gap or an opening that yawns is large and wide, and often frightening.
If you describe something such as a book or a film as a yawn, you think it is very boring.

shout / yell / scream / cheer / cry / call
If you yell, you shout loudly, usually because you are excited, angry, or in pain.
A yell is a loud shout given by someone who is afraid or in pain.

voca.means_ko: [엘읍]\n(보통 아파서) 꺅 하고 비명을 지르다 (꽥 악을 쓰다)
voca.means_en: If a person or dog yelps, they give a sudden short cry, often because of fear or pain.\nYipping and yelping\n
You use yesterday to refer to the day before today.\nYou can refer to the past, especially the recent past, as yesterday.\n

voca.means_ko:
[옛t]
(부정문, 의문문에서) 아직 (안 했거나 못했다는 뜻)
이제/앞으로, 
그렇지만, 그런데도
voca.means_en:
already / just / yet
You use yet in negative statements to indicate that something has not happened up to the present time, although it probably will happen. You can also use yet in questions to ask if something has happened up to the present time. In British English the simple past tense is not normally used with this meaning of `yet'.
You use yet with a negative statement when you are talking about the past, to report something that was not the case then, although it became the case later.
If you say that something should not or cannot be done yet, you mean that it should not or cannot be done now, although it will have to be done at a later time.
You use yet after a superlative to indicate, for example, that something is the worst or the best of its kind up to the present time.
You can use yet after expressions which refer to a period of time, when you want to say how much longer a situation will continue for.
If you say that you have yet to do something, you mean that you have never done it, especially when this is surprising or bad.

voca.means_ko:
[이-일d]
(수익, 결과, 농작물 등을) 산출/생산하다, 
가져오다, 넘겨주다, 양도하다,
야기하다
(농작물의) 산출량, 총수익
voca.means_en:
If you yield to someone or something, you stop resisting them.
If you yield something that you have control of or responsibility for, you allow someone else to have control or responsibility for it.
If a moving person or a vehicle yields, they slow down or stop in order to allow other people or vehicles to pass in front of them.
If something yields, it breaks or moves position because force or pressure has been put on it.
A yield is the amount of food produced on an area of land or by a number of animals.
A yield is the amount of money or profit produced by an investment.
to be replaced by something\n
If a dog or other animal yips, it gives a sudden short cry, often because of fear or pain.\nYipping and yelping\n
He heard a yowl in the distance.\nIf a person or an animal yowls, they make a long loud cry, especially because they are sad or in pain.\n
an exclamation indicating contempt, dislike, or disgust\n
Zeal is great enthusiasm, especially in connection with work, religion, or politics.\n
A zigzag is a line which has a series of angles in it like a continuous series of 'W's.\nIf you zigzag, you move forward by going at an angle first to one side then to the other.\n
If you talk about a zillion people or things, you are emphasizing that there is an extremely large number of them.\n

The zodiac is a diagram used by astrologers to represent the positions of the planets and stars. It is divided into twelve sections, each of which has its own name and symbol. The zodiac is used to try to calculate the influence of the planets, especially on someone's life.\n

구분/구획하다
voca.means_en: A zone is an area that has particular features or characteristics.\nIf an area of land is zoned, it is formally set aside for a particular purpose.\n
to fall asleep, become unconscious or stop paying attention\n
A zoo is a park where live animals are kept so that people can look at them.\n

voca.means_ko: [쥬움]\n움직이다, 질주하다, 급등하다, 확대/축소하다\n급상승, 붕하는 소리, 줌 렌즈
voca.means_en:
If you zoom somewhere, you go there very quickly.
A zoom is the same as a zoom lens.
One zoomed right by the boat.
if a camera zooms in/out, it shows the object that is being photographed from closer/further away, by using a zoom lens\n
The buggy zoomed out of the crater.\n
